number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												This was another game that I Kickstarted and then let linger for years before actually playing, hence the late review.Wasteland 2 is overall a pretty good game that could have been pretty great. As one reviewer said, in many ways it's the game that Fallout 3 should have been -- much more a spiritual successor to the earlier Fallout games than F3 was (although F3 is a great game in its own right). So why do I say it wasn't great? Well, the experience was marred by a few serious flaws that became more serious and irritating as the game continued on.First, the game is buggy as hell, and this is saying a lot for a game that came out three years ago. There are a lot of things that don't trigger properly, causing you to either find weird workarounds or say, 'Oh well,' about not being able to quite finish that side-quest or sub-plot that you worked so hard toward. The game gives you an extra smack in the face at the end when it summarizes a bunch of things about various characters you met in the game, often spelling out doom for people you saved because the game never quite recognized that you saved them. (Although this did work in my favour once, when the game claimed that a dead character ran away and had his "happily ever after" with his wife.)Second, as your characters become more powerful, there will be increasing numbers of things that you can't do Because Plot. There will be things that you can do in every case but the important ones, when your ability will inexplicably just not work on the target you wanted to use it on, which can be extra frustrating when you worked hard to get that ability just for that reason. Third, the pacing and difficulty are both very poorly done. There are areas where even if you're playing on the easiest difficulty, you're dominating like mad and then there's just a giant difficulty cliff, after which you're dominating like mad again. And the smooth overlapping of one task with the next falls apart in a few key places where you're just left with little or nothing to do. Couple that with poor hinting, bugs that can cause task markers to not appear, and show-stopping bugs, and the game will have you hitting up the internet for guides increasingly frequently as it goes on, even if just to confirm that something's a bug.Lastly, the UI and graphics could have used a lot more work. The use of UI elements is inconsistent, and a good chunk of the "I can't X" posts on the internet turn out to be resolved by, "Oh, you have to do it this totally new/different/unexpected way instead". Many key quest items don't look the way you'd expect. The succession of rad suits is so terrible and easy to screw up I'd just call it broken. And there are many instances where targets or even movement waypoints are obscured by the terrain making them almost impossible to click on no matter how you rotate the camera. Additionally, the game is only even vaguely playable zoomed out, but there are a lot of things you'll only notice when zoomed in, and you'll frequently hear the "I noticed something," sound and not be able to determine what caused it. Oh, and the system of having to design a 3D character model and then also pick a portrait from a terribly small list is awful and leads to almost none of your characters' portraits looking anything like the characters. (Oh, and while I'm complaining, the changes from one gender to another when putting on the same item of clothing are semi-random and often vaguely eyebrow-raising, with the 'female' version almost always bearing no resemblance whatsoever to the item's description).The fact that, despite all of that, I'm still giving it a thumbs-up, and that should tell you a lot about how strong the rest of the game is and about how strong a game this could have been with a bit more polish. It's engaging, challenging, has a compelling storyline and lots of interesting locales, and is often hilarious as all get-out. It also took me about 64 hours to complete, which makes its price (about $50 when not on sale) pretty reasonable, if not quite the best deal possible. But given that it's been a GOTA edition *and* a Director's Cut, I still expected it to be closer to what it could have been than what it is.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Wasteland 2 is a modern throwback to a long-gone era of gaming, when CRPGs were epic, and it wasn't uncommon to play one for weeks and still not reach the end; an era before hand-holding, where your decisions had real consequences.Pros:Huge amount of freedom with character skills and attributesChoices matter, truly affecting how the game's story unfoldsA very large number of playable characters that can join your partyInteresting story with decent voice actingIntuitive turn-based tactical combatSeveral, several hours of gameplayEvokes memories of Fallout, X-COM, and Baldur's Gate.Cons:Not all bugs have been worked out, but I've not run into anything gamebreakingThe graphics could be optimized better; even on a pretty modern system, I lag at the mid-range settingsSteep learning curve - you will probably start over after getting the hang of things (but it's worth it)Calculations for skill usage are a bit too simplified - and attributes only affect combat.Requires time to commit to the game, due to the length.In short, it's right up my alley, but for those unfamiliar with the genre, or who are looking for a super deep experience like Planescape: Torment, it may not be their cup of tea.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Well, a solid 41 hours later leaves me with a rather lacklustre sense of achievement, and a general confusion and frustration with how long it took to end. The lack of tactical options is frustrating - to say the least. Definitely an improvement over similar modern titles in the like of XCom, however compared to the classics the tactical options still fall tremendously short.I also have trouble seeing past the walls of text - in the end, I just didn't care. I didn't care about the characters, I didn't care about the storyline, the game just left me with a general sense of "meh". The throwbacks to pop culture were initally funny, but dragged on and ultimately became just another "meh" moment.The skill system became trivial towards the end of the game, where there were more than enough points to go around.Difficulty curve? The "difficult" part of the game is scaled by opponent health, which, after carrying around launchers for most of the game, quickly disappeared. I think the "hardest" part of the game was working out which option to choose, which in itself is another attempt at "grey" decisions. Spoilers ahead;I saved the AG centre. I never saw ANY repecussions in the game world for not saving Highpool, besides a slightly different map and a shout-out at the end of the game, trying to guilt trip the player because of a choice they could do nothing over. If I'd saved Highpool, I probably wouild have received the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.I also defused the nuke in the canyon. The monks disappeared? No cares whatsoever - I never saw any repecussions in my game, except for a slightly different map on the way out of♥♥♥♥♥♥central. Overall, a very solid "meh" out of 10.Didn't care about the story, didn't care about the characters, didn't care for the combat system. Not even sure why I finished it, but I did. So that's something.

Posted: October 19, 2014
												What can be said about this game. I never played the first game, and never really got into it when i tried. But that does not mean i do not know of it. I watched full walkthroughs to understand the first game years before Wasteland 2 was a recent concept. Because i am a fan of the Post-Apocolyptic genre, i knew Wasteland 2 would apeal to me as Fallout's 1, 2, 3, and New Vegas has done for me in the past. This game, from what i know of as one of the bigger kickstarter projects of its time, is well worth it. This game is not only a "True" sequal to the first game, but it also is NOT half-asses like some other abondoned Early Release titles that never were finished. Not only was thsi game finished, but the story is compelling, the charactors are likable, the voice acting is incredible, and the overall gameplay is rock solid with very minute bugs every now and again (enemy i was fighting once fell through the ground and got stuck in part of the map, kept shooting me but i couldnt shoot him, but i eventually used a grenade and got him).The map design is great, it does get repetative having to backtrack, but at least you have a feeling of accomplishment when you get further into the story. The weapons are great, as well as the skills and leveling aspect (I can have a trained SMG guy be able to mow down enemies with a trained sniper or 2 backing him up).To conclude, this game is great and worth the money for both a great game and a great time waster, because once you start playing, you wont want to put it down any time soon.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												To start, if anyone is having crashing problems on WIN 10, type -force-d3d9 into launch options on Steam. Haven't had a single crash after that.About the game, Wasteland 2 is not for everyone. Not by a long shot. It requires patience, thinking and in some cases, nerves of steel. The top-down view and turn-based combat may turn some people off. It's a hardcore RPG where your choices, starting from the very beginning at character creation, have lasting consequences throughout the game. If you're looking for an experience similar to the more recent Fallout games, you won't find it here.The character creation is intimidating at first, especially for newcomers to these types of games. There are tons of skills and you have no way to know in advance which are useful and which are more situational. I suggest consulting a character creation guide, but if you want to do everything on your own, one tip: make a team of specialists. After character creation, it's good to keep in mind these three things: Talk to EVERYONE, LOOT everything that isn't bolted down (or if it is, Brute Force can help with that ;)) and do EVERYTHING you can before moving to the next area. If you miss something, it might mean missing out on quests, companions or loot.The combat is tactical and turn-based. Director's Cut added precision strikes, which are not too useful at the beginning but can be lifesavers late in the game. It also brough some flavor to the combat system, which can be somewhat tedious at times. I found most of the quirks to be quite useless; their downsides were either too bad or they were too situational.Same goes for perks, they were a nice addition, but when selecting perks I had difficulty finding ones that were actually useful. Overall, precision strikes, quirks and perks feel somewhat like an aftertought; they're there and they're nice to have every once in a while, but they aren't really crucial to completing the game.The weapon rebalancing of DC was a welcome addition. Assault rifles and Snipers are still king, but Shotguns, for example, now actually have some use. SMG's and Handguns still suck, though.Overall, I definitely recommend this game to everyone. While it can be somewhat tedious and difficult at times, it's still a whole lot of fun. The world is huge and there's plenty to do, like blowing off the heads of raiders or solving feuds peacefully. BUT DON'T PRESS THE BUTTON AT RANGER CITADEL!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												A great game for fans of the older style CRPG that seems to be making a comeback.The storyline is good. No real "amazing" moments, but many interesting encounters were had with people throughout the waste. I'm not a fan of the conclusion but the ride to it was still worth taking.The graphics and sound aren't really up to par with today's standards. The actual game looks a little dated. The models are, quite frankly, ugly and character portraits are reused many times (including for characters that descriptions do not match the portrait at all). The music is fitting for most situations, the sound effects decent, and the voice acting...there. But none of them stood out as excellent and the voice acting could range from pretty good to kind of hammy. These are minor complaints, however, for an RPG of this type.Character progression in the game is a bit of a mix bag. Characters with high INT, thus more skill points, are far more playable and useful than those without. By a little planning I was able to have access to just about every useful skill, so I didn't feel as if I missed out on anything in the game. The weapon progression was handled very well I thought. It seemed like every time I was getting tired of someones weapon I was able to get access to a updated version. I did feel like money was a bit of a waste. By the time I found an upgrade I usually had enough gear on me, looted from bodies, to trade to cover the cost without dipping into the actual cash.You are given a large selection of choices to make in the game. Ranging from how you're going to tackle a problem, to who you are going to side with, or even just if you'll go out of your way to help certain people. You'll usually see the outcome of a decision but it often rings a little hollow. A small bit of assistance might be given to you, this person might be slightly more friendly (but probably doesn't have anything additional to say), or even the leader of the town might be entirely different. But that town is still going to look and function exactly the same, the only difference being what person you talk to. Most of the big decisions you make you won't see take effect until after you beat the game and it gives you a summary of what's happening to the people in the waste.All in all I would recommend playing the game. The combat was handled well, there is plenty of content in the game (sometimes it feels like a little to much), and the writing was enjoyable. If you played/enjoyed the first Wasteland there are plenty of references and throwbacks to the game that you'll probably enjoy, so I'd recommend it even more.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												I can't in good conscience recommend this game. Having played it from start to finish, I found the plot lazy, the game mechanics needlessly complicated/annoying, the characters one-dimensional, and the player's agency seemingly absent. Going against enemies with energy weapons? Better strip down to your undies! Find something that's locked? Better hope you have the correct out of SEVEN potential skills needed to open it (Safecracking, Lockpicking, Computer Science, Alarm Disarming, Brute Force, Demolitions, Toaster Repair (?)) at rank 10. Slaughtered every member of a militant cult? Nope, according to the game's post-script, they went on to slaughter everyone in the area because you didn't stop them! Buy Fallout 2 instead.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
Full disclosure: I am close friends with some of the developers of this game, however - I do not feel that this compromises the integrity of my review.I grew up playing the original Fallout, and other isometric-ish RPGs on the infinity engine. I've always had a soft spot in my heart for them and I honestly did not think I could ever return to that feeling.A friend picked up Wasteland 2 for me prior to release - I had my reservations when I started playing, but those went quickly out the window.Sure, it is said you can never go back to paradise -but you can come pretty close.I've just recently had the chance to finish my playthrough of Wasteland 2, the time and fun I've had from this title easily justifies the cost. However I don't think that is what I should leave as the primary point of the review.I am not one who enjoys replaying games, especially ones driven by a central narrative. I rarely find games that truly capture my attention and interest these days but Wasteland 2.. Well lets leave it at the following point:After completing Wasteland 2, I immediately wanted to reload my mid game save and play back through again with a different approach and playstyle to see how it affected the outcome of the game.I've not done that since the 90s. :)Loved this game, my game of the year for 2014.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												A great game for fans of the older style CRPG that seems to be making a comeback.The storyline is good. No real "amazing" moments, but many interesting encounters were had with people throughout the waste. I'm not a fan of the conclusion but the ride to it was still worth taking.The graphics and sound aren't really up to par with today's standards. The actual game looks a little dated. The models are, quite frankly, ugly and character portraits are reused many times (including for characters that descriptions do not match the portrait at all). The music is fitting for most situations, the sound effects decent, and the voice acting...there. But none of them stood out as excellent and the voice acting could range from pretty good to kind of hammy. These are minor complaints, however, for an RPG of this type.Character progression in the game is a bit of a mix bag. Characters with high INT, thus more skill points, are far more playable and useful than those without. By a little planning I was able to have access to just about every useful skill, so I didn't feel as if I missed out on anything in the game. The weapon progression was handled very well I thought. It seemed like every time I was getting tired of someones weapon I was able to get access to a updated version. I did feel like money was a bit of a waste. By the time I found an upgrade I usually had enough gear on me, looted from bodies, to trade to cover the cost without dipping into the actual cash.You are given a large selection of choices to make in the game. Ranging from how you're going to tackle a problem, to who you are going to side with, or even just if you'll go out of your way to help certain people. You'll usually see the outcome of a decision but it often rings a little hollow. A small bit of assistance might be given to you, this person might be slightly more friendly (but probably doesn't have anything additional to say), or even the leader of the town might be entirely different. But that town is still going to look and function exactly the same, the only difference being what person you talk to. Most of the big decisions you make you won't see take effect until after you beat the game and it gives you a summary of what's happening to the people in the waste.All in all I would recommend playing the game. The combat was handled well, there is plenty of content in the game (sometimes it feels like a little to much), and the writing was enjoyable. If you played/enjoyed the first Wasteland there are plenty of references and throwbacks to the game that you'll probably enjoy, so I'd recommend it even more.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I've been playing Fallout 2 since I first bought it new in 98' and never got the chance to ever play Wasteland, although I was aware of it and its profound influence. I picked up this game as soon as I could afford it and have fallen in love with isometric turn based combat all over again. I first played this on my off the shelf HP desktop with just a factory AMD A8-6500 using integrated Radeon 8570D graphics. This game played well with decent performance in all situations without measuring FPS on low settings. I since have added a GTX 750 Ti and can play the game maxed out and it is running over 60fps in all situations. So with my A8 barely on par with an Intel i3, anyone can pretty much enjoy this game on low end systems. Graphics: 10/10, it is beautiful and is what you would expect from a Fallout type universe. Combat: 10/10, some nice features that remind me of FO Tactics, familiar and easy to grasp.Gameplay: 10/10, much like Fallout games there is lots to see and do, side missions and quests, hidden things, locked or blocked things you can't get to until you level up or gain a perk. Good replayability. A major tip for new players: Make sure when building your squad you incorporate certain skills. This is not like Fallout games where you could master all skills throughout the game such as demolitions, lockpick, traps etc. This game forces you to equip characters with these skills or they simply will not be able to be utilized at all until you have a character possesing that particular skill. So if you start your squad and nobody has lockpicking skill, you will not be able to lockpick any doors at all until you acquire someone that does have the skill. If you like Fallout or the genre, you will not be dissapointed! Price has consistently dropped over last few months, I paid full price and would again.

												It's a bit hard to get into at first as it goes back to alot of conventions of older games and you have to really pay attention to figure out what to do. But arizona and california feel like living breathing worlds and everything from combat to characters to storytelling is engaging and deep with a wealth of choices that aren't just good v. evil. The sense of humor is absolutely fantastic, it's never completely overbearing or annoying and it doesn't get in the way of the more heartbreaking moments and I feel it serves a great contrast, you will absolutely find yourself laughing out loud from time to time but you will also find yourself possiby tearing up at other moments. This game isn't heavy on hardware and I honestly feel that even though I'm only 20 hours in every single person who has a pc should at least try this game. This is an absolute MUST play for all pc gamers and lovers of all forms of art.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												What can be said about this game. I never played the first game, and never really got into it when i tried. But that does not mean i do not know of it. I watched full walkthroughs to understand the first game years before Wasteland 2 was a recent concept. Because i am a fan of the Post-Apocolyptic genre, i knew Wasteland 2 would apeal to me as Fallout's 1, 2, 3, and New Vegas has done for me in the past. This game, from what i know of as one of the bigger kickstarter projects of its time, is well worth it. This game is not only a "True" sequal to the first game, but it also is NOT half-asses like some other abondoned Early Release titles that never were finished. Not only was thsi game finished, but the story is compelling, the charactors are likable, the voice acting is incredible, and the overall gameplay is rock solid with very minute bugs every now and again (enemy i was fighting once fell through the ground and got stuck in part of the map, kept shooting me but i couldnt shoot him, but i eventually used a grenade and got him).The map design is great, it does get repetative having to backtrack, but at least you have a feeling of accomplishment when you get further into the story. The weapons are great, as well as the skills and leveling aspect (I can have a trained SMG guy be able to mow down enemies with a trained sniper or 2 backing him up).To conclude, this game is great and worth the money for both a great game and a great time waster, because once you start playing, you wont want to put it down any time soon.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Well, a solid 41 hours later leaves me with a rather lacklustre sense of achievement, and a general confusion and frustration with how long it took to end. The lack of tactical options is frustrating - to say the least. Definitely an improvement over similar modern titles in the like of XCom, however compared to the classics the tactical options still fall tremendously short.I also have trouble seeing past the walls of text - in the end, I just didn't care. I didn't care about the characters, I didn't care about the storyline, the game just left me with a general sense of "meh". The throwbacks to pop culture were initally funny, but dragged on and ultimately became just another "meh" moment.The skill system became trivial towards the end of the game, where there were more than enough points to go around.Difficulty curve? The "difficult" part of the game is scaled by opponent health, which, after carrying around launchers for most of the game, quickly disappeared. I think the "hardest" part of the game was working out which option to choose, which in itself is another attempt at "grey" decisions. Spoilers ahead;I saved the AG centre. I never saw ANY repecussions in the game world for not saving Highpool, besides a slightly different map and a shout-out at the end of the game, trying to guilt trip the player because of a choice they could do nothing over. If I'd saved Highpool, I probably wouild have received the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.I also defused the nuke in the canyon. The monks disappeared? No cares whatsoever - I never saw any repecussions in my game, except for a slightly different map on the way out of♥♥♥♥♥♥central. Overall, a very solid "meh" out of 10.Didn't care about the story, didn't care about the characters, didn't care for the combat system. Not even sure why I finished it, but I did. So that's something.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Phenomenal. This is what happens when you let talent of the likes of Brian Fargo and his dream team of writers and designers (and Mark Morgan) create the game they wish to make: a love letter to classic CRPGs full of rich descriptive text and atmosphere, amazing depth in options, laugh out loud ridiculousness, and several truly chilling moments. In an age of gaming where we've grown tired of pressing the win button, Wasteland 2 throws hundreds of possibilities in your direction and doesn't even pretend to try to hold your hand, allowing you the joy of discovery and surprise as your decisions often leave no clear cut winners. You'll often find yourself under-equipped and struggling to keep your party members alive, tossing those last few rounds of ammo to a teammate and praying for their 35% hit probability to go your way after enemies have left you devastated. And right when you think you've gotten the hang of things, new scenarios will put you firmly back in your place. Wasteland 2 is a shining beacon of what games once were, and a sensational example of what they very well can be today when the fans - and not profits - come first.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Video games critic “Yahtzee” once remarked that he didn’t understand single-player RPGs. What is the appeal? With their emphasis on story over gameplay, why not just read a (good) book? Why interrupt the (maybe good) story with some of gaming’s weakest gameplay? Since then he’s likely discovered that there ARE good RPGs, and that good RPGs don’t emphasize story over gameplay; rather they emphasis both. In fact, the only key difference between an “RPG” and, say, a shooter like Half-Life is that in an “RPG” the development of your avatars’ virtual skill is emphasized (via leveling up, getting more powerful items, etc.) over your muscle memory skills.And here we have Wasteland 2, and like most old- AND new-school RPGs, it manages to emphasize neither gameplay nor story.You may at first find this hard to notice if isometric (“old-school”) RPGs are new to you. Even I was smitten. So turned on was I that, a dozen hours into the game, I donated $30 to InExile’s Torment project (OOPS!), to be followed an hour later by Wasteland 2’s depressing emptiness finally crashing down on me (♥♥♥♥!!!). Its gameplay proved to be just drudgery. To get a picture of it, imagine XCOM, but not anywhere as good, and with the saving angel of “reloading the last save” always being available? Now consider that to play without the reload function would render the game impossible to win within a lifetime, OR SO easy (because you can change the difficulty at any time) that there’s hardly any drama at all. Now add to this an inventory system that demands so much of your “play” time (a time-destroying chore similar in fun to data entry, except you don’t get paid). Then throw in the various versions of locked doors and chests and whatnot that all have their own skill trees. I want to underscore the fact that this last feature is neither fun nor intellectually stimulating, and that you need to do it to win the game. If, InExile, you are going to make your players spend a lot of time deciding where to invest their skill points, then at least make the payoff’s worth it. Make it so there are AWESOME rewards for opening stuff—a cool joke, a sexy weapon or armor set that you won’t find from enemies or shops—not just , soon-to-be-forgotten items. [There are also bugs, which, to their credit, they’re continuing to address.]Now for some almost good news. The writing is almost good. Because of the setting—a nuked one—they, like Bethesda, have gone the mostly-serious tone route. There are moments of cruelty in the game that invoke the horrors of real, demonic human beings, atrocities that happen in, say, Syria and the Congo. And sometimes it’s effective. For example, there’s a scene where a character died a horrible death, and as he or she lay dying, he or she told my party to deliver something to another character in some town. Well, I went to this town and got distracted. And many hours later, across the Arizona map away from the town, I thought, “Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ I forgot to deliver that object!” And I trudged across the game world back towards that town, knowing that it would put me in boring battles with weaker enemies. That is a moment of video game art that taught me something about myself.Moments like these are rare in the game, and the writing is mostly grim for no other reason than to remind players that nuclear holocausts are bad. As for strong characters; I think the leader of the Desert Rangers is named General Vargas. There’s also the Matthias guy. Aaaaand those are all the names I remember from my 50+ hours of playing.As for the plot, it’s an uninspired, boring cliché. To give you an idea of how zero it is, consider this. During the first half of the game, in the Ranger HQ, there’s this nuclear weapon in a museum. And when you press the wrong button, the place explodes and you get a Game Over screen that says, due to there being no Desert Rangers, Matthias and his Robot Army conquer the human race. In other words, InExile do not care about their own story enough to make a truly mysterious (or at least funny) enemy; this of course explains why the plot twists are so pathetically predictable that they basically don’t exist.The NPCs talk a lot of “who is this Matthias person” emptiness, to which I respond, “OH C’MON, HE’S OBVIOUSLY A BORING ROBOT HITLER!”[Robot Hitler, by the way, would be a more compelling, entertaining villain than Matthias.]So if the intellectual bits are rare, and the characters are boring, and the plot is boring, then is it funny?Nope. There’s at least one homage to a famous comedy. But basically that’s it. Visually they could have done many funny things—this is a 3D computer game, after all—but basically we got nothing. What missed opportunities…..To underscore how much these devs missed the mark, consider this: early in the game there’s a place you can opt to rescue from a giant flora infestation. What the developers could have done with this was pit your Rangers against, say, killer salads, aided by giant, banana-toting bananas. But what did InExile do? ZOMBIES! They made it so the plants infected the local fauna, turning them into zombies. Jesus Cliché Christ.As for the graphics in general, it’s black, brown, green and grey. There’s some red for blood. I do like the bullets flying and the body parts falling, especially when said body parts fall because someone hit the person with a blunt object. I also like some of the lasers. And the large robots look cool. Mostly I like the fact that you can dress your group like the Three Amigos. That was fun for twelve seconds.The game also features sound.SCORE: 3/10Back of the Box Statement: “Is there too much happiness in your life?”

												For isometric RPG veterans like myself, this is a game I have been itching to play ever since the Baldur's Gate re-release reminded me why this genre can be so great. content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												A true Desert Ranger, what a journey it was to become one. Wasteland 2 has captured the essence of computer role playing games, the best indicator of which is the giddyness you'll feel when you think about doing another playthrough. It has an astounding wealth of good writing in it, so many encounters, quests and dialogues that are simply joyous to experience. The best thing is, that so many of these things can play out differently, depending on your party and your actions. A reactive world with a deeply emotive story.On your adventures through the sands, towns and cities, the game accompanies you with amazing music and visual style. The art and sounds immerse you, creating an atmosphere, that is both truly gritty in its post-apocalyptic splendor and darkly humorous with countless references and jokes. It's a world you want more of, a world you want to experience and are constantly thrilled to see what comes next.Combat is tactical and bloody, you will be able to attain all kinds of weapons, hilarious and deadly, and the death animations with the combat action descriptions make it purely Wasteland. Thoroughly enjoyable action from beginning to end. Different playstyles are well taken into account, playing with a bunch of melee bruisers or a squad of dead-shot riflemen, it's all equally satisfying. Though let's just say, that my favorite remains pummeling four raiders into red mist with a single well-placed burst from an automatic shotgun. Brutal and awesome.You will be creating characters of any variety you wish, and you will fall in love with them. The attribute system, skill system and a cool variety of cosmetic customization are a joy to tinker around with. As you play the game you will learn more about how the game progresses with the type of characters you've created, or NPCs you've recruited, and you'll be excited to try out different things next time. It's a game that keeps on giving.Do yourself a favor, if you've liked the 90's cRPGs, and play this game. It has been a long wait, but we finally got a game worthy of being up there at the top, with the best cRPG classics. Many games fail to deliver memorable moments, but this one, just like the good ones before it, has you fondly thinking back at the great things you've experienced with it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												To start, if anyone is having crashing problems on WIN 10, type -force-d3d9 into launch options on Steam. Haven't had a single crash after that.About the game, Wasteland 2 is not for everyone. Not by a long shot. It requires patience, thinking and in some cases, nerves of steel. The top-down view and turn-based combat may turn some people off. It's a hardcore RPG where your choices, starting from the very beginning at character creation, have lasting consequences throughout the game. If you're looking for an experience similar to the more recent Fallout games, you won't find it here.The character creation is intimidating at first, especially for newcomers to these types of games. There are tons of skills and you have no way to know in advance which are useful and which are more situational. I suggest consulting a character creation guide, but if you want to do everything on your own, one tip: make a team of specialists. After character creation, it's good to keep in mind these three things: Talk to EVERYONE, LOOT everything that isn't bolted down (or if it is, Brute Force can help with that ;)) and do EVERYTHING you can before moving to the next area. If you miss something, it might mean missing out on quests, companions or loot.The combat is tactical and turn-based. Director's Cut added precision strikes, which are not too useful at the beginning but can be lifesavers late in the game. It also brough some flavor to the combat system, which can be somewhat tedious at times. I found most of the quirks to be quite useless; their downsides were either too bad or they were too situational.Same goes for perks, they were a nice addition, but when selecting perks I had difficulty finding ones that were actually useful. Overall, precision strikes, quirks and perks feel somewhat like an aftertought; they're there and they're nice to have every once in a while, but they aren't really crucial to completing the game.The weapon rebalancing of DC was a welcome addition. Assault rifles and Snipers are still king, but Shotguns, for example, now actually have some use. SMG's and Handguns still suck, though.Overall, I definitely recommend this game to everyone. While it can be somewhat tedious and difficult at times, it's still a whole lot of fun. The world is huge and there's plenty to do, like blowing off the heads of raiders or solving feuds peacefully. BUT DON'T PRESS THE BUTTON AT RANGER CITADEL!

												For what it wants to be, it does everything right. It's an experience you could only get back in the day, with no handholding, no bottlenecked storytelling and no fast-travel. The combat is interesting as well, but with limited options. You can end up in situations that require changes in thinking and I like that. You will act differently when you are in a tight corridor againt snipers and shotgunners or vs Honey Badgers on a plain field.It got boring after a while, I played this game while it was free and I don't feel like buying it. The thing with this game is that you have to invest effort for the game to really shine; that means it isn't for everyone. You have to like reading a lot, and the plot took too long to develop so I have lost interest. You can read back on the log if you missed something, but you won't get an arrow pointing at the objective.The tone is very Fallout-y, as in, horrible and hilarious. the writing is good, in the dialogue and in the pop-ups that show up in the environment to set the mood.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												At 130.5 hours, I still haven't beaten this ♥♥♥♥ing game. This is the first time since New Vegas I actually pursued the side content actively and I love it! The Ranger customization really gives you a sense of connection to your team and there are some really interesting NPC characters you can interact with, some can even join you in your mission.The game itself is quite fun, holding simple, yet fun, turn-based combat combined with a well paced leveling system, a wide array of different skills your characters can spec into, and writing that you can tell had a lot of love put into it. I can tell the devs of Wasteland had a lot of fun and enjoyment with this game, returning to the roots of classic video games with their encouragment of exploration and higher difficulty. Overall, I'd say this game is worth your time. Though with any game it may take some getting used to. This is very different from the typical video game that comes out these days, retaining it's old concepts of exploration, branching paths, missions that can be failed without a game over (most of the time) and even have worse consequences than a game over, and requires you to manage who is talking with whom when you have a charisma guy in your party. It's still fun, and if it's on sale you should go for it.Also you can repair toasters to get random♥♥♥♥♥♥out of them. You can also pick up♥♥♥♥♥♥and sell it for lots of cash. 10/10

												To start I might already mention it as many before, as a person who enjoyed a lot first 2 fallout games I do enyoj this game very much. Why?1. It  has enjoyable and clear CHARACTER CREATION, you choose and make your crafted characters to fit a specific roles. If you like some theory  crafting then you will enyoj crafting your own core 4 characters, if not you can choose the presets. thought it is not as complicated as the ones in fallouts.2. Also some unclearances about field of wiev if you use high cover. The ingame GRAPHICS might not be as good as some might want them from 2014, it varies from place to place. 4. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a decent CRPG, Game is worth playing especially if you loved the old Fallout games and wish Van Buren was real. The character creation is intimidating at first, but the manual will explain things. For the most part it avoids having any single attribute as a dump stat, although charisma and luck come close. The skill system could use some work. Three dialogue skills is two too many, and a lot of non-combat skills are just various ways to open loot crates, although there are several cases where high repair or demolitions are needed to progress in a quest. Strangely, your attributes only affect your derived stats - the majority of which are sadly hidden from you - but have no effect on your skills.Combat is a huge part of this game, and while it is fun it's also rather simple. It uses a turn based system similar to Fallout, but you get control of each member of your party. There's an ambush attack similar to overwatch from XCOM which is pretty useful, but there aren't any aimed shots except for headshots, which are pretty boring. The weapons are seriously imbalanced, with assault rifles becoming really good about 1/3 of the way through, and godlike in the end-game.The quest design is decent; there are a handful of major quests in both areas of the game that are pretty complex and fulfilling to solve but the majority of them are short and combat focused. The quests in the first half are more polished while the back half feels rushed and incomplete.PROSThe game successfully incorporates tips and training pointers as you progress early on in the game. Rather than have to go through boring tutorials, you learn along the way. Absolutely loving the Ambush option available when you encounter enemies. Makes for excellent strategy and placement and forces you to consider approaches for maximum benefits as you encounter enemies later on.The Unity Engine is nice looking, with details in landscapes.The game is realistic in that you need to be prepared to take on encounters by having clear lines of fire along with readied weapons. Shooting an enemy who's in front of another friend isn't a good idea...A planned approach with players who have specific perks like lockpicking, etc are beyond valuable early on in the game.The devs have a wicked sense of humour with very colourful language all-around in the game...CONS-When you are investigating in real-time an area, I find the map option lacking. There is no map function already built into your display. You can alternate to the map by pressing 'm' but I'd rather have it as part of the overall picture itself as you move your characters around. -Some of the penalities associated with shooting are not realistic. I have one merc crouched while another one behind him is standing up firing with a rifle and he still manages to friendly fire the guy in front of him. Stupid, and the devs should have taken this into account.-Some of the shooting mechanics are way off. I have a merc with a rifile crouched who cannot take a shot at an enemy who is diagonally across from me. -The AP for rabbits is ridiculously overgenerous. They can scamper across half the screen and still carry out an attack. -The enemy AI seems to have crazy high AP...-No regional Pricing for India I need to wait for a year to buy at suitable price.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												I liked it from the beginning... it should however be noted that this game is a slow burner.Fallout 2 was one of my favs as a child, so I'll use it as a comparison despite the fact that WL2 isn't a Fallout game. I like the Wastland 2 soundtrack, though it maybe a bit avant-garde. It makes more use of ambiance, instruments that embody complex harmonics and lean arrangement, then it'll juxtapose those tunes with some driving electronic music for combat sections. FO2 had the same thing going for it music wise and even the newer Fallout games employ some very non-traditional music when the radio isn't on. I don't think there were any original pieces in the FO series that you would hear the mailman whistling. Also, if you haven't seen it, watch the movie The Stand. I think a lot of the original music from that movie, particularly the slide guitar portions, directly influence a few tracks for the Wasteland and Fallout games.Combat, if we're comparing this to older Fallout titles, is an improvement overall. It's not as much as an improvement to as say Pillars of Eternity made upon the formula of games like Baldur's Gate, but Wasteland 2 is still less clunky and requires less fuss than the FO 1 or 2. Combat can get extremely intense though. You will be confronted with situations that require tactical engagement and that might get you through threadbare. The real draw of the game for me is the story. There is a sense of intrigue from the beginning and you're there to hunt down answers. Along the way you meet some characters and the interactions feel meaningful. Also, a lot of areas of the game are chockful of macabre grim darkness and despair, which appeal to me greatly.I say give it chance. Some of the things about the game are hella sketch especially those godawful 3D character models and the optimization is poor for what the game is, but it's got a great aesthetic and the story should keep you wandering the wastes to solve the mystery.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I am only 10 hours in and I am already beyond addicted! The kickstarter guys did NOT phone this game in (unlike another kickstarter game I won't mention *cough* *Shadowrun Returns* *cough*). This is the kind of game that will make you long for a return to actual RPGs and will remind you of why you fell in love with the genre in the first place. The character generation is so in depth! You have your basic stat setup (Str, Spd, etc) but all 7 of the core attributes work beautifully together. But where the game really shines is with the plethora of skills that you can choose from. You get four "core" characters and can recruit up to three more in game. I really like the 7 member squad, I don't like it when games limit you to only 4 or 5 members. I also am really impressed with how well the designers worked in making all of the skills actually useful and not just the combat skills. There are plenty of traps, locks, safes, alarms, and more that will make it essential to have a well rounded team with all of the proper skills to effectively get the most out of every environment you visit. Additionally where many games fail when it comes to "dialouge" skills--there are three in this game--and each one offers some very nice perks. The setting is nice, but does not offer much of anything new to the whole post-apocalyptic setting found in many games today (I do concede that the original game--to my understanding--spearheaded this type of game though). But it is still a fairly well written story. Also, I admit I don't know how often this will happen in the game, I have already came across a choice that has acutal in game everlasting consequences. So that's always fun.This game can be hard and unforgiving, but in a good challenging way. So if you are a veteran of this genre of game you will not be disappointed. If you are a rookie but are tired of the cookie cutter action "RPGs" and would like to try something different, then at 30 bucks this might be the game for you. I will warn the rooks out there that there may be somewhat of a learning curve, but once you get past that you will finally see what all of the fuss from us older gamers is about.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												This game is unique.  In the parlance of our times, its 'genre' doesn't really exist anymore.  Once, there was a time in gaming when titles did not have to contain certain genre tropes in order to be easily classified and immediately accessible.  So you would do well to consider what this game is, and what it is not, and adjust your expectations accordingly.This game is fan service of the highest order.  The original Wasteland game lives and breathes inside of this one.  This is the master class on how to update a title with current technology without sacrificing the spirit of the original.  If you loved the original Wasteland, you may buy this title immediately without reservation.  It will blow your mind.  This game is for you.  They made it for you.  Praise them, and thank them for closing the loop. We have come full circle from our gaming origins, and we may now rejoice in exploding our foes like blood sausages.However, it is important to note:THIS IS NOT A TACTICAL SQUAD BASED RPG.  This is an update of a title from an era of gaming where, due to technical limitations, it was difficult to even render your party members as seperate icons.  So obviously if you are looking for compelling, deep and complex tactical turn based combat (as I often do) then there are dozens of other titles that do it better.  Its just not a priority for this game, this game is about narrative, it is from a time when narrative was king.  Comparisons to X-Com and whatnot are missing the point.Anywho.  The writing is brilliant, the world is vibrant, the nostalgia is soul shattering, the humor is mature and hilarious.  It didn't make me feel bad about myself the way Fallout did.  If narrative is your jam, you're gonna love it, the wonky camera won't hamper your enjoyment.  If you're under 30, be warned you will have to click your mouse more than you're used to.Franchise reboots are for suckers.

												I love this game as much as I love Fallout 1 and 2 (and 3 and New Vegas). Fallout 2 is still my top favourite of them all (being the first game I played in the Fallout universe), but Wasteland 2 is close!The story, the humor (both black and white), the irony, the mockery, the stark raving mad characters, the problems that can't be solved in any "good" way no matter what you do? All wonderful!Sure, there are plot holes (can't mention any without spoilers), the way active skills like lockpicking, disarming, safecracking etc work can be seriously frustrating time consumers and the UI is a bit cumbersome, but I can easily forgive that.It's the only game I've ever started a second run of immediately after completing the first, being especially fun since I could continue using the veterans from the first run. Over-powered in the second run? You bet, and I'm loving it, eventhough I raised the difficulty one step (to Ranger).Solid entertainment, lots of fun, I highly recommend it!I'm having fun hunting achievements now. :)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Let me tell you about Wasteland 2.I was out on a mission after having managed to strike a truce with a potential enemy who'd already flattened my crew more than once. The guy who tried to land the Desert Rangers in trouble with them is scared for his life because I dobbed him in as the true culprit - even after he helped me put things right, even after I said I wouldn't. He runs off to get his scaly mates all wound up and ready to make trouble.I think about it for a split second then headshot the stupid bugger. He can have his little hissyfit, but there's no way he's stuffing up this unexpected and welcome truce, Not while my sniper's rifle is loaded.Then I realise the effect this game is having on me. I'm horrified with myself. I rationalise the decision: the guy was too dumb to live; he'd have only got more innocent people killed; he was trying to covertly start fights he couldn't finish; at least if I put him down like this the other mob wouldn't torture him to death or something. I'm even more horrified at the rationalisations. I wonder if the game even has an event path for what I just did. Would his friends jump me next time because of a bug, or did he need to actually make it back to his friends to trigger that situation? Would there still be a truce when I got back? Did I really take care of the problem? The problem. Huh. That problem had a name. And friends. Possibly a family.This game is getting me to play like an amoral hardcase for the first time ever (usually I do my best to be a good guy) - and I simultaneously love it and fear it for that. Not because it's fun but because everything is a moral grey area, every success has a bit of failure in it, and it's rare for everyone to make it out alive and unscathed.10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												First off, I love this game.  I recomend it highly, it was worth my 60 dollars to play it in the early release it is definitely worth the 40 dollars it is now.   It has come a long way since the Early Access review that I did, so I am updating it now.  This game plays very much like Final Fantasy Tactics or Fallout Tactics (minus the real time option).  In it you will create 4 of your own Desert Rangers and then head out into the wastes and explore, and either clean up the wasteland or kill everyone and thing in your path.  Along the way you can recruit many extra characters to your cause, each with their own personality and traits, up to 3 may travel with you at any given time. The difficulty of the game varies sharply depending on how you choose to play it.  Early on most enemies you fight will be much weaker than you are, however you are not forced to play the game in any linear fashion and as such you may wander into areas with much stronger enemies than you are prepared to face (not that you can't win but it can be brutal).  The ability to go where you want and do what you want flows throughout the entire game.  You can sweet talk people into giving you what you want, threaten them (with the proper skills) or if that fails shoot your way through.  Wall in your way?  Use a grenade.   Person make you mad?  Shoot him, or don't.  Raiders take over a town?  Negotiate or kill them it's all up to you and how you want to play.  Most choices have concequences further down the line, some amusing and some well down right destructive, even when you think you are making the right choices nothing is ever black and white. You will collect all kinds of weapons and armor, and most weapons can be customized by stripping down others for base parts.  Everything from WW2 rifles to futuristic laser weapons are represented each with an optimal range, armor penetration and rates of fire.  In battle many of your enemies will show up with different kinds of weapons, often enough you can kill them an take it for yourself.  The various enemie types also force you to prioritize targets: Do you kill the big guy with the sword made out of the one way sign (yes, they really are swords made out of sign posts and one way signs) attacking your medic, or do you take out the guy who is still too far out to hit you but is charging with grenades that will hurt everyone?  Oh and friendly fire is a thing, don't try and use a shotgun from behind your own people. Character progression is handled in an RPG like fashion with skill points gained at every level and ability points every 10.  You can be a generalst and do a bit of everything but nothing well or you can specialize each of your characters (highly reccomend you do) into different things.I broke my basic team into:a) Sniper / Lockpicks / submachine gun - gave me nice range and something when stuff got closerb) Sniper / Perception / Kiss A** / Submachinegun - can see traps still shoot far and sweet talkc) Heavy weapons / Safe Cracking / Assault Rifle - HMG to mow down eneies - rifle to consere ammod) Energy weapon / First Aid / Rifle / demolotions - can remove traps and is the field medicThen I picked up and kept in my party ae) A drunkard shotgun specialist whom I also turned into the groups weaponsmith (because drunks make the best weapons right?)f) Lady scientist who can hack any computers and is handy with a pistol (and later rifles)g) Young kid who's life I saved,  he started with brawling and ended with rifles pistols and the ability to talk to strange animals. I built my team knowing that I would go to a specific place and pick up a particular npc.. how you create your team is entirely up to you and playing around with different builds is half the fun. - Pros -- Great turn based combat.- Easy to understand mechanics- Fun!- Lots of humor built into the game- So many different ways to resolve things in the game- Ability to break your own missions through poor choices (and sometimes good ones) requiring some creative solutions to be used to move on.- Solid strategies will win most fights.  Using cover, hitting clusters of enemies with a grenade etc.- Ammo doesn't grow on trees, making conservation of rounds part of the strategy.- All different kinds of weapons with all kinds of pros / cons built into them.- Not all weapons are a straight forward upgrade, sometimes you just have to try them out.- Each person can only carry so much weight, there is no way to be Rambo and run around with 1000's of rounds of ammo and infinite first aid kits. - Cons -- Did I really just wipe out an entire town on accident? Oops.- Random battles can be major easy or completely overwhelming.  Luck plays a part.- Bah stupid AI won't stop throwing grenades at my clustered people.- Drunk bugger keeps going rogue on my party and getting himself shot to pieces.- Some fights, more so early on can be extremely difficult to get through.  The first boss fight was really bad for me as my squad was almost dead and did not expect the guy to attack me since we were talking at first- Ammo can be hard to come by in the early game, forcing you to either use weapons your team isn't skilled for or to spend all of your money on nothing but ammo instead of armor / weapon mods / first aid kits etc.

												This game in uninspiring and tedious even given the fact that I did not complete a fraction of the side quests.  The narrative and graphics are subpar and the game is only recommended for fans, or those with a high tolerance for reading lots of text and navigating poorly programmed inventory screens.  This game reminds me of how far we've come with rpgs and how much we not take for granted in the genre.  Sometimes the good ol' days were not that good.   Really hated the fact you had to manually reload after ever fight and that you had to drag and drop weapons into the inventory of your weaponsmith to mod.  There is alot of tedious inventory management in this game and I have played Fallout 1,2,3,NV.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Not great, but easily good enough.Wasteland 2 is a throwback to older RPGs with the text-heavy story and the turn based combat. Look, it's easy to pick holes in the game - it was launched with quite a few broken quests, the weapon balance isn't good, the combat options could be more plentiful - stuff like that. Perhaps the main storyline isn't that compelling for some folks though it was fine for me.In short there are a lot of things it could have done better. It's certainly not perfect. But I enjoyed it enough.There's 50 hours of gameplay here and most of it is old-school RPG fun. Questing, combat and exploration are all central parts of this game and they're all done well enough that the overall experience is great. I quite liked the world and the atmosphere and that kept me going during some of the duller times. In addition, the devs have done a great job of updating and patching the game. I went to play it again with the newer version and made it about halfway through before quitting. So in my book it's not a great game but it was enjoyable enough to feel like I got my money's worth. So if you're looking for some old-school RPG fun, buy this title. It may not be the GOTY, but odds are you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Wasteland 1 was out before my time.  I grew up on Fallout 1 and 2.  If you are a fan of classic Fallout, you'll feel right at home in Wasteland 2.Character customization is very robust.  Even with a crew of 4 personalized rangers, it is hard to build a 100% comprehensive team.  The creative freedom is welcome even if I did restart my first few playthroughs because some of my rangers did not perform as well as I expected.  Without experience or research, you're likely to build sub-optimal team members.Wasteland really shines when it comes to content.  The world has plenty of subquests and diversions to discover.  The larger quests offer numerous interconnected choices with the potential for wildly varying conclusions and rewards.  The complexity of the quest design did introduce some glitches and inconsistencies during my play throughs.  Every now and then an NPC would incorrectly acknowledge a decision I did or did not actually make earlier in my game, but it was never game breaking.The combat will feel familiar if you've played XCOM.  The RPG aspects of combat work well.  Weapons are quite diverse even within single categories and deciding which one to use rarely boils down to a single stat.  Healing takes a significant turn investment.  Friendly fire is a consideration when shooting past teammates.  Penalties are applied to your hit rate depending on range and your choice of weapon.  Weapons and ammo get progressively heavier and inventory management becomes progressively more important.  There is surprising variety in enemy archetypes.  All these factors add up to a thoughtful combat system, but it is not without its flaws.  The worst of Wasteland 2's combat can be attrbuted to poor level design.  Combat operates on a grid, but the levels are often built without this in mind.  A diagonal wall is suddenly a much bigger obstacle than it first seemed.  The game does have a cover system that comes highly encouraged, but there are no clear visual rules for what you can and can't use for cover.  Environmental interactivity was supposed to be a big deal and was emphasized during gameplay trailers.  There are destructable crates peppered in most combat scenarios, but that's largely the extent of the dynamic environments.  I don't remember seeing an explosive barrel/pod beyond the first mission.Overall, Wasteland 2 is a faithful modernization of its source material and there's plenty here to keep you coming back long after the credits roll.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
Product received for free
												I will be getting this game primarily to encourage the free previewing of games like this and thus further increasing their accessibility. Every once in a while you get tired of being treated to fancy schmancy cinematic spectacles and just want to relax with a nice trip through a fantasy world where you have freedom over how your adventure unfolds. You enter an abandoned building and find out that the interior power generators aren't working? No problem, you have a guy for that. You stumble across some nasty wasteland creatures? No problem, you can create a tough guy to fend them off and better increase your party's chance of survival.The trick with these types of computer games is, even if they seem shocking at first glance with all the menus and text; do not overthink things while you're playing. Get lost in the world, don't be afraid to be a little creative, and have fun!

												This game demands patience, managemant, and strategy.  This is something most people who are giving this game bad reviews don't seem to understand. While it can be time consuming to learn how to balance out your squad properly and do managemant, especially coming from a guy who didnt grow up in the Fallout 1-2 era, the reward is satisfactory.  For those who got into video games in early 2000s, this is simply later Fallout with more stats and strategy.  Get this game while its on sale.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												TL;DR- This game is amazing as far as RPGs go. The tactical combat is challenging and rewarding. The storyline is solid and  cohesive. As someone who didn't play the original before I got it along with this game I feel that the devs did a great job at staying true to the original while making a wholly playable and engrossing sequel, paying homage to the players of the 1st game while not entirely alienating their new market. Simply one of the best role-playing games I have had the pleasure to play in the last decade.Wasteland 2 made me feel like I was playing Fallout-Advanced Edition. Yes the post apocalyptic genre may be reaching its saturation point, but to pull it off with the style and flair that the devs did with this game is truly a feat that others should feel beholden to match in the future. Back in my day *takes a slug off of a clay jug marked XXX* players used their imaginations to fill in the holes that graphic and framerate left empty and Wasteland 2 managed to bridge that gap with nuance and gusto. I felt for my characters. I lovingly crafted their skills to conquor all that the wasteland had to throw at me. I was treated to inside jokes, 80's humor, and a difficulty that suited my playstyle (played on hard difficulty). If you're looking for a great tactical RPG, this is a sure bet. If you're looking for a storyline that will keep you playing to the end, start clicking the buy button now. Dim the lights. Crank the speakers. And sit down for a while and witness true RPG entertainment at it's best.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I can't in good conscious recommend Wasteland 2 as a finished product. It's too lackluster and has a few major issues. It plays fine, and I will probably continue playing it even after I write this, but there's two main issues at the time of writing.The first being off is the god for saken prison. Ran by raiders with no redeemable factors that turn people into slaves only be disguising them as workers. They do nothing good, everyone that you come across will say you can be the savior, march right up to the leader, and kill him, simple task, right?Apparently not, once you get there you run into a plotwall. Two turrets at 4K health each(To put that in perspective, 20ish hours in my characters only have 125ish health). Okay, fine, just bring out heavy weapons. Wrong again, they have a stupid high intiative, and a stupid high amount of action points. They fired 5ish times each, doing 300 damage per bullet. Good luck getting your party through that.Even if you *DO* manage to kill the turrets, there's apparently accounts of impossible-to-defuse landmines that 1 hit kill party members.Why is this happening? I'm not sure, but if I had to guess, one of the team members working on wasteland felt so proud of their plot twist they decided to make sure everyone can only expirence the plot twist like that. So you just have to go 'welp, i know these guys beat and enslave you, but hes's got deus ex machina backing him so we can't do anything till the game says so'The other issue is just hour 10ish. It becomes out-of-ammo gun-jam simulator. You won't have enough ammo to get into skrims, or if you do, you'll be cutting it close and it'll just be fustrating. Then when you do have ammo, your gun jams. A lot. I'm not sure how complex a double barrel shotgun is, but i'm pretty sure it's not prone to the amount of jamming it got.Now for the nitpicky stuff. Somethings just outpace your levels, but that's fine, maybe I shouldn't be rushing through the content as fast as I was. Another issue is just not being able to interact with the world. There's a girl who's (perpetually) dying, constantly groaning into your radio, asking for some one named Elroy. You can find her, confront her. But even if you're the best doc of the entire world, you can't help her, only shoot her. It may sound super nit picky, but not even given the illusion of choice sucks. I couldn't try, I could only mercy kill.There is good htngs, the game is close to being a perfect masterpiece. Combat is actually alright, atleast mid game. Things start getting faster, combat is quick but a bit tactical. It could benefit from a few small tweaks. Flanking, some more cover options, and a change to friendly fire calculations(Not as bad as fallout 2. Damn it Sulik, give me that gun.) The characters are alright, followers feel human as they comment on the scenery and situation where applicable, instead of being a silent moving turret. They have their flaws, they have their benefit, but not so much so they become a god send or dead weight.Over all the game feels... unpolished. It feels as if I'm playing in a beta, which I'm not. If it gets changed, or the mod tools get released, I'm sure this game could be something fantastic. But at the moment it's simply okay.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Wanted to love this game. After many, many, restarts and partial playthroughs I just ended up calling it quits. Played FO1 and 2, and Tactics when they were first released and they sit high on my list of "fond of old games." This, I did not care for at all. Enemies zerg you (that's the extent of the AI). In FO Tactics they at least had the sense to flank you, take cover, hide, runaway, switch weapons appropriately, etc. You'd think that would be something we'd see in the 21st century. Not here. They run at you or shoot, then you shoot back, repeat. The stat system is broken (not using that word as a euphamism or perjorative, there are stats that matter and those that don't. And your stats don't effect your skills at all beyond intelligence).  There are only a few viable builds to complete the game. The skills are so convoluted and could have been easily reduced by half. For instance you have: Alarm Disarming, Lockpicking, and Safe Cracking. Is there any reason these couldn't be under one skill instead of three? No. Then you have: Hard A*s, Kiss A*s, Smart A*s, Barter, and Leadership, aren't these all subsets of a larger skill like persuasion/speech or based on charisma? Well, no, not in Wasteland 2. Why are they convoluted? Probably to compensate for a game design that allows for so few actions in game beyond "kill person in this manner" or "successfully interact with this object for a reward." Weapons and armor have arbitrary penalties that exist only to impose penalties. For instance, did you know that an "assault rifle" loses all efficiency at five feet and  a board with a nail in it works MUCH better? I didn't know that, but after playing WL2 I do. Further energy weapons do lots of damage to you if they hit your armor, but if they hit your bare skin they don't do much on any damage at all. Logic! It's the guise of strategy, not actual strategy. It's strategic like rock, papers, scissors. This game has a lot of heart. It tries very hard an certainly has charm. Yet I've played browser based games with more depth, complexity, strategy, and sophistication. Really wanted something to take me back to those first days playing FO1/2 and Tactics. Instead it's better to just play those instead of WL2. Or, if you really want a strategy based around functional abilities, gear (that you build or collect), multiple means of achieving you goal, and competent AI go play XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within.I want my money back.

								May 1st 201459 hours on record, not 24.I've been playing Wasteland 2 for a while now and figured I should write a review. I hardly ever write reviews but I feel that this game deserves it. When i first bought it (a week or two after release) the game was buggy to say the least. A bit boring during combat and the story was dry......then the patches started rolling out. The game became beautifully designed. The artwork is amazing, the combat feels solid and easy to use. The story feels like a true rpg. Still being in Beta and being apart of the process has been amazing. I have enjoyed every patch and have no complaints. I can wait to see what it's like once it's fully released. If you have any doubts about not liking this game wait until full release, but if you want to buy it now and help the dev's create a game more to your liking this is the company to do it with. content:
Posted: February 24
												Not as good as Wasteland 1 and not the spiritual Fallout 3 that many Fallout fans wanted, but it's a good role-playing game. In hindsight, as backers, we shouldn't have expected inXile to deliver an amazing game; inXile hadn't developed an RPG since the Interplay days more than a decade ago.inXile learned a lot developing this game though. Signs of ambition are all over the game, with tons of reactivity from the start. But as the game progresses, you notice that many things seem to scale back in quality. There is less reactivity, and eventually the random radio chatter stops. This is more noticeable in California with the ranger HQ and the big cities. Santa Fe Springs has a relatively large map but it's never used. Hollywood in particular promises greatness if only inXile had more money and thus time. Quests can be tackled largely out of order with plenty of dialogue options to form alliances fake or real, but it's ruined by bugs or even perceived bugginess. It's definitely rough.We already know Wasteland 3 will not try to be a 100 hour game, and is instead aiming for something along the lines of Torment: Tides of Numenera which is supposedly around 40 or 50 hours. Considering the original Fallouts and Wasteland were only around 20 hours each and how unpolished the later areas of Wasteland 2 were, I think this is a good idea.
