number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								When I played the beta of this game in 2013, I was not impressed. I was frustrated with the UI, the art direction, the scripting, and the way combat was weighed. I played the original in the late 1980s, and loved the surreal and unforgiving world it created.I came back, this month, hoping that the issues I'd complained about had been fixed. I genuinely love this series and was pessimistic about its survival. I owe the devs an apology--the beta I've played this month has been everything I could have wanted (though I could always use more toasters and mutants, if anyone is listening).I can recommend this game to fans of the first game, as well as fans of dystopian and apocalyptic games. However, it is distinct from other entries in this genre, including the often-cited Fallout series. Closer to the roots of such games than the more recent entries in the apolcalyptic genre, Wasteland 2 is tactical and played from above your party's head. You can pause between turns, and sometimes you'd better think about it first.It also has the charm of being more appropriately unforgiving--it's the !@#(*% apocalypse, the stakes are high, and I APPROVE of punishing button mashing and careless playing.Know your save file, love your save file. The game saves less often than you might want it to, so you'll want to stay on that yourself.Your characters will have to specialize, and no single character will be able to be everything. You will want to think hard about how you want to allocate specialties. It is very possible to make in-game mistakes that kill you and your party instantly, though you'd have to be pretty oblivious to make them. If the button says "do not push me," do no--actually, if you push it, you deserve what you get. The wrong comment to the wrong person can touch off wars between groups, closing whole story sections to you. The appropriate choice in dialog is not always obvious, and the best choice is not always available to you, without specializing.Depending on your level of difficulty, making use of the ability to create ambushes and lead people into them will become very useful, as is developing a character able to scout ahead.The game is still being developed, and has some on-going and minor technical issues, including an optimization problem I ran into on my rig that required me to turn down the refresh rate and render quality considerably. From reading the forums, this problem is not exactly common, but happens often enough to merit mention.The half of the game available for play right now also seems a bit short--I'm hoping that the final product will be much longer (gimmie!)It's hard to evaluate a story when you're missing the denouemont, but to this point, it has a familiar and interesting arc. Given the development, I'm fairly confident the finished product, based on the skill I've seen, will have been worth backing the project.A word of advice: do not buy this game expecting Fallout: New Vegas, or expecting a completely open, huge world filled with 1950s kitsch, naivete, and classic sci-fi allusions. Expect, instead, a world hemmed in on all sides by radiation and death, with the disaffection, paramiliatry themes, and violence of the 1980s. The devs have done a particularly good job of recalling the first game without simply recreating it.And devs, at the risk of spoiling something, the Brothers patrolling the mountain pass are just about perfect. If there's any fear close to our current, collective hearts, it's contamination.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												I’ve only played the Original Wasteland game very briefly a long time ago, however I’ve spent countless hours playing the pre-Fallout 3 Fallout games on PC which were inspired by Wasteland. Now I’ve played Wasteland 2 for around 7 hours, it’s not a fast paced game, this has only been enough time for me to complete one of the first main missions.- Overall I was very happy with the game, personally it was awesome to see a modern Fallout-like game with a traditional isometric view and detailed text descriptions of everything seen and done in the world.- However I found that I spent way too much time having to loot one loot container after another as well as sometimes fighting identical enemies repeatedly.


YouTube™ Video: Wasteland 2: Gameplay First Look (Beta) 

			Views: 1,626		

			First Look Wasteland 2 video showcasing PC Gameplay. Wasteland 2 reviews, impressions, tips and features to get you started. Thank you for watching, like, comment and subscribe if you enjoyed!		




YouTube™ Video: SatanovichZ1 Wasteland 2 gameplay 

			Views: 11		

			This game is Wasteland 2 by in InXile Entertainment. Enjoy. Read my steam review here - http://steamcommunity.com/id/SatanovichZ1/recommended/240760 Support new Gaming YouTubers -...		

In the character creation the graphics aren’t very appealing. However when you actually play the game you don’t usually view things so closely.-----Generally the actual graphics looked good in my opinion. But personally I’m satisfied as long as it’s a competent modern three-dimensional adaptation of Wasteland and an adequate improvement compared to the two-dimensional Fallout titles.-----What I was really impressed by was actually the textual description of entities and objects in the game. They provided more interesting details about everything you see.-----I also really liked the text dialogue that my companion expressed during combat rather than being mute. It really made the character seem more alive.-----Most of the character models looked fine, especially humans who featured a lot of variety. But I really got tired of seeing the same unimpressive giant bunnies again and again.-----There were also a couple of locations which I was not impressed by. One area was just a big empty square. While another fenced you into lanes which I don’t think fit well into a world that I believe should feel very open.-----But I was really impressed by many of the other environments that I saw. I liked how you could rotate the view, this would reveal objects you couldn’t see previously.-----Many environments looked handcrafted and irregularly shaped. I think this platform has a lot of potential even for other games with a fantasy theme.I liked the character attributes and skill system. However the benefits of investing into some attributes didn’t seem worthwhile. Likewise investing in combat skills seemed to suffer from strong diminishing returns.-----I set out to play this game in an unusual way. I didn’t want to micromanage a squad. So initially I took only one ranger. This didn’t work out so well initially.-----So after playing for an hour I started over and I redesigned my starting character. This time I created a more intelligent character so that they could multi-skill and thus take on multiple roles.-----Early on there is a high level character who you can recruit named ‘Angela Deth’, I took her along with me because going solo with a low level character is actually very difficult. So the game almost let me play the way I wanted to because I didn’t have to take a whole squad.-----I don’t mind the turn based combat, but it’s one of the reasons the game is slow paced. I knows it’s more traditional. But I would have preferred a real time system where you could pause and redirect the action.-----Occasionally my companion would go out of control in combat and make actions without me directing her. How do I make her do this all the time? I’d rather my NPC teammates were more autonomous. I don’t want to have to tell them to do every little thing.-----Outside of combat for the first several hours that I played, I couldn’t move my characters individually for some reason. So I wasn’t able to rearrange my character before entering combat-----This was a bit weird. I don’t know why this happened but eventually I was suddenly able to direct them individually.-----In games like this I feel compelled to search every nook and cranny in a level for loot. Especially because you really need to do so in order to scrape up enough ammunition to fight and enough medical supplies to survive.-----I know it’s a post apocalyptic game and scavenging may be the ‘thing’ to do. But I think I easily spent half of my seven hours of game-play looting and managing my characters’ inventories. That was tedious.-----Why do I have to ransack the property of people who I am supposed to protect? How do my characters carry all those guns and where do they keep them, just to sell at a vendor?-----I wish there was a better system for acquiring better gear. Perhaps credit towards an interchangeable load-out based on each characters rank and experience levels?So yes, I definitely have my gripes about this game. But I was very happy to play it. This game proves that Fallout 3 didn’t have to make the shift to FPS. Not sure that I will have more time for Wasteland 2 though.-----I’m happy that the price has come down. The previous $60 price tag was a major reason that I had not purchased this game quite some time ago.Click here for my YouTube gaming channel

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												While it's worth the 25+ year wait for it, it's not without its flaws. If you are reading this then I'm certain you've read at least a couple of the other player reviews of this game, if not official reviews from IGN, PC Gamer & the like.  Many of the reviews equate this game as being a "tactical RPG",  I would classify it more as an RPG with some (note emphasis) tactical elements, there's a difference.  Like in the "golden age" of PC RPGs, you create your inital squad members, you can recruit up to 3 others, making a total of 7.  There are quite a few NPCs to recruit also, each has their own reasons for being on your team.  Depending on your actions it can be quite temporary how long a potential recruit stays on your team.  How you mix & match your PCs & NPCs can be quite interesting. Like the PC based RPGs of yesteryear, once a character dies, they're gone forever, so save often.  The game does not hold your hands on things, some of the clues in certain quests are down right obtuse & depending on the difficulty you set it at certain other things... well you'll see for yourself.  Is the game "pretty", nope.  Is the story something I've not seen before, nope on that also.  But this games does give me something I see too little of in RPGs these days: choice & consequence.  Most of the consequences based on the choices are also not readily apparent, they have a small ripple effect that may not be seen for hours down the road; are you seriously about to reload a save from 2 or 4 or more hours ago when the consequence of such a decision is happening so far down the line?  I seriously doubt that, which is another thing I like, you have to think on most of the choices here; "How will doing X bite me in the rear?" is something you should really consider.  I did one playthrough, it took me 120 hours to finish, I had a blast in exploring & finding things.  I intend on another.  Just 'cause I liked it though & felt it a fitting sequal to the original, it doesn't mean that I'm blind to the weaknesses of the game.  In most cases I hope what I wrote n the weakness column is considered & fixed for Wasteland 3, should the franchise continue.SrengthsChoice & ConsequenceBig & long game reminiscent of the games of yesteryear.  Does not hold your hand, it's a thinking persons game.  Either have a decent memory on certain quests or use the notes system provided, you'll be glad you did.  Dark humor a-la the original Interplay Fallouts, but more subtle.  WeaknessesUI not as tweakable as I'd likeThe character customization could be way better. While I didn't expect it to be anywhere near as pretty as Divinity Original Sin, I did want my characters to look somewhat like the pics I imported to represent them.  A lot of the portraits & random areas were reused.  The battles also felt repetative after awhile, the latter being the fault of a really bare-bones tactical aspect (no called shots on body parts other then the head, no sneak skill).  I would've liked a few more optional quest areas like the Mine & Rail Nomads. Some areas were really big, I would've liked a waypoint option.  For better & worse most of the Skills didn't relate to the statistics of the characters.  At least to me they didn't feel this way.  HaasGaming wrote it best:  "If you are patient and give Wasteland 2 the time it needs to show its potential, it will be a tremendously enjoyable experience. Time definitely worth investing."

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												I looked forward to this game for a long time, and will admit that once I got it did not fall in love with it and so have put very limited time into it, so take my game experience with that grain of salt.  Many people have clearly loved it, and so maybe you will too, but I feel let down and consider this a title that for me has lived up neither to its hype or even to its promises.Clearly a lot of care and attention to detail went into crafting this game, as well as a long process of interacting with the community during development, and I am impressed with the features.  That they did not add up to a fun and immersive experience for me may have been primarily due to a dislike for the camera handling.  I found early on that I preferred a wide view most of the time, but the camera handles poorly for that.I also believe that the bar was set reasonably high for visual quality, but again I feel like the look achieved was not equal to the sum of the components, and possibly that has to do with the Unity engine.I have generally good feelings that Fargo's team was revived by this project and has leveraged the enthusiasm for this revival to  continue on with new projects as well as encouraging other developers doing interesting projects, but otherwise am not too excited to have been a day 1 kickstart supporter.Some 32 months after the project was officially funded we have not seen the mod tools kit that was promised.  I realize that Fargo was honest in projecting that mod tools would require further time and it will probably come someday, but at this stage of the game's shelf life I'm about ready to declare that a broken promise.  This may seem like a moot point since I haven't cared much for the game, but it is disappointing nonetheless.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												So, if you take the term 'CRPG' really seriously and enjoy getting in fights about how modern RPGs aren't 'real' RPGs, and you wish it were still the late 1990s, this is a great game for you and you don't need to read the rest of my review.On the other hand, if you enjoy isometric party-based RPGs but also might like to see some progress from the last 15 years or so of gaming history, Wasteland 2 is kind of a letdown precisely because of how stubbornly it emulates the UI fiddliness of Fallout 1/2.  Get ready to remember which party member owns a shovel, switch to them, activate the shovel item, and wait while a progress bar fills up, every time you want to dig something up.  And this isn't just shovels, it's *every specialized skill*.  You're not realistically going to put together a party with more than one girl or guy who knows Safecracking or some other random♥♥♥♥♥♥ but the game will never let you just click on the safe and have the one Safecracker open it.The maps suffer from a similar level of fiddliness.  You will have to memorize where in town that random questgiver is, or come back from a fetch quest to wander all over wondering where his shop is among a town of identical-looking dwellings.  No quest markers is fine, I don't think that the player should have telepathic knowledge of where stuff is ahead of time, but when you're looking to turn in quests (and the characters would already know where shopkeeper X is) it's just a hassle.  Isometric design also means that the level designers hide crates in places where you need to rotate the camera to find them ... which is fine, but after a while, it's not clever, it's just irritating to have to rotate the camera every time you enter a new room or potentially miss out on loot.I could go on with examples of the weird sort of micromanagement that Wasteland 2 requires of the player (there are many more), but you get the point.Bottom line, it feels like a game that came out in 2000, not 2014.  If you're fine with this, go ahead and get it (but you probably already did).  If you're not, and especially if you haven't played Fallout 1/2 to death, there's really no reason to play this instead of Fallout 1/2.

								After half-hour playing with the character creation and then a good solid 90 minutes of play I am impressed with the game so far and am very much enthusiastic about seeing the end product. The gameplay is very similar to Fallout Tactics and the Jagged Alliance games, which I reckon suit it immensely, and they have retained the feel of the original Wasteland with the grim tones and occasional quirky humor (gotta love using the Smart A$$ skill to befuddle a bunch of raiders in a certain set encounter which allowed me to pass by and set up an ambush ^_^) so that is scoring top marks with me.The only downsides so far are the occasional bugs (for one, doing alt-tab to chat with a friend who asked how the game was resulted in a crash - ironic!) which one can easily forgive given that it's still in Beta; plenty of time to chase up those issues.So in the end I'm giving it 8.5/10 and highly expectant of giving top marks for the final release.Now time for me to dive back in and get to saving what's left of Arizona; it's a dirty job, but someone's gotta do it...

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												RELEASE VERSION UPDATE: Initial beta/backers review found after.This is it. This is the big one. For many people, this is one of the most anticipated games of the year - the great inspiration for Fallout, the driver of classic RPGs, the callback to a genre slowly reviving. One of the first big huge Kickstarted games. After two years in development, how does it hold up? Spoilers: it holds up damn well.Wasteland 2 is a classic RPG in the style of Fallout 1, 2, and Tactics. In fact, the original Wasteland was the inspiration for the Fallout universe, and shares many similarities and concepts with Wasteland. You take control of four fresh-faced Ranger recruits, sent out on a task to make yourselves worthy of your badges. What ends up happening is a journey across Arizona, and then some.The game starts off with character creation. You can choose to create your own Ranger from scratch, or pick a pre-made Ranger from a list. The pre-made characters are alright, but for most people, you'll want to make your own customized Rangers. You can distribute attribute and skillpoints as you see fit, change your Ranger's physical appearance, and even stick in his/her own little bio and a custom portrait.After setting yourself up, you end up in the Arizona wasteland, right outside Ranger Citadel. You are greeted by General Vargas, a veteran Ranger and an old character from Wasteland.  Another Ranger vet, Ace, has just died in action, and you and your team are sent out to investigate his murder and finish his mission as a trial. Succeed, and you all become official Rangers.At first glance, one can immediately note the biggest downside to the game - graphical fidelity. While I personally feel that the graphics do not detract from the game, and in fact works to further the atmosphere it sets about creating, it is easy to see that the game is not about the shinies. Its easily trumped by Divinity: Original Sin in terms of fidelity, but that is not to say the game looks bad. It is simply objectively dated, even for a Unity-based game. Performance also leaves something to be desired - on a GTX 765M, the game hovers at about 40-50fps, sometimes dipping below to 30. Whilst expected for a new release, it certainly does not look like it should be choking up a moderately good mobile GPU as far as it is.  However, the graphical style the game takes is very immersive - you have varying environs, from lush greens to barren browns, and everything in between. The wasteland feels desolate and real.Wasteland 2 is set in an isometric, top-down view. You control your Rangers overhead, order them around by clicking in the world. There are two world types - the main world, showing you Arizona and the rest of the area, where you go around between smaller local maps, looking for oases for water, and avoiding rad clouds, then the local maps, which is where you explore, do missions, talk to people, shoot people, all that good stuff. Combat is turn based, engaging when you run into hostiles or turn other people hostile by shooting at them/having a negative interaction. Characters take turns in commiting actions, with each action costing certain Action Points to do. Your characters can use a slew of weapons, from going in fisticuffs, to heavy armanents such as bazookas and heavy MGs, all of which can be skilled up. Positioning is key, with certain weapons being effective at certain ranges, and cover helping you avoid damage. Damaged Rangers can only be healed up with medkits, pain pills, and trauma kits if they bleed out. There is no idle healing, which means every fight has to be planned, and you have to have enough supplies to last.Overall, I feel that Wasteland 2 offers a refreshing jump back into cRPGs, bringing the spirit of post-apocalyptic games from the past well into the 21st century. If you love turn based games, old RPGs, post-apocalypse settings, then you'll love (or absolutely hate - in a good way!) Wasteland 2. Give it a try._________________________________________________________________________________Wasteland 2: One of the first gigantic projects on Kickstarter, the revival of an era, the granddaddy of Fallout, the great leap back for inXile.Is it any good (so far?) The short answer:  yes, yes it is.Wasteland 2 is one of the biggest, most high profile projects funded through Kickstarter – indeed, funding for the game came after Double Fine Adventure’s own successful Kickstarter. The game raised roughly 3,000,000USD, well exceeding its goal of 900,000USD.The game follows up on Wasteland, which was the basis for many elements in the Fallout series. Many elements seen in Fallout can be seen here – radioactive wasteland, Rangers building up a civilized society, raiders, tech-fanatics, militant religious fanatics are all present in the game, clearly showing how much it influenced other games later on.Gameplay is very much Fallout like as well. You explore the world with your party, with the world map being just that – a map that you navigate your party blimp through. Movement is dependent upon your water supply – you lose water, you die. Thankfully, there are hidden oases all over the map, giving enough opportunities to refill water to quench one’s wanderlust. In local areas, one goes about with the whole party, with your selected member doing the interactions. Conversations follow a keyword system – anything you observe in the environment might pop up as a keyword for characters in the locale, while some words in conversations can lead to further inquiries as well. Some conversation options require certain skills to be at a certain level, and can lead to clearing certain obstacles in a peaceful manner. Combat is turn based, following an AP system similar to, again, Fallout. On this, I cannot say much – I’ve only played less than two hours, and so far, the early mobs were easy enough to wipe without having to worry about cover and positioning. Even then, I did take a noteable amount of damage, and would probably lose my party members if I continued to do so.Wasteland 2 runs on Unity – so far, in this current beta build, there are no graphical options to speak of, besides resolution and an overall graphics preset. Setting it to Fantastic with an i7-4700MQ and GTX 765M, the game looks fantastic – it pushes Unity to the edge. However, this being a beta, performance is not spectacular – fully zoomed out, FRAPS was showing around 24fps to a max of 30fps, which is barely passable. Dropping presets down to standard did not help performance, so I am assuming this is a “beta is beta” issue, and will be patched before the actual launch.Is Wasteland 2 worth your time right now for 60USD? I would say, yes – if you can get past the beta-ness of it (you’ll have to download and print the reference sheet as there isn’t much of a tutorial in game), it is a good sign of the return of cRPGs and TBS games with rich narrative and an open approach to quests. While it wouldn’t hurt to wait, if you’ve been on the fence on it and can’t wait, it’s a solid game beta.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Product received for free
												First of all I did not play the original Wasteland. But when I heard that Brian Fargo, who is responsible for the best games in the world (Fallout 1 and Fallout 2), wants to make a Wasteland 2 I was immediately interested. I bought Wasteland 2 but it waited a long time before I found the time to play and in the meantime a Director's Cut edition was published, which I received for free.This game is not Fallout. But it is an awesome game nonetheless. It combines the RPG with tactics game (with more tactics element that RPG) but in a better way that Fallout Tactics did it. The game is hard. The combat is challenging and you always have less point in the skill that you need to use right now.The plot is good with some nice plot twist at the end of the game. I was surprised as it all turned out. I enjoyed the grim future of the post-nuclear wasteland. People are struggling to maintain a decent life and you cannot help everybody. Sometimes you must choose who will live and who dies. And there are a lot of mad inhabitants (just as in Mad Max series and Fallout series you could tell that something in the radiations affects the brain cells). As I love a post-nuclear setting this was one of the best example of this unfriendly world.The graphic could be better but for me it is not a major issue in a game like this. But it is done in a way to emphasis the dark world you are playing and that was done great. Personally I think that there could be more portraits. The sounds and voice acting are satisfying. Adrian Gordon wins the award for the best performance, he was outstanding. Just listen to his 'RAIN JERKS?!'. And last but not least the music. For me it was excellent. It caught the climate of the game perfectly. And I recommend to listen to the 'Cries of a Dead World' by Miracle of Sound (it is in the credits).It is not the best game in the world but I rate it 9/10. Play it. Play it now!

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												A truly disappointing experience..It boggles the mind, how the developers managed to secure triple the budget of Divinity Original Sin yet come up with such an unpolished mess of a game. I am a huge fan of Fallout 1 and Fallout 2, and this game fails to deliver on every single factor of what made Fallout 1 and 2 such instant classics. Character skills are only there to give the illusion of variety, when really a locked chest will yield the same or sometimes WORST loot when compared to an unlocked one.Combat strategy is extremely straight forward, there are no skills whatsoever, all characters just shoot. Cover is very buggy, an obvious stone slab that seems to provide cover may actually not provide any benefits whatsoever(you have to go into combat to find out what actually IS cover)Storyline is linear as well, giving the illusion of an open world but will only allow more exploration once a criteria has been met.Quests MUST be done in a certain order or you will fail..  The *hard* choices that the developers promise seemed forced. There isnt a single hard choice that feels as though the options are justified, the game always makes you feel like you are just as dumb as the characters involved when better options are clearly out there.A very unpolished experience overall and a major disappointment, my search for a true fallout sequel continues...

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Colossally overrated. -Most skills are just keys to open up different kinds of boxes-The game is a tunnel with only one way forward. You need all the skills to open all the boxes along the way, and that's it.-Sometimes, but not often enough to matter much, the tunnel branches for a moment before it merges again.-Characters are simplified and have personalities as thin as cardboard. You'll find more character depth in most FPS titles than this.-The animations are unfinished and lazy.-Combat looks and feels as real and visceral as your average MMO title.-There's a lot of dialogue, but very little of it is meaningful in any way. You just click through it all and move forward in the tunnel.-In fallout 2, playing a character with vastly differing stats changed the entire game experience and modified the plot. Here it changes your action point amounts and HP.In short: This is not the worst game out there, but if you want to play your next fallout 2, keep waiting. It isn't here.

Early Access Review
								When i first took a look at wasteland 2 i was suprised because i never thought Inxile was going to make a brand new sequel to wasteland 1 which was one of the best strategy based post apocalyptic rpgs of all time. It was 44 euros, but i thought "why the hell not" and bought it. When i first started playing i was shocked, there was so much frame drop and the game crashed when i attempted to exit the primary area of the game, i was very dissapointed BUT WAIT. I heard from the support of the game that there was an upcoming update that was going solve all the crashing issues and many more things. A week passed by and the update had finally been released, it had fixed 2,000 issues, such as bugs, glitches, and even added new structures and maps.I started up the game and i was blown away, there was no lag at all and the graphics where stunning. They had even added a store to the primary area, i exited the place and there was no crash, "that is what im talking about" and so the game went on with no bugs or lag. This goes to show how dedicated the wasteland 2 team is to assist their fan base in their problems. Im usualy not into giving a rating, but as i once said "why the hell not !"8/10,thanks for your guys attention.

												Wasteland 2 is... interesting. Built on a flimsy engine with stilted voice acting more common in games almost twenty years ago, Fallout this is not. It's not bad, per se, but it's not good. It's a game you pick up in the bargin bin, or during a Steam Summer Sale and enjoy it, beat it and never play it again.After about two hours the lack of atmosphere, debatable story and uninspired psuedo western apocalyptic setting (snoresville) I uninstalled. Not because it was bad, but because I have a LOT better games to go play.Good if you don't have anything else. Otherwise? Just pick up A Fallout entry. They have more soul, humor, darkness and cohesion as a whole. Chris Avellone is infamous for his hokey, stilted writing and this game is no exception.Save it for a rainy day.

number of helpful: 17 of 33 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This is an adequate game. When I had a lot of free time, I didn't mind investing a few tens of hours to appreciate W2's strong points. Now that I have less time for gaming, there are enough better games that I won't play Wasteland 2 again (although I'll probably reinstall to look at the Game of the Year version).In this review, I'll compare it to X-COM: Enemy Unknown and Skyrim, which seem like natural comparisons for different aspects of Wasteland 2. (I assume Fallout 3 is a more natural comparison, but I never played it.)Good partsWeaponsmithing: Interesting and fun. Deeper than the smithing system in Skyrim but easier to understand.Roaming freely: Exploring in W2 isn't as rewarding as Skyrim, but the hybrid turn-based system combined with exploring makes Wasteland 2 feel, if not bigger, at least freer than X-COM: EU.NPCs: Several but not all NPCs are well-written. NPC interactions add something that wasn't in X-COM: EU, but they're not at the level of Skyrim.Bad partsLack of tension in combat: X-COM: EU's well-designed maps and the soldiers' vurnerability made combat a taut, exciting chess match. In Wasteland 2, the lack of cover, friendly fire (by itself a great addition), and soldiers durability (on seasoned difficulty), made combat an exercise in lining up American Revolution-style and rolling your dice against the enemy. On seasoned difficulty, my soldiers never went down except to friendly fire. Ranger difficulty made combat more difficult, but the outcome of combat never felt like the result of skill or strategy.Mediocre writing: For me, the writing was good enough to made up for the uninteresting combat through the end of the Arizona section. The Rail Nomad camp and Happy Valley set up interesting scenarios. However, the narrative lost momentum after the start of the California section. When the game essentially copy-pasted the Rail Nomad scenario for another level, I lost interest.Skills: More than half of the skills feel like they were added to pad the game and provide a sink for skill points. For example, Skyrim had one skill for picking locks. Wasteland 2 has 5 or 6 skills that serve exactly the same function. What's the difference between lock picking, toaster repair, and brute force? Nothing. Skyrim's two melee combat skills are fundamentally different and highly customizable. Wasteland 2 has 3 melee combat skills that all work exactly the same. Skyrim had one speech skill. Wasteland 2 has 3 speech skills that all work exactly the same. Skyrim has two healing skills (restoration and alchemy) that could not be more functionally different. W2's two healing skills are almost exactly the same (although some of the status effect descriptions are funny). At least half of the skills in Wasteland 2 are unnecessary clones of other skills.Overall, Wasteland 2 has some strong points that are overwhelmed by it's weaknesses.

number of helpful: 18 of 35 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13
												Notice: My review states that I do not recommend this game because of inXile Entertainment's exceptionally scummy behavior during the "inXile vs The Alien Wasteland" incident (Google it for more details - basically, inXile used copyright laws in a frivolous way to bully a small indie developer). If you are in any way conscious about the future of game development, I implore you not to buy the game or any of the other Wasteland games. (If you are desperately looking for a post-apoc RPG, have a look at Underrail!)To other reviewers: due to a Steam glitch, you have to review Wasteland 2 DC by posting a review to regular Wasteland 2. That also means you have to install and play that for at least 5 minutes too if you haven't already. (This is why it seems like I've only played a couple minutes - my real playtime is ~50 hours right now.)For the sake of honesty, I am also going to write up a brief summary of the good and the bad points of the game itself. Wasteland 2: Director's Cut is a post-apocalyptic RPG about an American militia organization named the Desert Rangers who try to uphold law and order in Arizona after a global nuclear apocalypse, as well as the events of the first game (which, as explained very soon in the game as well, involved stopping a crazy scientist and a malevolent AI). You lead a party of four (or less) Rangers on a mission to find out about the circumstances of the death of another Ranger. This party can later gain up to three additional followers, up to a squad size of seven. These followers (of which there are plenty, so you'll have to make choices as to who you carry along) have the slight drawback that they can "go rogue", i.e. ignore your orders and do their own thing each turn (this can be mitigated), but are otherwise perfectly functional player characters.Sounds like a lot to manage? It's not as bad as it sounds. The character attribute/skill system is simple enough, though it can feel overwhelming on a first playthrough. However, W2 DC does provide a default squad - you can roll with it on the normal ("Seasoned") difficulty level on a first playthrough and do alright (at least I did). The tutorial system is adequate and explores the various elements of the game well enough that you probably won't feel lost after the first 15-30 minutes. Combat may seem a bit punishing at first, but if you explore enough, the game rewards you pretty soon with a "crutch" follower, who is quite a bit stronger than your characters at that point and will help you get through the first few areas. (Though I also have a minor quibble here: this very same follower will eventually leave you, so if you thought they were a solid fixture on your team and rely on them for a critical skill, you may suddenly be left with a gaping hole in your team after they leave. You are subtly warned that they might only stay while your team are still greenhorns, but the warning is too subtle in my opinion. Most other followers do stick around once they join you, though, unless you make a choice that pisses them off big time.)Speaking of choices, this game does have its fair share of "choices and consequences". Like most games that advertise this, this game does not deviate too much from its major storyline either, and the choices only have flavor effects or some minor gameplay effects at most. This does not mean the C&C system in the game is necessarily bad - I'm just telling you what to expect. Your choices do shape the world, even if not all of them have a significant effect on when and how you win the game. In keeping with the gritty theme, often you are forced to choose between two bad outcomes or may not be able to  stop a certain kind of evil at all no matter what you do, but at other times you can help the wasteland become a better place.The various factions in the game are interesting, many of them are well-developed and have engaging characters. Unfortunately, the main plot is a bit too railroaded for my taste - the game is designed with the assumption that you are going to be a Desert Ranger through and through, identifying with them without question and opposing the main boss. There are some interesting nuances to the ideology of the main antagonists, but the game does not explore them sufficiently. There are alternate endings where you do not do what the Rangers expect you to do, but they are unsatisfying to say the least. The side quests are actually more interesting than the main plot IMO.Regarding game balance, the game is balanced well enough that you can do a first playthrough on Seasoned (the default, normal difficulty level) with just the right amount of challenge, not too much frustration, but not too easy either. I think you might conceivably be able try a blind ironman first run as well, if you are so inclined - though I'd probably recommend  Rookie for that. The game is not a roguelike though, and it isn't designed for endless replayability - I think that there are about 2-3 playthroughs' worth of material in the game (provided you like it enough to replay it), and no more, so I'd advise against blind ironman play. One positive I'd like to note is that unlike quite a few CRPGs I've ever seen (the worst violator being Age of Decadence), this game - at least on normal difficulty - does not need extreme minmaxing to succeed, and you *can* start with suboptimal builds and still perform well enough. You can even branch out into a lot of non-combat skills and still be strong enough to be able to fight, and the game is forgiving enough that you can make drastic changes to your skill focuses over the course of 5-10 levels if you take your team in the wrong direction (my characters were around level 40 by the time they completed the game). For example, if you realize you desperately need the Lockpicking skill and forgot to take it on any of your characters, well, you'll be missing some containers for a while, but you aren't hopelessly behind and will probably still be able to max it out if you aren't too late into the game.The interface and user-friendly aspects are generally good - there aren't a lot of really inconvenient/frustrating functionalities I've found, carry weights are not a huge issue, useless junk items that have no use other than sell value can be sold with a single click all at once... not much bad I can say here.If you care about that sort of thing, the game is also LGBTQ-positive. Well, I haven't seen any T, but they might exist without you realizing it, y'know? There are quite a few openly gay characters though (mostly minor, but a particular married lesbian couple will help you out in the final battle if you help them out before). I've also found at least one crossdresser (in a town which is famous for its extreme sexual libertinism, to the point of being ruled over by a sex worker - and they are actually one of the nicer communities in the game, certainly compared to their main rivals) and hey, the game does technically allow you to have gay sex, though nothing is shown on screen - so if you're looking for smut, don't get your hopes up.As a minor bonus, you can dress up your character in one of many different outfits found throughout the game world - this'll affect the appearance of your toons in the game world and on the character screen (though it's only cosmetic), and since any worn armor doesn't actually appear on you, this functionality isn't made obsolete as soon as you want to put some armor on. You can put really indecent clothes on your females, or have your men walk around in a pair of hold-up stockings, or even dress them up in a way that's actually intimidating and/or practical (but why'd you want to do that?!). It's a fun little minigame you can entertain yourself with while you are shuffling your inventory around.Overall verdict: avoid, for reasons stated in the very beginning. If you do not care about punishing dodgy business practices, then I'll let you judge based on the rest of the review.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												“Bottle caps?! We only accept scrap.”Greetings to you, traveller! We welcome you into our wasteland with water in our cans and radiation in our lungs!You may not understand our wasteland, you may even fear it. Do not worry, we have all struggled in such ignorance or died of thirst in the desert. To understand what the wasteland is, is to understand the Great Glow. Everything is part of it, but it is the mushroom cloud that expresses it most directly.But, do you not need to seek the next mushroom cloud to find the Great Glow? The answer is no! Look into the eyes of a mutated animal that is about to attack you. See that energy, that life there? That is the Great Glow.  Of course the blessing of the Great Glow is not for free, for nothing in life is free. Study the various wasteland guides to truly understand the Great Glow, the nature of the mushroom cloud, and understand why salvation lies only through their wisdom.  And always keep these rules in mind:1. Tread lightly and carry a big gun and/or stick.2. Every animal with the prefix ‘mutated’ considers you to be its lunch. 3. If your Geiger counter starts going off the scale, you should turn around.  4. The only thing worse than a robot the size of a truck with a circular saw and a laser beam, is a robot the size of a house with a minigun, a flamethrower and half a dozen minions that are coming right for you.5. Toaster repair is essential for a good breakfast.Fun fact: The credit song “Cries of a Dead World” by Miracle of Sound perfectly captures the atmosphere of Wasteland 2. --My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:-	Atmosphere-	Combat & Controls-	Details-	Tactical gameplay-	Characters-	StoryBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading: -	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorIf the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).--Atmosphere: S-Rank(This oddly dressed merchant sports a slight tan, huge arms and legs, a bear belly, and big beard with two white stripes in it. Under normal circumstances the pink tutu around his belly would look odd, but somehow Ratboy makes it work.)Combat & Controls: S-Rank(If yer sober, that’s the best yer gonna feel all day.)Details: S-Rank(Shoving your hand into a roiling vat of glowing radioactive gloop is probably one of the worst ideas you’ve ever had.) Tactical gameplay: S-Rank(A little more persistence, a little more effort, and what seemed hopeless failure may turn out to glorious success.)Characters: A-Rank Story: A-Rank--To conquer all achievements of Wasteland 2, you will most likely spend more than 100 hours. You can get them all in one play-through, assuming you watch out for the ‘Wasteland Historian’ achievement.   There are no multiplayer achievements. Two very useful guides can be found on the links below (thanks to Carrarius & Tigi). 


YouTube™ Video: Wasteland 2 Director's Cut - First Hour Noob 60fps

number of helpful: 27 of 53 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												I so want to like this game... The story is nice, the writing is good, but the combat is awful. The gameplay is dated, maybe it can appeal to retro gamers or people who mistake boring mechanics with hardcore. There is a lot of boring combats, which is slow and crappy.The hard consequences that the game touted are...subpar so far. Fallout New Vegas felt more alive and your actions had more weight than here.To talk in details about the combat system, think fallout without any combat options (no called shots) and moronic AI. You just trade blows with hard-hitting melee sprinters or eagle eyed ranged NPCs that suffer from a preference to eat lead by leaving cover if someone is next to them. It's turn based, but with no tactics (you could call the cover system tactical if you were very nice) and as such it ends up being slow.The character creation system is poor and having no perks and lackluster attributes leave not so much to the imagination. The skills are varied and made necessary if you don't want to trudge throught the combats.The dialogues are sometimes a tad strange and you end up with some stereotypical NPCs. They try to put a veneer of gray on your choices with cynicism and "realism", but it often fall flat IMHO due to the comedic nature of some situations.A lot of the quests are fedex quests made painful by the lack of fast travel, slowness of movement and the ubiquitous boring slow combats. The so-called inhospitable wastelands are filled with oasis, making the presence of the water mechanics... strange to say the least as it never occured to me I could lack water.The "open world" is level locked, so even though you could probably go wherever you want, the choices are often limited.If you have most of the skills (and with the 3 NPCs you can recruit, it's easy to keep nearly all of them maxed) you'll be rich and never have to worry about ammo.I understand the devs wanted to cater to the nostalgics of Wasteland 1, but gaming has evolved and some mechanics are better left dead in the 90s.In short, a promising game with crappy combats

content:

Early Access Review
								I honestly can't see how there are so many positive reviews on this garbage at it's current state, i'm honestly starting to believe I may have recieved some "nega copy" from the depths that should be played by no man alike.Let me just start out with this; as a fallout 1 and 2 childhood fan, i truly looked forward to this title after seeing it raise about three million dollars. Now if you don't know already, three million creates hype for those who don't even understand the cultural relevance of the first wasteland, so this early release had something to live up to. Hell even the early reviews state that the game is promising, so maybe i'm not the one understanding what the word 'promising' means any longer. See when I think of a 'promising' three million dollar game, I think of an enjoyable yet somewhat bumpy experience at this point of development, not some poorly put together thing called a game that can't function past fifteen minutes without bugs annihilating everything in their path. And the best part, that during those fifteen minutes of play I recieve, even the bugs aside, the game is boring. Nothing, and I mean nothing, compels me to go forward with the lackluster story, the combat is atrociously broken and slow, and the whole experience feels like it was made by two men in a basement with a few connections to decent voice actors who had no idea what on earth they were doing, not a skilled development team with a ludicrous amount of money at their fingertips.But hey. I'm a glass half full kind of guy, so maybe this piece of trash is another man's treasure.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Have tried to get into this game now 2-3 times and it's not working for me. Interface with the party members moving together and separate is awkward--especially when arcane puzzles require your characters to be all over like at the early AG center quest (but then they can move together through doors to other areas? How can you separate party members then have them teleport back together when one leaves an adventure map?Combat is awkward on a grid w/o hex. Mobs pretty much cover the entire map in one turn so good luck with a distribution of your melee and ranged characters. Many different skills are great, but it's awkward when you have things like safe requiring either computer skill or safecracking depending on type which must be perceived first followed by counter-intuitive things like using demolition skill to clear traps and such. Most of all really is the poison time limit they place on you in aformentioned Ag center quest. Solve all these arcane puzzles and fight all these awkward battles to avoid your party dying of a time limit disease. There is a reason I enjoy turn based games. I don't need time constraints. Game is just not clean and clear. If you want to add complexity to the game that is fine but you need to clear up your interface first. I LOVED Fallout and XCOM and this just isn't anything like them really. Really disappointed.

								I recommend this digital deluxe edition to 1) everyone who liked the original wasteland, fallout 1 and 2 or fallout tactics and want such games back, 2) people who like to support crowdfunded games by independent producers, 3) people who want to participate in a beta process.The game is obviously in a beta stadium, but the game looks overall promising. The current beta is also lengthy, at least about 8-12 hours. There are still some major bugs to be fixed, optimizations to be done, some mechanics to be included, and some heavy balancing issues to be solved, but according to inXile the beta should get updated regulary and they also said, they are going to add a few maps to the beta over time. 								One of my earlier games I love to play was wasteland. So upon seeing this brings back memories and at a instant I really wanted to get this and try out besides Fallout Franchise being one of my favourites.I have play for a while now I am ready for a review. I am quite neutral about this wasteland 2. I felt something is missing as in the past.Pros1) Good depth of character customization.2) Side and main quests3) Good amount of weapons items etc4) Freedom to move around and explore5)Combat system is a pretty challenging. Cons1) Even on rookie levels can be quite a challenge. 2) You cannot go higher a few levels of each character even though you radio or farm till you completed certain quests so its quite restrain. ( BIggest Minus Point for me )3) Encounters are pretty fixed in certain areas example just south of Ranger camp you will always enounter 3 bandits no less no more most times.4) Ammo is so so hard to get and super expensive even in Rookie mode. Also items like first aid etc.5) Once in quest every encounters is crucial as almost of of your members will get injuries at some point and you need alot of first aid to scrap through. Your hp does not recover over time etc.Conclusion: If you like challenging just like xcom2 you can give this a try. However if you are one like me having not much time working and just a old school game where even at rookie stage will provide you a hairgrib then i will say give it a miss. Till now I have only play like less than a day I dun feel so much of interest of playing.  For me a game that cost over $60 I am looking for a game to enjoy and not give too much of difficulty even at rookie challenge.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Having played the original Wasteland and every Fallout game released, (Yes, even that one for the X-Box. You know the one I'm talking about), I was pretty much expecting a better version of Fallout Tactics with a deeper, richer story line. The result? I little underwhelming, but overall a good experience.Tight, turn-based tactical combat with a rotatable isometric view mean that other than a few oddities that occur with objects that are "between the camera and the view," the control is pretty solid. The game rewards you for good tactics and positioning with every weapon skill having it's pro's and it's cons. You're not penalized for having a diverse team and the biggest problem of simply having a team of grunts with no real other skills is simply that a lot of side missions will be more difficult, if not impossible.The downside... the story feels a little "been there, bought the t-shirt." And not just for a player of wasteland. There really isn't anything in this world that the game presents that genuinely feels original in any way, with the unfortunate majority of the various groups you come across feeling like someone blew the dust off and gave it a new coat of paint. Not a slapdash job though, but a loving restoration with a few embellishments here-and-there. The big disappointment was the final mission/ending. If any part felt like you'd played it before, it was this one. *sigh*Still, an enjoyable game for Hardcore fans of the Post Apocalyptic genre, or relative newcomers. But anyone else may want to give it a miss if retreading familiar ground doesn't catch their fancy.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Let's start with the bottom line - If you liked Fallout 1/2 - Get this game.Buy it now , stop wasting your time.This game is great.It's an absolute throwback to post apocalyptic games of the 90s-2000s with some modern parts.I say some - because it mainly sticks to mechanics invented in the 90s , not a lot of inovation.That said - the game has very good writing , lot's of player choice and interesting skill trees that evolve nicely.Good thing you start with a party of 4 to be able to divide the skills between your characters - because you'll be totally surprised of how useful some skills are over others.I'm 50 hours into the game and reached the last fight - it's very challenging and I feel I might have reached it too early which is a bit of a bummer.Regarding bugs - the only one that affected me was the 32bit memory issue. this would mean - when using high textures - it will crash when moving into / out of maps constantly.This is especially absurd because it's only for the lack of 64 bit support on mac.I'm playing on a MBPr 15" - which can run this game easily and it crashes all the time.Solution - lower the texture maps one notch.Another bummer is it doesn't really support the Retina resolution , There is no reason for me to play on my native non retina resolution when my screen can easily work on double that resolution / at least at 1080P.Other then those issues - no complaints whatsoever.Looking forward to playing much more.

number of helpful: 14 of 28 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								OK...now this is the game. This is the successor to the grand father of cRPGs, the spiritual father of FALLOUT...This is Wasteland 2!The game is still in beta (or early access, what ever you want to call it). It is also still suffering from optimization issues, bugs, and clunky game design.HOWEVER, these things do not hinder the game. In its state, is is solid, and plays very well. It feels like a true port-apocalyptic game, and it can definitely stand up to FALLOUT of STALKER. The story telling is wonderful, combat works and feels great, the atmosphere is just perfect, there is a bit of humor and secrets, many new and unfamiliar enemies, andTONS of customization. You can tactically set up your team and develop them as they level up, or you can build your own character from the ground up. It is just overall a well done project.It is still being developed, and new updates will be coming out for it. The UI will be fixed, it will be optimized, much more will be added...and in the end, this wonderful, promising stone will be polished to be one of the greatest cRPGs done.I know, the price tag is a little steep. But, if you are willing to buy it, and if you are willing to put up with a (currently) incomplete game, and if you are going to commit yourself to giving back to the devs, then it will be a worthwhile purchase. Additionally, this is a great game if you loved FALLOUT (esp. the first 2 and tactics) and Wasteland. Should you buy it? It depends, you might not want to, and you are certainly not being forced to. But if you do, know you are contributing to a constantly developing and promising sequel to a beloved game.

												Suffers from a lot of the same problems as other "1990s throwback" isometric RPGs, which is to say confusing maps and awkward progression. Expect to get lost a lot (hint: backspace resets north to up), spend a lot of time tramping over the same ground (agian, and again, and again), and getting frustrated when you do things "out of order" and turn an entire zone against you (yeah, Canyon of Titan, I'm looking at you).An otherwise interesting premise (it's essentially Fallout 2.5) that would benifit from a lot more polish and the inclusion of some of the "quality of life" stuff from more modern games (map markers would be a nice start).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Update: I changed my review to not recommend in order to purposefully lower the rating of this game on Steam. Quite simply when I kickstarted this game, Brian Fargo liked to go on and on about how they wanted to get away from big Publisher models, always being on the hook to publishers just seeking profit. But then they have been going out and trying to force developers with complete success so far, to change the names of their games if it contains the word Wasteland.You know its funny, because thats exactly something a publisher would do, they would throw money away pursuing these things instead of making games like Brian Fargo claimed thats what he wanted to do. Its understandable to engage in these legal matters when a game is intentionally trying to ape your stuff, but in every case the only similarity between titles, was the word Wasteland.Have the courage to stand for something InXile, no one is going to try and USURP the Wasteland IP by making ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little indie games. I won't be sending you anymore of my money(unless you get the Fallout IP back and make Fallout games). So yeah, Never again.Original, still true review below:I have about 110 combined hours between Wasteland 2 Classic and the Director's Cut.I backed this game on kickstarter and was pleased with Wasteland 2, to get the Director's Cut after for free was a huge bonus for me.The game itself plays like a squad-based Fallout 1 and 2, but in its own 1980s style post-nuclear setting. The RPG elements are solid but the game is combat focused which I am happy for. You get a number of useable skills to to do quests with, find hidden objects and loot. There is a ton of flavor text everywhere you go which help adds to the immersion and feeling of the game which I love. The music is a perfect ambient style soundtrack which hits all the right notes and there is an ambient soundtrack for areas aswell to help add to that immersion.There are tons of things to do in the wasteland and plenty to shoot aswell. Lots of weapons to choose from and different types of armors to wear. You can find clothing to dress your rangers up if you want, or will need to find clothing if you get it burnt off in combat!I think if you enjoy squad based turn based combat, you'll like this game. If you enjoy post-apocalypse settings, you'll enjoy this game. If you like to read and use your imagination, you'll like this game.If you liked Fallout 1 and 2, you will like this game.I found a Speak and Spell(remember those?) and pawned to the vendor for 8 scrap, it doesn't get much better than that.9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is super buggy right now and I'm not having a fun time at all playing it.Here's the specs of the two systems I'm using: 1) Win7     2.6 GHz i5 (4 core)     650 GTX Ti Boost 2) 15" Macbook Retina 2013IssuesMechanics: - Skills do not work properly and/or not included at this time. - Some items requiring a certain skill to use are not selectable when attempting to use the skill. - Lockpick and Safecracking are separate skills but are usually coupled together (you unlock a door and the only thing in the room is a safe, also this is just a pet peeve of mine)UI: - Dispite being told by the game of this functionality, I cannot to scroll the view port by moving my mouse to the sides of the screen. The screen seems to lock onto your party once they begin to move and otherwise WASD+QE is the only way I've found to move the camera. - Not attractive, not terrible though, and can only be scaled larger to a cartoonish size. - Help pop ups seemed to appear and disappear randomly (I was in many fights before a tip about Ambush ever occured) - Outside of your skill bar, keyboard shortcuts are not displayed for actions. I spent more time in the Control Mapping menu than I'd care too but this was so much more helpful than anything in-game. - Unless you mash on Perception all the time as you run, you'll miss things all the time. Nothing useable like chests, doors, computers are very obvious at all and blend in to the other dark browns, greens, and blacks. - It's sometime difficult to select an item to use. I've dug up a few mounds with the shovel that wouldn't highlight or change the cursor when selecting them. - You can interact with things through walls.Graphics: - Textures are no where near "beautiful" (their word, not mine) - Your brightness level is forgotten each time you load a save - Some enemy corpses continue to animate like they are alive - There are many items with no icons at all, so a Misc default image is used.I'm sure I've left off some things and I'm sure there are other aspects of the game I really like that aren't coming to mind (I'm still playing it). This just doesn't feel like a beta much less a $60 beta. I've read the devs reporting ~50 hrs of gameplay but in this state there's no way anyone will want to play it for more than a few unless you're blinded by fandom.If you're an old school Fallout or Wasteland fan, you'll probably want to buy it.Just don't expect it to be everything you've hoped for.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								So far so good, Wasteland 2 is shaping up to be a great buy but in its current state I would hold off unless you a) like beta testing or b) are nostalgic for Fallout 1+2.The game is much more combat focused than the early Fallout games but its combat system is definitely an improvement over those games. The visuals are also very pleasing and level of detail is nice. Your actions do have consequence to the world and some choices will cause certain areas to be inaccessbile, this makes me think that multiple playthroughs will be necessary in order to experience most of the comabt.Other than the obvious issues associated with being early in beta such as missing or limited content there are some major issues.  There is little feedback for most of the skills and during combat it is hard to tell how many action points some actions cost. There are also numerous bugs and pathing issues that can be frustrating but most won't ruin a playthrough.I would hesitate to buy this game now while it's in its infancy and with its current 60$ pricetag it is a sizeable investment. Down the road when it becomes more finished I would highly recommend this game. Based on the current direction I am estimating that this game will be a very enjoyable RPG.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Finally, after all these years, we get a proper spiritual sequel to the first Fallout games. In fact, Wasteland 2 looks and feels so much like a Fallout game that it took me some time to accept that I had no Pipboy, Vault suit or funny perks.It's a really engaging game with an interesting story (without being revolutionary in any way), with the usual moral dilemmas and multiple paths to complete objectives. And it's great value for money; I personally spent 86 hours on a single playthrough! Granted, I like to take my time more than most, but few games offer me that much nowadays.It's not a perfect game though; the ending is lackluster and the latter half of the game (with one area in particular) is riddled with some rather annoying (but not gamebreaking) bugs. But eh, I guess the bugs is just another aspect  that emulates the good old Fallout games...All in all, I'll definetely recommend this for fans of post-apocalyptic settings, roleplaying games and the Fallout series in particular.8/10 (perhaps even 9/10 if they fix most of the bugs)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I love many things about this game. I dislike very few things.But what is most important is that this game has the wondrous feeling of escapist post-apocalyptic exploration flavor I thought we had lost forever.When Bethesda butchered Fallout III (and although Obsidian salvaged it) -- I had no hope that I would feel the way I did in the late 90s again. I was an impressionable kid, getting owned by floaters and centaurs, unprepared, Sulik bursting like a dumba$$ riddling Vic with holes-- but I loved every moment of it.Wasteland 2 took me to that place once again, especially as you progress through the game, it becomes an old school classic that we were sorely missing in our lives for the past 20 years.This game is an heir to the likes of Baldur's Gate 2, Fallout 1&2 and of course the grandfather of them all, the original Wasteland.Thanks Brian & Co. for the liquifying energy weapon animations. Thanks for the non-linear love this game got. Thanks for all the times you listened to the community and backers. Thanks for sticking to your ideals and not caving in like Bioware at the onslaught of console idiocy. Thanks for Ertan the Satanist.Thanks for returning us 90s kids back to the world intelligent, brutal and immersive cRPG gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												+ Branching quests with multiple viable solutions and diverse outcomes.+ The choices you make affect the world in meaningful ways.+ Tons of content with very little filler (unlike Dragon Age: Inquisition).+ Solid writing.- Assault rifles are OP and make every other weapon type seem comparatively useless.- Combat doesn't have a lot of depth or variety.- Game was pretty buggy at launch, particularly the late game (though this may be fixed by now).- Graphics ain't too pretty.- Some skills are overly specialized (like Toaster Repair and Blunt Force).- It's easy to screw yourself over if you don't have a lot of experience with CRPGs.Conclusion: If you enjoyed the first two Fallout games, you will likely enjoy Wasteland 2. If you didn't, you probably won't. Also, if you only care about combat and don't care about things like quest design or reactivity, you'll probably get bored.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Summary – 7/10 Good game for those who like post apocalypse setting, top down 3rd person point of view, large variety of weapons.  Buy when on sale for under $20.Pro:+ Post Apocalypse setting+ Lots of decision trees, dialog options+ Multiple ways to complete an objective+ Interesting story (bringing law and order to a place of total anarchy)+ Decent number of quests (about 60-70)+ Nice unique maps+ Dismemberment, melting on some kill shots+ Easy to use UI+ Humor and funny references especially of the 80’s throughout. Con: - Lacks the immersiveness of 1st person viewpoint games  (Fallout: New Vegas, Fallout 3)- Can’t interact with most of the environment.  Almost all building entrances are blocked and using explosives won’t change that.- Poor AI – just set up an ambush point on a map send out a meat shield to draw the enemies and kill them as they approach.  Works almost every time.- Explosives so overpowered in combat.  They never miss even if your character doesn’t have a single point in explosives. Give meatshield a ton of STR (which equals HP).  Have enemy mob him.  He runs out then toss grenades.  Battle won. Rinse. Repeat.- Game maps are fairly linear (except for Titan Canyon)- Dull weapon/shooting animations (just one animation for all weapons)- Non realistic skill (Toaster Repair (really!!))- Poor stat optimization.  Intelligence > all.  Many stats just not important.- Too many skills focused on just opening containers (open lock, tumbler, alarm, trap, perception) since you have to divide up skills amongst players to max them all quickly it means switching through multiple players just to open a container.  Pretty poor design.- Every container is either trapped or has an alarm attached to it (or both).  - Few locations (Less than a two dozen maps in the AZ and CA zones)- RNG on skills is not even close to what is listed.  50% chance of success really means 10% chance of success at most.  Use PF9 and PF11 constantly can waste 10 minutes opening a chest/safe not very enjoyable.- Easily broken quests. Lots of reloading to complete a quest.- No mods or modding community (lack of replayability) Note my playtime means nothing as I have a small child now and often have a game running/paused on one monitor all weekend even though I may only play 15 minutes every couple hours when I have a few minutes to relax.  Probably only spent 25-30 hrs actually completing the game.In general if you are a huge fan of Post Apocalypse games like me then you will enjoy this game.  Not too many bugs in the game just a few like:- Examining ground that says something is buried but not allowing you to use a shovel or any other skill on the ground.  This happened 3-4 times.- Trying to save after visiting a travelling merchant to offload junk.  Get a message saying “you are in combat and can’t save at this time”  Guess the merchants don’t like the deal they received hehe. - Memory Leak (At least when you pause the game for 2+ hours and then unpause the game it moves slower than molasses. It’s a pain if you forgot to PF9 before hitting pause. (Use a liquid cooled Alienware rig as my main gaming machine and it’s a beast so they lag/stutter and huge decrease in frame-rate is due to a memory leak).Though please note that it is not even comparable to Fallout: New Vegas with its fully interactive environment, open world, 1st person view, great soundtrack, number of factions and locations but for a budget/on sale game this is something to enjoy for awhile.  Still not sure why all the most valuable items (skill books) in a post apocalypse world would be stored inside toasters.  Also be sure to PF9 before using any skill then PF11 when it fails will allow you to open every intractable item in the game.  Also press “Z” a lot to find all intractable items.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								So far so good, Wasteland 2 is shaping up to be a great buy but in its current state I would hold off unless you a) like beta testing or b) are nostalgic for Fallout 1+2.The game is much more combat focused than the early Fallout games but its combat system is definitely an improvement over those games. The visuals are also very pleasing and level of detail is nice. Your actions do have consequence to the world and some choices will cause certain areas to be inaccessbile, this makes me think that multiple playthroughs will be necessary in order to experience most of the comabt.Other than the obvious issues associated with being early in beta such as missing or limited content there are some major issues.  There is little feedback for most of the skills and during combat it is hard to tell how many action points some actions cost. There are also numerous bugs and pathing issues that can be frustrating but most won't ruin a playthrough.I would hesitate to buy this game now while it's in its infancy and with its current 60$ pricetag it is a sizeable investment. Down the road when it becomes more finished I would highly recommend this game. Based on the current direction I am estimating that this game will be a very enjoyable RPG.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I can not be more clear that this: IF you've enjoyed games of this genre in the past (i.e. Jagged Alliance, XCom, Fallouts 1 & 2), then you WILL love (not like, but love) this game.  Period.  It blends the very best parts of what makes games of this genre good, and does it very successfully.Graphics: checkUI: CheckGreat Story: CheckVoice Acting: CheckDrama, Choice, and Consequence: CheckCharacter customization and development: CheckThings I left off but that are important to this genre: CheckHonestly, if you've like the games I named above, and don't buy this game, you're doing it wrong.I'm not going into the the whole "this is a beta", "I found a bug", or "the game isn't complete yet" discussions because they are all short term issues with what is a long term home run.  Buy it now, or buy it later, but BUY IT.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Edit after a few more hours of playBacked on Kickstarter with BG2 nostalgia. Too much of a mixed bag for me. - Writing, atmosphere and emotional engagementLet's be clear, that's why we're here. Boy have I missed playing a squad of lively characters with believable, coherent personalities (yeah I'm looking at you Bethesda). You start with 4 PCs and can have 3 NPCs at a time. The writing is good but very unequal from zone to zone, sometimes great, sometimes annoying. - Strategy, tactics and intellectual engagement Tactics are OK but get boring quite quickly. More complexity and diversity would have been nice, like with expanded science/crafting/mechanics skills and lots of consumables and craftable devices to adapt to each encounter (to have something akin to the wizards in BG2). Strategy is annoying. Your choices are too uninformed early on ; for me the beginning was very hard whereas it got too easy after I got the mechanics. Non-combat skills are universally unnerving. They are designed so that you can only get a fraction of the game per playthrough, unless you save and reload a lot, so you are left to pick between playing the game 15 times or reloading all the time. - Design and engineeringI haven't played the beta. The game is fluid and bug free on my 64-bit Ubuntu rig (still looking at you Bethesda). I initially had 1 glitch in 40 hours, but then there was a bug that made me lose 4 hours of play and that's kind of a dealbreaker for me. Loading times could have been faster, and the UI could have been better (more visible highlight mode, unified and codified representation of possible interactions (wasted one real-life hour in highpool because the highlighting of the Surgeon skill is different form that of Disarm), a panel with all the skills from everybody ...). - GraphicsLet's be clear, that's not why we're here. Isometric 3D works for me, other than that, don't care. Sometimes it's too 3D : stuff gets in the way and it's hard to click where you want (whatever). - SoundMusic OK but not memorable - would have loved some epic music. Voice acting sometimes dull, sometimes great, sometimes non-existent.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I cant recommend it yet. The Models need serious attention, and its clear that some areas received a lot of love and care in their construction and others are very much still Beta-Playtest blanks; and this is in the intro areas, Im talking about Citadel, Ag Center and Hightower.  Stat, loot and skill balancing needs work, and there's some very *very* clunky and poorly thought out UI choices, which Im unsure of whether they can blame that on Unity or not. Considering the LOD that the Cenega XCOM games, and most recently the *actual* Xcom games recieved, the turn based combat here doesnt seem retro, it just seems amateurish. not being able to force 'combat mode' so you can properly position your people to spring ambushes is particularly awful if you're trying the higher difficulty levels.Admittedly most of my gripes come down to mechanics; but the HardAss/KissAss/SmartAss mechanics ties directly into the players experience of the plot, and to split this out into three stats rather than a single Social check results in the player experiencing their characters as belligirent, smarmy or conniving caricatures, rather than intelligent people making choices. I keep putting the hours in, hoping it'll turn around, but for now Im really rather disappointed: this comes across less like a sequel to wasteland, and more like the original wasteland creators haven't played or written a game since then; and then came out of hibernation, dug out UnityInANutshell and promised all us whippersnappers a good time.
