number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is super buggy right now and I'm not having a fun time at all playing it.Here's the specs of the two systems I'm using: 1) Win7     2.6 GHz i5 (4 core)     650 GTX Ti Boost 2) 15" Macbook Retina 2013IssuesMechanics: - Skills do not work properly and/or not included at this time. - Some items requiring a certain skill to use are not selectable when attempting to use the skill. - Lockpick and Safecracking are separate skills but are usually coupled together (you unlock a door and the only thing in the room is a safe, also this is just a pet peeve of mine)UI: - Dispite being told by the game of this functionality, I cannot to scroll the view port by moving my mouse to the sides of the screen. The screen seems to lock onto your party once they begin to move and otherwise WASD+QE is the only way I've found to move the camera. - Not attractive, not terrible though, and can only be scaled larger to a cartoonish size. - Help pop ups seemed to appear and disappear randomly (I was in many fights before a tip about Ambush ever occured) - Outside of your skill bar, keyboard shortcuts are not displayed for actions. I spent more time in the Control Mapping menu than I'd care too but this was so much more helpful than anything in-game. - Unless you mash on Perception all the time as you run, you'll miss things all the time. Nothing useable like chests, doors, computers are very obvious at all and blend in to the other dark browns, greens, and blacks. - It's sometime difficult to select an item to use. I've dug up a few mounds with the shovel that wouldn't highlight or change the cursor when selecting them. - You can interact with things through walls.Graphics: - Textures are no where near "beautiful" (their word, not mine) - Your brightness level is forgotten each time you load a save - Some enemy corpses continue to animate like they are alive - There are many items with no icons at all, so a Misc default image is used.I'm sure I've left off some things and I'm sure there are other aspects of the game I really like that aren't coming to mind (I'm still playing it). This just doesn't feel like a beta much less a $60 beta. I've read the devs reporting ~50 hrs of gameplay but in this state there's no way anyone will want to play it for more than a few unless you're blinded by fandom.If you're an old school Fallout or Wasteland fan, you'll probably want to buy it.Just don't expect it to be everything you've hoped for.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the early access so I will try to be reasonable with how I feel about the game.The game reminds me so much of Fallout 1 & 2 with support for higher resolution. The graphics are nothing spectacular but it doesnt have to be since the game focuses more on user experience and immersion. Yes immersion! I'm not a big fan of reading especially long dialogs but this game does it well by letting you visualize what's happening in the world via text (type writer) and npc barks. It totally allows you to use your imagination without even realizing it. Yes, there are a bunch of typos that I've noticed which affects my experience personally, but then again it's still on beta. I like the fact that the quest log system does not treat you like a dumb person, unlike Fallout 3 where it shows you on your compass where you need to go. Instead the log gives you details of what you've accomplished so far and what you need to do next. I'm playing the default difficulty (seasoned) which is very challenging and the loot system is well thought of. The scarcity of ammos and health pickups allow you to decide whether you should go back to citadel (home) by travelling which is by the way is very very dangerous, or just keep pursuing hoping that you'll maybe get lucky and find some loot or vendors along the way. There are also a lot of interesting items you may find such as sega genesis console, neogeo, and even a used condom. I think they are irrelevant to the game but it's defnitely entertaining. I probably won't sell them. It would really be awesome if the developers can go even further with it and allow you to give it to a person in citadel to place it in citadel collection room or something, to display your awesome finds.The controls are pretty good, it's could be improved though. But I liked the fact that I can play it with just the mouse, so I don't have to hunch down in front of my keyboard. I can just sit back, relax, with one hand on the mouse. It accomodates old gamer like me who's retired and doesn't have to work and just allow the kid inside me to just enjoy what I've missed when I was growing up working too hard. No more stiff necks and sore elbows. But like I said it can be improved. Also, if I may add, I really like how the cursor system was in fallout 1& 2. I think it's actually one of my favorite and memorable to me that right-clicking changes the cursor behavior to walking or action command. I can't remember if it was double click the walk mode to run but that would be awesome option. instead of holding down shift key.I like that they stayed away from static camera, but sometimes I wish there's an option to turn it back to static camera because the camera can get a little clunky sometimes. When you're tryign to find the travel zone it can get very frustrating, I think the way to solve this is by minimap (starcraft like)  which you can click on an area in the minimap and move the camera to that spot, which is currently not in the game. Speaking of map, I wish they have the option like in fallout 1 & 2 to have some kind of a town map that you recently visited to allow you to just go directly to a certain part of the town instead of walking all the way from the travel zone just to talk to one guy, then walking back all the way again to get out of the town. By the way the first time i took a ride at the crane elevator at highpool i was like, "Oh cool", but after doing that for about 10 times I'm like "Okay...", then I'd noticed one of my party member was left behind so i have to go through the cutscene again just to get my other team mate. I know it probably took some time and even effort for whoever designed this but it get's annoying especially when you're on the go. I'm not sure if there's vehicles in the game that you can ride like in fallout 2, and if there is it'll be awesome if you can customize it to add protection from radiation and and dehydration and allow a faster travel with options to attack random encounters using a higher outdoorsman skill. Also what's up with kick♥♥♥♥♥ smart♥♥♥♥♥ and hard♥♥♥♥♥ I mean, does it really need to have 3 separate skill for each one? I hope they make this into just one skill, I don't know like just Kick♥♥♥♥♥ I'm kinda glad that it's still in beta, which leaves a lot of room for improvements, I just hope that the deveopers are as open as they should be for suggestions and improvements. And I look forward for this awesome game to get even more awesome.Bottom line is I'm totally recommending this game if you can tolerate grotesque, rude languages, violence, drugs, prostitution, and sad reality of the world to come after the apocalipse.I know I've written a lot already, but I will add some more as I progress with the game.Thank you InXile for making this game.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												I was skeptical that a crowd funded game with a 60 dollar initial pricetag would actually end up being a solid title. Thankfully, I was proven wrong. I picked up the game for 40 dollars and so far it has been worth every penny.Gameplay- This isn't a game that holds your hand every step of the way, often times you need to think about what you are doing or saying (dialogue) and if you mess up it might give you an undesirable result. Personally, I enjoy it since I feel like everytime i go anywhere new there is a chance to find some need little tidbit or item that normally would not stand out.Characters- While it is unusual to find an RPG these days that allows the creation of a party (only other one i can think of is might and magic legacy), it provides an opportunity to make characters specialize in different fields. For example, I have a hand to hand bruiser that has meathead skills (break, hard♥♥♥♥♥and mechanical repair (not meathead but the best i could do)). Then another character has sniper computer science and smart♥♥♥♥♥ Another cool aspect is that you can assign characters religion, nationality and even their favorite pack of smokes- who knows maybe there is a little easter egg somewhere if you have a jewish asian etc. Also there are optional companions along the way, which can add 3 more faces (max) to your party.Combat- Being as it is turn base, it takes patience, but at the same time it allows the methodical approach. A lot of people don't like weapon jamming (requires an action similar to a reload), but i like it considering it adds more variability. If you have like Classic Turn-Based combat then you will enjoy this.Loot- I dont like how treasure was dealt with in this game. I find myself normally picking up heaps of junk or 6-7 of the same crappy gun i've been using. It also seems a little odd that there is such an abundance of ammo in an apocalytic wasteland. There are also some hidden items that can be turned into npcs for rewards, so keep an eye out!The World-  The game utilizes a travel mechanic that places the part on a "board" in which they have to travel to different locations all the while you can be attacked by raiders and be mindful of your water supply. As for whether the game is open ended or not, I would say yes to an extent. Even though there are optional side objectives, the path always leads you in the direction of the mission. It is similar to the Mass Effect Series as both have the option for exploration and side missions, but the story missions are required to advance.Overall-Have you played Divinity: Original Sin (check)Have you played Shadowrun Returns (check)Have you played Fallout 2 (check)Did you like any of them (check)Then you will love this (check)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												This game was on Kickstarter and accumulated around 3 million USD from backers. Then why in [insert Deity of choice] green Earth is the game looking like something from the early nineties?After 2.5 years in development and 3 million dollars, I expected a whole lot more than this. The UI is just awful looking. The character models are really poorly detailed. Hell, the entire game is graphically terrible. Where did those 3 million go? Sure as hell wasn't the graphics. Character models don't even display what kind of armour you are wearing. It only shows whatever tattered piece of clothing you are currently wearing. It shows new weapons when you equip them, why not armour?Skills and Attributes are not connected in the same way as they are in Fallout. An example: You can have a 1 Strength character with 10 Brute Force and he or she would be able to bash open anything you can use the skill on, whereas a 10 strength character with 1 Brute Force can't do anything. You would've thought that a maxed out strength would add to Brute Force but it doesn't. Makes no sense. In effect, you can highly specialize your characters and you will still be able to pass all "checks" (smart♥♥♥♥♥ brute force, lockpicking, etc.). Intelligence is the Godmode Stat. Max it out at character creation screen and reduce everything else but the other primary stat you want (conditioning, for example, or Luck). Since the game doesn't check your attributes but only how much you have in certain skills, it doesn't matter if you are running around with 1 charisma or what have you; you can still be the most charming individual on earth. There are still loads of bugs in the game. Nothing gamebreaking but a lot of side quests don't work. NPC's not being where they are supposed to be or you can't talk to them or any other combination.The combat system is also dull and the A.I is cheating. They get a truckload more action points than you do. This is even more prevalent late game. Tactics don't matter, saving action points for an ambush don't matter. It's just whoever has the biggest gun wins. Did I mention that the A.I has an uncanny accuracy with almost every weapon? Yeah, not only do you have to deal with that but also with weapon jamming. All weapons have a certain % chance of jamming. It sits around 2-5%. In truth it is MUCH higher. The weapons jam almost every other combat situation and this is a major source of frustration. Especially if it occurs three-four times in a row. 2-5% indeed...The game is just so very linear. The sidequests are bland and uninspiring, much like the characters themselves. There are no really memorable characters at all in the game. The entire game is just painfully average. It's boring. It's just nothing out of the ordinary. It feels like Fallout, it plays like Fallout but it just misses everything that made Fallout great. Hell, I'd rather be playing Fallout than this.My only concern after playing Wasteland 2 is that Torment: Tides of Numenera is going to go the same way Wasteland did: terrible graphics and terrible combat system with a bland and uninspiring story. I certainly hope not since they've joined forces with a lot of good writers of fantasy (Patrick Rothfuss for one).Final Verdict: Wasteland 2 is a boring, bland game that fails to meet the expectations of many. It plays like Fallout, feels like Fallout but fails to capture anything that made Fallout great. If you want to play Wasteland play Fallout, it's a hell of a lot better.Final Score: 3/10. It's 2014, can we get rid of terrible graphic engines, please? Today's computers and consoles CAN handle the good stuff from, say, CryEngine or UnrealEngine. Stop making half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥games based on outdated engines.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I would love to recommend this game.Unfortunately I cannot. It was advertised as a spiritual successor to Fallout 1 & 2 and sadly it is nowhere near the quality of these games.Given the credentials of the creators of this game, the fundamental issues it has have been a major dissapointment to me.I could look over the simple, passable if shallow combat system in what was supposed to be a crpg, but mostly is a tactical squad shooter.But hopelessly shallow and illogical crpg mechanics I cannot forgive.The attributes are very weak and have very little impact on gameplay, like maximum 10 Coordination gives +10 to hit - about as much as 1-2 ranks in the respective weapon skill. And less then what 1 weapon mod can give you...Speaking about skills, this system is awfully shallow, with no connection between attributes and skills. Yes, your 1 Strenght wimp will be just as good at bashing doors open, as a 10 Strenght champion strongman. Or your 1 Charisma cavemen will talk just as smoothly as your 10 Charisma face. There is a large number of skills, many of which are redundant (medic and surgeon, lockpicking and safe cracking, perception and outdoorsman, to a lesser degree the separate combat skills for each weapon type).Out of the attributes in the end only the derived stats Action Points and Combat Initiative really count. There are no perks/traits/talents.There is actually little incentive to keep levelling after the first 20 levels or so. As the skills check difficulty will invariably rise as the game goes on and only the highest skill ranks are worth anything,  you need to split the skill load between charcters. So on each level you get some more hp and some skill points, which you assign to the same skills you have chosen for each character at the beginning of the game. The levelling process could just as well be automated.Oh and you get a stat point... every 10 levels.There are no range accuracy modifiers, no aiming at and disabling different body parts.Terrible, random loot. What's with the hordes of containers and safes! spread seeingly randomly all over the place? Was it raining safes in Arizona or something? That's beyond silly. Oh and when you finally diffuse that trap and beat that impossible lock guarding that chest/safe, you will certainly feel very rewarded when you find 5 bullets and a glass eye inside. Don't expect valuable stashes of old technology hidden by some bosses/factions/military organizations/research centers, not in this game, no. Only a handfull of bullets for you. Better buy your guns at the local vendor... oh and that power armor too.Actually maybe don't. Armor... suffice to say it's horrible. In the end game it's much safer not to wear any...I would love to change my opinion if the devs can "fix" this game. Unfortunately there is so much wrong with it, that it would be a monumental task. Still, one can hope. It is pretty much my favourite genre and the game has a lot of potential.But that makes its fundamental flaws that much more painfull to me. It was so near, but so many design choices make absolutely no sense....

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Have tried to get into this game now 2-3 times and it's not working for me. Interface with the party members moving together and separate is awkward--especially when arcane puzzles require your characters to be all over like at the early AG center quest (but then they can move together through doors to other areas? How can you separate party members then have them teleport back together when one leaves an adventure map?Combat is awkward on a grid w/o hex. Mobs pretty much cover the entire map in one turn so good luck with a distribution of your melee and ranged characters. Many different skills are great, but it's awkward when you have things like safe requiring either computer skill or safecracking depending on type which must be perceived first followed by counter-intuitive things like using demolition skill to clear traps and such. Most of all really is the poison time limit they place on you in aformentioned Ag center quest. Solve all these arcane puzzles and fight all these awkward battles to avoid your party dying of a time limit disease. There is a reason I enjoy turn based games. I don't need time constraints. Game is just not clean and clear. If you want to add complexity to the game that is fine but you need to clear up your interface first. I LOVED Fallout and XCOM and this just isn't anything like them really. Really disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I'm currently writing this review through gritted teeth and clenched fists and I'm trying hard to stay objective and clear headed.  Firstly I'm list the positive things.The atmosphere of this game is excellent and it truly feels like a real post apocalyptic world.  Immersed in this environment are numerous choices you must make that really do affect different outcomes.  Many games offer multiple conversation lines that lead to the same answer regardless of what you choose (giving the illusion of a more broad conversation) but in this game there was clearly a lot of thought put into the writing.  The replay value of this game is definitely immense.  I've read different reviews on different sites, and some of the weaknesses others have mentioned about this game, I actually see as strengths.  As an old-school gamer and a big fan of deep RPGs, I'm not looking to have things served to me on a plate.  So having to rotate my camera around, to see chests behind trees or whatnot, isn't a hinderance but actually adds to my gaming experience.Also with the large number of skills and their gradual progression, it makes possible something else I really enjoy in video games; which is revisiting old places with higher skills to make new discoveries.  That's why I always have one character with high perception skills.  Some have complained that combat in this game is repetitive.  I don't agree, I enjoy dividing my party and placing snipers at high points and using high AP characters to lead enemies into ambushes.  That's just one of the many tactics I use during combat.  I could go on and on about the positives.  Now here's the negative:I can't play it for more than an hour without a crash.  The game is extremely unstable.  I've tried every workaround mentioned by inXile staff and not a single one has worked.  I did have the Early Access version (which had the same crash problem) but I uninstalled it before I installed the released version.  Nothing works.  Now I'm just waiting for a patch that will fix these crashes before I can play again because it's really ruining the experience.Another annoyance is the right-click move button.  I need to click an area a few times before the party will actually move there.Other than that, the game is great and I highly recommend it.  I only wish these crashes would stop.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												An amazing remake of the classic post-apocalyptic RPG of the same name, Wasteland 2 truly delivers when it comes to content.  Honestly, with all the crowdfunding games that under deliver, WL2 actually caught me by surprise with simply how much many locations and situations there are to discover.  This is a complete and well thought out game. Story wise, there are a lot of choices to be made among the ruins of the old world and the game excels at showing you the consequences of those decisions.  There is a location that became so story rich, I had to actually stop and think about the multi-layers of intrigue before acting on anyone’s request for help because the ramifications affected so many other characters.  (to be fair, this section was so involved that I found my trigger-finger itching for some combat but it was well worth it when it came)I also found the game mechanics deep and leveling characters was very satisfying.  There’s a ton of skills and your characters become focused on specific builds – one will be your safecrack/lockpick/alarm disabler and another might be your expert in assault rifles and demolitions – but I never felt limited when customizing.  What is equally surprising is that all skills come into play at some point and you are never required (mostly) to have a certain skill to progress through the main storyline; you always have options.All in all, a great time.  Be warned: it's a time gobbler.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is an incredibly fun post-apocalyptic RPG. I came into this series with this entry (although I own the first one from a bundle), and although some of the nuances of this world's narrative are lost on me I have little difficulty becoming immersed in the world and its stories.This game has very dense RPG elements to it, and I think that is a very good thing. There are an incredible number of skills that could fall under various traditional RPG roles (tank, rogue, healer, etc), and even within one of those major categories there's plenty of room for variation. I find this a fun aspect of the game, because the four characters (which I created completely from scratch, from their appearance to their skills to their religion and the brand of cigarettes they smoke) can be completely different from each other and are able to support each other well in combat, trading, persuading, and other tasks in which they find themselves.I will definitely work my way through the entire storyline in this game at least once, and it's entirely likely that I'll go through several more times because, with this wide variety of character traits to choose from, I don't see myself playing the game the same way twice.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												I have just finish the game and I have honestly review it.I would recommend it to anyone who likes true RPG (choices that matter, not just character development) and post-apocalitpic mood.(+) The single strongest advantage of the game is giving player many choices, small and large regarding people and communities player run across in the wasteland. Very ofteb there are more that two possible solutions, so everyone should find the one they like the most, it is usually support faction A or B, kill them both, or make peace between them. Sometimes you will have to chose side as peace is not always possible. Such choices are give to the player not only about the very end-game (how most games nowdays deliver), but from the start to the end, from small signel quests to whole communities future.So I often had a chance to ask myself, what do I think that matter? What would I do in such situation? Should I pick side or let them fight each other?Regarding end-game player also has bad and good ending to chose from.Now regarding other stuff.(-) Game is unfortunately poorly made, even after all the patches it still crashes like hell. I had to play in window mode and lowest graphics (apparently my bugs were about graphics).(-) Graphics in general are poor compared to modern game standards, I would even say that they are from the times of Fallout.(-) Combat is this game is not tactical by comparing for example to XCOM. Most often best solution is to engage from as far as possible and wait as close range enemies will charge you so you can shoot them like on firing range. Cover is not well done and AI somehow always find right angle to hit my troops. Line of sight is even worse, very often enemies and my team were shooting through walls, rocks etc that usually blocks like of sight.(-) Equipment is poorly delivered, there are few weapon categories, however few such as Heavy Weapons and Handguns are made useless because there are much better alternatives. Assault Rifles are kings of battlefield. Approach to armor and armor penetration is in favour to armor penetration, so wearing any kind of armor (except the one with value of 10, which slows to down to a crawl) is useless as enemies most likely have enough armor penetration.(+) However developers shown us new approach to energy weapons, instead of competing with ordinary bullets, energy guns deal more damage the higher target armor and minimum damage to low armor.At the end few more good points.(+) Story of the game is well told. It is interesting, engaging, full of choices. There are a lot of dialogs in the game, however not that much to make you tired. Some stuff, solutions, ways to solve problems are a bit hidden or not plain obvious.(+) Regarding end of the story I had my suspicions, but I was never the less plesently suprised by how it all played.I managed to find a computer in the game with Wasteland 3 on it, so I hope that inXile will deliver us the third part of the story in some near future after new Plancescape.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I'm a huge fallout fan, so this game was highly anticipated for me. I tried playing the classic fallout games a few times, but unfortunately their age made the games far too slow and painful to progress through despite their amazing visual style and overall presentation. I picked up Wasteland 2 to fill that experience I always wanted, but unfortunately it just couldn't do it. Overall, the game is very unpolished, and just doesn't have the fit and finish I would expect from a game that's been in development for nearly three years. Incoming gripe-fest: I can't say too much on the story or progression yet, as I'm not too far into it, but I feel like the game keeps you in areas far longer than you should be in. The Ag center quest took me nearly SIX hours in total, and I don't feel like much was accomplished in that time. The quest system is fairly ambiguous as there are no map markers or anything to even send you in the general direction of a task. I've had bugs make me reload a save from nearly hours earlier just for it to happen again(pathfinding is wonky). The lack of lore is another thing that pains me. The game doesn't go too far into what's going on in the world other than forcing DESERT RANGERS! down your throat for the first hour. Scavenging is weird: there are SO MANY obvious loot crates just sitting around for no apparent reason other than to give you ammo- there is so much ammo that it is never a problem in the slightest. And on the off chance you actually find a hidden safe, for the most part it is RNG, so it is likely you will just find .38 ammo over and over again.The game does have its merits though despite being quite janky. There is a LOT to do, and for content-per-dollar, I'd say you get a lot out of it. So if you're looking for a game where there is tons to do and you can play it for hours on end, this is a good choice. However, if you're like me and enjoy games with a higher quality standard, you should steer clear-at least until the game is well patched. The game is definitely a fallout fan's paradise in concept, but it just can't live up to it for so many reasons. I could rant all day, but in the end the only thing that matters is: How big of a Fallout fan are you?

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I was looking forward to this game and I waited until it was released.  I feel sorry for the people that paid 59.95 for something that was then released for 39.95.  I am wondering what on Earth they used all that money for?  It is not the graphics as they are mundane at best even at the highest settings.  The graphic design is amateurish.  Although there are many games that are graphically impressive and the play value is less than satisfying.  Unfortunately this game fails at that as well.  One aspect of the game is it’s supposed to adhere to some kind of reality.  Such as a rifleman being unable to shoot well, if a target is pressing them with a melee weapon or the weapons being old and prone to jams in the middle of combat.  Now one aspect of reality is a human being can see in a 180 degree arc barring any physical problems.  Yet in this game the player has to constantly twist and turn, pan, zoom in an out and mouse over everything in sight so as not to miss anything that is obviously needed to complete the mission goal.  Another sore point for me is the random encounters that occur when traveling on the world map.  Every encounter is on the same one of three possible areas.  Every encounter drops the player at one seemingly random entry point.  The player might reach the enemy in two turns, but the enemy can cross the entire screen and still be able to attack multiple times.   Assuming the player survives, they loot and then get to pan all over the screen looking for the exit point.  There is nothing else in a random encounter aside from the NPCs to be killed.  No random loot, no hidden chests, nothing at all.  So why the busy work to locate and then run to an exit?   And the exit is a Globe of some kind on pedestal.   Forget the boring senseless random encounters, look at the exit point.  Is that Immersion into a game world or what?A word to anyone buying this game if you have small children in the house when you play.  Play with the sound off or use headphones.  I am not prude by any sense of your imagination but this game spews profanity like a drunken sailor on leave at a bordello on the docks.As to difficulty, I can’t put my finger on the problem but boredom comes to mind as well as the old line seen in old adventure games "you can't do that now"  It doesn't actually say that, but that is the feeling the player gets when you examine a trap and it says 98% chance of success and 5% chance of critical fail and your explosives expert fails 3 times in a row and then it blows up in his face.   Now the % to fail or succeed is the game comparing the traps level to the team member’s skill level.Now, like all games all new teams start out at level 1 and as you gain experience you gain levels.  All standard fair, right?  So how come the first NPC team member you can add to your group is a level 15?

												To the point: I would not reccomend this game, at least not in its current iteration. A patch was released a few days ago that fixes numerous bugs, which is always good, but worries of how many are still rampant. Beyond that, 'balance' is a foreign word in this game, with Assault Rifles reigning supreme, Handguns, Bladed and Blunt weapons being a complete joke, and doing more sustained damage by PUNCHING GIANT METAL ROBOTS than using live ammo. If you haven't done research prior to actually playing this game, you won't get very far, with many attributes and skills being virtually useless; this leads to either frustrating gameplay with your characters not possessing the correct skills, or starting from scratch (again and again) until you get it right. Hardcore players aside, most of us just want to jump in without having to worry about using a day calendar to make sure we can electronically unlock and unwire the explosives from a trash bag with...4 shotgun shells. Also, forget upgrading to cool armor like in Fallout and becoming a walking tank: more armor = bad in the Wasteland universe once enemies start using energy weapons. With that rant out of the way, let's focus on the good: Excellent atmosphere, funny characters, and a system, that if you ENJOY in-depth theoretical number-crunching, will last you hours, days, maybe even weeks and months. For most of us, however, that time investment just isn't worth it.Final Verdict: This game is...decent, for a Kickstarter title, but certainly not worth the $40USD pricetag. Find it on sale or get it from somewhere other than Steam to consider a refund if you find it lacking.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Where to start... The game is awesome. I'm an early backer and I've played every beta that has been released, as far through as I can. Many of the bugs/issues noted by previous reviewers just simply aren't there anymore so a lot of the Cons of the reviewers just aren't correct.If you loved the original wasteland and you like turn based combat and actual movement strategy (think X-Com where if you move the wrong position you're toast) and a place where choices have real consequences then you will love this game. If you like all action and no brains then don't get this game. While it isn't a deep cerebral game, you do have to think about the solutions to problems (there are almost always two solutions or more to every problem). The isometric view isn't for some people but for those of us who came from the original world of RPG's it's an old friend that gives you a better view of the battlefield.Some in-depth points. This is a deep story and if you played the original you will appreciate a lot of the subtle humor. The NPC's almost all have a background - you don't though and you don't ever "grow" into a personalilty with a back story. I happen to like this approach where you get to explore your world without worrying about yourself too much. However, almost every path through the story will shape how other people view you and it will either help you accomplish missions or make it much more difficult.Pros: Everything. Basically if I was going to wait for a sequel then I would want it to be this. I don't really have any Cons for this game. Everything is beautiful and well done. It is a very replayable game (I've mapped out about 9 different paths that I want to (or have tried) try. In addition sometimes having certain NPC's with your party allows you to unlock areas or conversation paths that you could not otherwise discover.The team did a great job and I hope to write up a complete walkthrough in addition to the getting started guide which I'll update once the game goes live.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												This game is XCOM meets Fallout. It has the dark humour and post-apocalyptic setting of the Fallout series, with the punishing, perma-death combat of the XCOM series.The graphics aren't amazing, but they're adequate for the game style. The music is atmospheric, the writing is fun, and the voice acting is hit-or-miss.The gameplay is great for people who like this sort of turn-based squad combat. All the usual elements are here: objects in the environment provide cover, hits are percent-based, and actions cost AP to execute, which replenishes each turn.My only real complaint is the navigation on the overworld map, which seems like a cop-out from making an interesting overworld. Whenever you aren't in an encounter area (random encounter, dungeon, town), your party is represented as a marker on a huge map of the American Southwest, which will slowly move toward your destination in the way Indiana Jones travels-- a line drawn on the map.It's fun to create characters, and the combat is challenging but rewarding.Well worth the purchase price.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Wasteland 2, oh Wasteland 2. I had more than a handful of bugs happen to me. I fought with the camera nearly the entire time of my play through. I understand why some people didn't like it. I felt frustration and almost stopped playing more times than I can remember, but boy does this game have charm. I played in Seasoned difficulty, it was painful but I was careless.If you are looking for another Fallout in the traditional form, this comes the closest. There are a few things I wish I knew from the beginning, things the game doesn't explain. The further you go into the game, the more these are revealed, and yet there are even more unexplained things scattered around the wastes. Things I couldn't figure out. Things no one has. I was a cat thrown into a laser disco. In the brief flashes of light between the waves of shadow, you were sure you saw the grin of a dog. Then the shadows come back, and the figures move, and behind all the masks are things moving to the groove of some unheard music. You know there are other cats around somewhere. But the shadows continue to dance, and it looks like one is following a laser though maybe it is not. And you don't know who is who, and what they want, but you know the only way out is through the crowd and the shadows, or you could just follow the lasers. Though in between the lights, and in between the macabre dance, a few beautiful notes licked at the edges of your perception. You could tell something beautiful was around the corner, and you weren't sure where it was going or where you were coming in but you had to find out, you had to let yourself be engulfed in the dance. The Wasteland dance.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												The game starts great - many people find it annoying, but I loved how brutal was the game to a newbie who doesn't know how to optimize the characters. Yes, you are unable to open a lot of locks, and you often can't talk the crooks out of doing bad stuff, but it's more realistic this way, and I never got the feeling I was stuck. It only made me want to play again to see the things I've missed. There are other ways to accomplish a goal even if you think you're too low on resources to do it. Combat feels right even if it's less tactical than, say, Jagged Alliance's, and the scarcity of ammo only adds to the atmosphere.On the other hand, the base story is kinda flat, and the game is slightly buggy and unpolished in some places, but there are still enough details to distract from it, so it didn't bother me most of the time. More problematic is the lack of cues for completing side quests, and it's easy to miss important locations/people, or do things in a wrong order. The end is probably the most disappointing part, as the final battles are quite anticlimatic (the badass scorpion robot on the start screen looks like a plush toy and does about as much damage to well-equipped characters). Still, the rest of the game was enjoyable enough to be worth my time.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Basically this game is a lot of fun and challenge for the most parts. But lacks some content which made Fallout and other similar games the best.Combat:One of the biggest downs is the non avaible sneak mode. Once your spotted (and you will be at a very long range usually)every enemy near the one who spot you will enter combat. That part is okay i guess, because if you get spotted by an enemy human guard IRL i guess he would scream for help and the other would still be coming because of the gunfire.But usually there is huge open areas which are impossible to sneak through without taking a totally different way which anyhow leads up to a combat situation just from an other entry point. So forget about playing sneaky because there are no stealthboys in this game. And also the hit ratio seems messed up (or im just really unlucky).Questing: I have really enjoyed the quest, its no pointing fingers in this game. You just get a general tip of the whereabout of whatever you'r searching for. It's no arrow pointing you exactly to the location to go. Which is really nice. If you do the "right" thing in a questline its a huge chance you end up with better supplies and another follower to your party (which is always nice because combat is unforgiving, if you play on normal or ranger difficulty).Lots of random loot you find will be of interest to various NPC's throughout the world (not the junk items, altho it says in tooltip that you never know who might be interested in a junk item. Still haven't found any use of em)World: Like many others said before me, its too much space with not enough content. And too many preset combat situations when walking on the map from zone to zone. Bugs: With the most recent patch i havent encountered many. Just one where monk suiciders go through stairs and walls.Overall: 6/10 Lots of fun but without enough depth to satisfy you'r RPG experience. Too much sloppy work on character development (like there are only a few of your party members on whom you can customize pants, jacket and hat) Many of them got just preset apperance.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												XCOM was a big favourite for me, so I was looking for similar turn-based tactical games. Wasteland 2 was a disappointment for me, mainly because the combat is very boring to several reasons: - map is not properly designed for the combat, not enough cover (or something which looks like a cover turns out not to be a cover once the game turns into turn-based) in many cases simple open area - enemies have terrible AI, they just keep running towards you, until they are in firing range, then they start shooting someone randomly - melee is useless, most efficient is assault/sniper - no way to properly prepare for a battle, you cannot position your soldiers, because you don't know what is cover, and how the grid layout looks like (that only becomes visible when the game switches to turn-based)So after a while I realized that the most efficient is to use only weapons with long range (sniper/assault/heavy), and being defensive, just wait until they come close enough, and shoot them. Many of the combats was just going into position with the group, crouch everyone, shoot something with the sniper to initiate the battle, then keep shooting the closest enemy with everyone, without moving at all. No tactics, boring like hell. I was really trying to be more offensive, but it doesn't work.Story is OK, but the character progress is boring, you pick a few skills for each character at the beginning, and then just put skill points on those as the character levels up. Lots of the skills are just to open boxes for loot. Graphic could also be better.I played most of the time in offline more, so I played way more than just 0.3 hours.

												In my opinion, this is one of the top 10 crpgs ever made.  It has everything I look for in a crpg - party creation, good chargen and chardev, lots of ways that your skills interact with the environment, good combat, good story, great characters (like the kid that follows you around in the California base, Chisel, etc).9.5/10The only cons for me are -Would have liked 5 or 6 character creation instead of 4Too many and too much leveling that kind of makes the character development less meaningful. Honestly, I did not believe inXile was capable of making a crpg, never mind a rpg I that is in my top 10 (and I've been playing crpgs since the mid-late-80s.  I am really looking forward to the new Bard's Tale from them now too.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I love many things about this game. I dislike very few things.But what is most important is that this game has the wondrous feeling of escapist post-apocalyptic exploration flavor I thought we had lost forever.When Bethesda butchered Fallout III (and although Obsidian salvaged it) -- I had no hope that I would feel the way I did in the late 90s again. I was an impressionable kid, getting owned by floaters and centaurs, unprepared, Sulik bursting like a dumba$$ riddling Vic with holes-- but I loved every moment of it.Wasteland 2 took me to that place once again, especially as you progress through the game, it becomes an old school classic that we were sorely missing in our lives for the past 20 years.This game is an heir to the likes of Baldur's Gate 2, Fallout 1&2 and of course the grandfather of them all, the original Wasteland.Thanks Brian & Co. for the liquifying energy weapon animations. Thanks for the non-linear love this game got. Thanks for all the times you listened to the community and backers. Thanks for sticking to your ideals and not caving in like Bioware at the onslaught of console idiocy. Thanks for Ertan the Satanist.Thanks for returning us 90s kids back to the world intelligent, brutal and immersive cRPG gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Having played the original Wasteland and every Fallout game released, (Yes, even that one for the X-Box. You know the one I'm talking about), I was pretty much expecting a better version of Fallout Tactics with a deeper, richer story line. The result? I little underwhelming, but overall a good experience.Tight, turn-based tactical combat with a rotatable isometric view mean that other than a few oddities that occur with objects that are "between the camera and the view," the control is pretty solid. The game rewards you for good tactics and positioning with every weapon skill having it's pro's and it's cons. You're not penalized for having a diverse team and the biggest problem of simply having a team of grunts with no real other skills is simply that a lot of side missions will be more difficult, if not impossible.The downside... the story feels a little "been there, bought the t-shirt." And not just for a player of wasteland. There really isn't anything in this world that the game presents that genuinely feels original in any way, with the unfortunate majority of the various groups you come across feeling like someone blew the dust off and gave it a new coat of paint. Not a slapdash job though, but a loving restoration with a few embellishments here-and-there. The big disappointment was the final mission/ending. If any part felt like you'd played it before, it was this one. *sigh*Still, an enjoyable game for Hardcore fans of the Post Apocalyptic genre, or relative newcomers. But anyone else may want to give it a miss if retreading familiar ground doesn't catch their fancy.

												Spent first 30 hours defeating first "zone" of the game.Progressed all the way to the next world map.Game breaking bug prevented any kind of progress on arrival in new map.Reloaded game, to an hour prior save, same bug happened.Instead of ragequiting for months untill I had worked up the desire to play again (which is what would normally happen to me in this situation with any other game), I shrugged, and restarted with a new party optimized for a wider variety of skills to the detriment of combat effectiveness, ramped up the diffuculty, and spent another 30 hours conqureing arizona again.Made it to the second world map, bug did not happen, the game became 100 times more fun with challenging enemies, interesting dialogue, and a whole slew of new adventures to have that make Arizona's map look like a friggin ghost town compared with Las Vegas.10/10 would glitch again...

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												OK, I've had it; this game cracks me up.I test all the boundaries, turning over every rock, and the developers and writers have satisfied me every time. I think, "I bet if I go back and check out this area the same dialogue will be present as if nothing happened." WRONG. This team has impressed me every time! And all the mature humor, and little odd-n-ends just make this game even more enjoyable. Like seriously, whats up with the rubber toy? And why on that particular character? These things have been making me laugh out loud too much for what could be a serious wasteland survival game. I really read almost every line of text in this game, and look foward to even the descriptions for junk items. This game is challenging, filled with content, and highly enjoyable. Much recommended.

Sure it's NOT the sequel to Fallout 2 but it's still good :)The good: Apocalyptic scenery, TBT fights, robots and odd enemies. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												To me, Wasteland 2 feels like Fallout and Baldur's gate/Icewind Dale got dumped into a blender, and the result is a great old-school, hardass (true to the Wasteland name, it is a ballbustingly hard game!) RPG. The game looks very good graphically, and the story is, so far, pretty good. Like the original Wasteland, you have a plethora of skills to choose from -- weapon, utilitarian, dialogue, and the selection of weapons is also pretty good, although if you like energy weapons, I'd suggest waiting before taking points in the skill, as it will take a while before finding some. In short: This game is awesome! If you enjoyed the old Fallout games, and any of the Infinity Engine RPGs, this game is a MUST PLAY. inXile has done a stellar job with this one, and I HEARTILY agree with PCWorld saying this is GoTY of 2014 -- it absolutely is!

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Wasteland 2 provides a great RPG experience at a good price. For players of the first Wasteland game, it's a must-buy, and newcomers (particularly those who enjoyed games like Fallout 1&2) will find a lot to love.The character creation system is very nice, and while I fretted over skill and attribute points at first, I found that the game is so huge and there are so many different paths to take that you will find a rewarding, engaging, and different story with each party that you form (and you will likely want to play it through with a different setup at least once).The choices you make can have long lasting impact on gameplay, and for that reason it's one of the few (maybe the only?) that I played through again immediately after finishing.It's funny, entertaining, and well worth the price; to top it off it's a great example of crowdfunding done right.

												 I don't give amazing reviews of games often. But this is a must have game for anybody who likes long games and likes to use their heads. Great challenge and I have found myself wondering how I am going to proceed with limited supplies and such. Also, you can seriously ♥♥♥♥ your game up at the very beginning. Characters get perma-death and if you don't have the characters or resources to proceed, this game can become unbeatable. Be smart!9/10

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Great atmosphere, writing, voice acting and storytelling. Pretty much anything that isn't directly gameplay related is top notch.The gameplay itself is very unpolished and shallow. There's isn't a lot of options/ways for actual strategy in combat, all that you can do is to pretty much try and improve your odds by taking cover or higher ground and then let the diceparty roll its way. Building your characters isn't anything more then gaining numbers/stats.My biggest issue with the game is it's difficulty. I love playing games with "above normal"/hard difficulty so I sticked to the Ranger difficulty which has also been said that it's the recommended one to play, so playing on a lower difficulty was not an option for me and it would have felt rather demotivating.I grinded for a bit on the world map (random encounters, areas) between each (main) mission but I was still constantly struggling. Enemies were pumped with more health then your characters and most of the time they will also do more damage (example: throwing tons of rare/expensive explosives on you).. Oh and they will probably outnumber you as well.. The game turned into a tedious and unhealthy save reloading RNG party.If you are more into lore and storytelling then this is a game for you (preferably on a normal or lower difficulty).If you are looking for a strategic turn based RPG then this game will leave you dissapointed.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Let's start with the bottom line - If you liked Fallout 1/2 - Get this game.Buy it now , stop wasting your time.This game is great.It's an absolute throwback to post apocalyptic games of the 90s-2000s with some modern parts.I say some - because it mainly sticks to mechanics invented in the 90s , not a lot of inovation.That said - the game has very good writing , lot's of player choice and interesting skill trees that evolve nicely.Good thing you start with a party of 4 to be able to divide the skills between your characters - because you'll be totally surprised of how useful some skills are over others.I'm 50 hours into the game and reached the last fight - it's very challenging and I feel I might have reached it too early which is a bit of a bummer.Regarding bugs - the only one that affected me was the 32bit memory issue. this would mean - when using high textures - it will crash when moving into / out of maps constantly.This is especially absurd because it's only for the lack of 64 bit support on mac.I'm playing on a MBPr 15" - which can run this game easily and it crashes all the time.Solution - lower the texture maps one notch.Another bummer is it doesn't really support the Retina resolution , There is no reason for me to play on my native non retina resolution when my screen can easily work on double that resolution / at least at 1080P.Other then those issues - no complaints whatsoever.Looking forward to playing much more.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Wasteland 2 was one of those games that really speaks to older generations of games. There are many good as well as bad design features, but overall it's an enjoyable experience if you're willing to put yourself through it. Upon starting up your first game you create a party of four Rangers and can choose their stats and skills, select character appearance options, and write a quick bio should you so desire. Of course, one of the things that is limited by the standards of old crpgs is that you can't play your character too far off the path of the desert rangers, but still the story is interesting and features a lot of unique ideas that might just get you to crack a smile. Now there is a ton of dialogue and text in this game, but of course that means a lot of conversation options come up time after time. You'll find your self clicking things to get them out of the way, and of course sometimes this can get you into confrontations without any clear indications. Since I like to schmooze my way through many of these it was kind of annoying that there werent more options to use the skills associated with conversation, but at least they were there. The combat mechanics were probably the most fun. I played this game at the second highest difficulty on my first try and didn't have too much trouble. There are some frustrating things, like enemies walking 150 tiles across the map straight up to your characters on the first turn and punching them in the face, but so long as you're prepared you can usually deal with this by lobbing out grenades and rockets. That being said, there are plenty of different weapons to take advantage of and they are all useful and unique in different ways. Some character stats are more useful to combat than others, so it helps a ton to diversify your party because the situations that arise require different skills and weapons. Some enemies are tough to take out with light weapons, but easy targets with energy guns, and vice versa. As a piece of advice you will be binding quick save to the key closest to your keyboard hand, and pressing it often. There are times where it is not always clear what you have to do, and if you do them in the wrong order you can get into situations like endless combat for HOURS before you give up and reload. It's truly unfortunate that unorthodox situations do this to the player, as it feels restricting at times. I remember early in the game trying to expedite a mayoral race, and did as many helpful tasks as I could save for one that I could not find. Turns out the doctor, who said he didn't need any help, actually needec you to use your surgeon skill on his patients... seriously? I spent hours trying to figure this out before looking it up. Another gripe is that you will spend hours just walking across maps, for no purpouse other than you're going back and fourth for quests. There are sometimes ways around this that open up after having done enough to open up a quicker passage, but usually by this point it doesn't even matter anymore. You'll experience this enough to come to hate the experience. You'll be getting out your chair to find something to distract you for three minutes while your party walks around, and sometimes you have no idea if where you're going is going to help your quest. Truly this was the most frustrating aspect of the game. Yet another thing, many characters have the same portraits, even important ones at times. I really wish that they had taken the Baldurs Gate appreach and only gave important characters unique portraits. And the portraits, they look like they were painted by a college student. They werent bad, but felt lacking. Sometimes it made the characters you meet less unique, as they just sort of blend into each other. Now it might seem i'm going off on the negative aspects of the game, but these are things you should know before you start playing. It's by no means perfect, but hightly enjoyable. Comparable to Shadowrun Returns, where as shadowrun had a really focused story and an enjoyable simplicity, Wasteland 2 has a very big and diluted feel with explosive chests falling out of the sky and arguably more interesting combat mechanics and a big world.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												I am happy to say that this was probably the best game I purchased off of STEAM for the entire year. PROS:~Super rich detail in everything.~Maps are huge. ~Ability to create your own 4 person squad from the get go. ~The ability to have a max of seven people in your party! How awesome is that!?~Lots of guns. ~You can set up ambushes/surprise attacks. Also, attacking from higher ground and behind cover equals PWNAGE! I've even had enemies throw grenades at me from low ground only to have them hit something and hit their allies instead. Awesomeness for sure!~Every single skill is usable unless you don't want to. And that simply makes some aspects of the game much harder. CONS: The game is extremely well done, and the only issues I could possibly have with it are not being able to zoom in on the map display, which can make missing parts of maps an easy thing to do, leaving you wandering back and forth until you get frustrated. Then again, I may not have noticed where I was supposed to go. Either way, it's an extremely minor thing, especially when the maps for most places are quite huge, many consisting of other areas you have to travel to in order to search the area fully. The other thing I would have liked is voice acting for everything. But I suppose I am spoiled like many others these days, where pretty much every game out now has voice acting throughout. Overall, two little things that don't deter from my experience whatsoever.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is unfortunately a booring game. Four critical flaws make it so. First, it doesen't really capture the post-apocalyptic feel. The sounds aren't haunting and lonely enough, the people you meet doesen't have character enough, the narrative doesen't emphasise it enough, and the world is more absurd than gritty.Second, the story doesen't grip me. It's bland and seems uninspired, more like a backdrop for laying down lead than anything else. It fails to motivate me, making leveling and shooting the only motivation to keep playing.Thirdly, because the game fails to convey the feel and story of the wasteland, each new area is just a hub for more generic tasks. Exploring in this game just mean finding another safe to crack, another lock to fiddle with and another bandit to shoot. In other words, exprloring is booring.Fourth, the leveling is also booring. The formula is too easy, has too little crunch, too little character and feels kinda pointless. Once you figure out that the only thing that matters from character creation is action points, initiative and skillpoints, you realize that the best party consist  of 4 clones, with some small ajustments to one of them to make sure you have good range of sight. There is almost no correlation between stats and skill, meaning you can pin any skill on any character with the same effect. This is ok if you don't want to make character building a focus, but it also removes character building as a motivation to play on. Further, this game reward not spending your skillpoints until you really need them, which kills the excitement of gaining a new level.In contrast, Fallout 1 and 2 was the opposite in all of the above, and it's what made them shine imo.So I'm halfway into the game. I don't really care about what just happened in Arizona and I don't care about what's gonna happen in California. Why should I keep playing? I don't care about what happens the next level. The story ain't gonna improve. The feel ain't gonna improve. I don't care about shooting my gun just once more or opening just one more lock or disarming just one more trap. I've had my fill of generic tasks, and I'm just boored.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												TL;DR: Decent story, interesting world, mediocre dialogues. Relatively boring battles/gameplay. Decent sound and graphics, but limited customization and very ugly character models.  Would have fared better without the high expectations from the kickstarter. Close to a positive recommendation, but not quite: 5/10.The sequel to the inspiration for Fallout... talk about high expectations. Add to this the fact that it was a super-successful Kickstarter project that promised to put the creative people back in charge of their own projects, and it's easy to see why so many hopes for the future of PC roleplaying rest(ed) on this game. I found it somewhat disappointing in many details small and large, unfortunately. Would I have liked it without the hype? I will never know. Does it matter for this review? No. A game that carries so much baggage needs to be reviewed with it in mind. Story/World: Meh. As so often, it is difficult to say anything without too many spoilers. The world is an... interesting place. Unlike Fallout, it places less emphasis on realism and does not take itself too seriously, allowing for some weird and fascinating factions and places, which are fun to explore. Unfortunately, while there are some gems, the size of the world means that no place has much depth and really catches your heart. Did I feel at home and connected to Ranger Citadel? No. Did I care that a lot of old acquaintances showed up, helped and died in the final battle? No. Did I really care for the epilogues for the places I had visited? No. So: While the game presents a varied and interesting world, it failed to pull me in.Additionally, they sat a bit heavily on the predecessor (old characters, old locations, old stories that are repeated again and again) which I did not play, making it hard for me to get invested.Dialogues were a mixed bag as well. Some good, but also a lot of repetition of the same pieces of information over and over again.The roleplaying came down to a handful of choices (Do I help this person? Which of those two factions do I support?). My characters lacked, unfortunately, a character.The main story is actually very short. Weird robots show up. Now go and fight them. It's nice and consistent, without plot holes, but the ending  not only digs out the Big Bad from part one, but also uses the Terminator reasoning for the nuclear war, which seems lazy. Sound: Nice enough, but could have been more varied.Graphics: I usually don't care too much about graphics, but some things really disturbed me here from the very beginning. Character models are ugly. What's more, there are a very limited number of character portraits, all of which are used as NPC portraits as well, so you quite often have two identically-looking people talking to each other. Finally, the descriptions of characters in the world very often don't match their portrait at all. Takes me out of the story. That said, the maps are done with great care and are quite beautiful.Gameplay: Yeah... that was what almost made me give up on the game in between. There are a few minor things that bugged me (area map is a screenshot, allows no notes, shows no locations), but the big thing is the combat. This is where you spend most of your game. But the combat is pretty damn boring: There is a basic cover mechanic, but many places in which you will find yourself starting battles are devoid of cover at least for your group. Thus, many battles end up being about choosing who to shoot. Throw in some small-ish things like unclear sight lines/weapon ranges especially when the battle goes over two levels and the whole affair becomes less an intricate chess game between you and the (mediocre) AI and more a tedious excercise in mopping up without using too many resources.Then there are the crates. And the safes. And the holes. And the toasters. Everything wants to give you items, which are absolutely necessary in the beginning and absolutely superfluous in the end. But if you're anything like me, you will STILL open the next safe - just in case of the very occasional plot-relevant item. Makes the game go even slower and becomes, at times, an excercise in quick-saving and quick-loading.Finally, while the game throws loads of skills at you, there is no deep character building here. One weapon skill, one auxiliary skill (or three for the skill monkeys) per person, done.In summary, while the game amused me and made me smile at times, it did not make me think and it did not make me care for its world or characters. At least one of those I expect from a roleplaying game. Thus: Not recommended.Addendum: Reading it again, this review sounds exceptionally negative. It wasn't really meant to be; most of the issues I mentioned bothered me, but not as much as in other games. It's just that a lot of things that don't bother me too much add up to make this game pretty mediocre - maybe 5/10.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the early access so I will try to be reasonable with how I feel about the game.The game reminds me so much of Fallout 1 & 2 with support for higher resolution. The graphics are nothing spectacular but it doesnt have to be since the game focuses more on user experience and immersion. Yes immersion! I'm not a big fan of reading especially long dialogs but this game does it well by letting you visualize what's happening in the world via text (type writer) and npc barks. It totally allows you to use your imagination without even realizing it. Yes, there are a bunch of typos that I've noticed which affects my experience personally, but then again it's still on beta. I like the fact that the quest log system does not treat you like a dumb person, unlike Fallout 3 where it shows you on your compass where you need to go. Instead the log gives you details of what you've accomplished so far and what you need to do next. I'm playing the default difficulty (seasoned) which is very challenging and the loot system is well thought of. The scarcity of ammos and health pickups allow you to decide whether you should go back to citadel (home) by travelling which is by the way is very very dangerous, or just keep pursuing hoping that you'll maybe get lucky and find some loot or vendors along the way. There are also a lot of interesting items you may find such as sega genesis console, neogeo, and even a used condom. I think they are irrelevant to the game but it's defnitely entertaining. I probably won't sell them. It would really be awesome if the developers can go even further with it and allow you to give it to a person in citadel to place it in citadel collection room or something, to display your awesome finds.The controls are pretty good, it's could be improved though. But I liked the fact that I can play it with just the mouse, so I don't have to hunch down in front of my keyboard. I can just sit back, relax, with one hand on the mouse. It accomodates old gamer like me who's retired and doesn't have to work and just allow the kid inside me to just enjoy what I've missed when I was growing up working too hard. No more stiff necks and sore elbows. But like I said it can be improved. Also, if I may add, I really like how the cursor system was in fallout 1& 2. I think it's actually one of my favorite and memorable to me that right-clicking changes the cursor behavior to walking or action command. I can't remember if it was double click the walk mode to run but that would be awesome option. instead of holding down shift key.I like that they stayed away from static camera, but sometimes I wish there's an option to turn it back to static camera because the camera can get a little clunky sometimes. When you're tryign to find the travel zone it can get very frustrating, I think the way to solve this is by minimap (starcraft like)  which you can click on an area in the minimap and move the camera to that spot, which is currently not in the game. Speaking of map, I wish they have the option like in fallout 1 & 2 to have some kind of a town map that you recently visited to allow you to just go directly to a certain part of the town instead of walking all the way from the travel zone just to talk to one guy, then walking back all the way again to get out of the town. By the way the first time i took a ride at the crane elevator at highpool i was like, "Oh cool", but after doing that for about 10 times I'm like "Okay...", then I'd noticed one of my party member was left behind so i have to go through the cutscene again just to get my other team mate. I know it probably took some time and even effort for whoever designed this but it get's annoying especially when you're on the go. I'm not sure if there's vehicles in the game that you can ride like in fallout 2, and if there is it'll be awesome if you can customize it to add protection from radiation and and dehydration and allow a faster travel with options to attack random encounters using a higher outdoorsman skill. Also what's up with kick♥♥♥♥♥ smart♥♥♥♥♥ and hard♥♥♥♥♥ I mean, does it really need to have 3 separate skill for each one? I hope they make this into just one skill, I don't know like just Kick♥♥♥♥♥ I'm kinda glad that it's still in beta, which leaves a lot of room for improvements, I just hope that the deveopers are as open as they should be for suggestions and improvements. And I look forward for this awesome game to get even more awesome.Bottom line is I'm totally recommending this game if you can tolerate grotesque, rude languages, violence, drugs, prostitution, and sad reality of the world to come after the apocalipse.I know I've written a lot already, but I will add some more as I progress with the game.Thank you InXile for making this game.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												The game starts great - many people find it annoying, but I loved how brutal was the game to a newbie who doesn't know how to optimize the characters. Yes, you are unable to open a lot of locks, and you often can't talk the crooks out of doing bad stuff, but it's more realistic this way, and I never got the feeling I was stuck. It only made me want to play again to see the things I've missed. There are other ways to accomplish a goal even if you think you're too low on resources to do it. Combat feels right even if it's less tactical than, say, Jagged Alliance's, and the scarcity of ammo only adds to the atmosphere.On the other hand, the base story is kinda flat, and the game is slightly buggy and unpolished in some places, but there are still enough details to distract from it, so it didn't bother me most of the time. More problematic is the lack of cues for completing side quests, and it's easy to miss important locations/people, or do things in a wrong order. The end is probably the most disappointing part, as the final battles are quite anticlimatic (the badass scorpion robot on the start screen looks like a plush toy and does about as much damage to well-equipped characters). Still, the rest of the game was enjoyable enough to be worth my time.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												Basically this game is a lot of fun and challenge for the most parts. But lacks some content which made Fallout and other similar games the best.Combat:One of the biggest downs is the non avaible sneak mode. Once your spotted (and you will be at a very long range usually)every enemy near the one who spot you will enter combat. That part is okay i guess, because if you get spotted by an enemy human guard IRL i guess he would scream for help and the other would still be coming because of the gunfire.But usually there is huge open areas which are impossible to sneak through without taking a totally different way which anyhow leads up to a combat situation just from an other entry point. So forget about playing sneaky because there are no stealthboys in this game. And also the hit ratio seems messed up (or im just really unlucky).Questing: I have really enjoyed the quest, its no pointing fingers in this game. You just get a general tip of the whereabout of whatever you'r searching for. It's no arrow pointing you exactly to the location to go. Which is really nice. If you do the "right" thing in a questline its a huge chance you end up with better supplies and another follower to your party (which is always nice because combat is unforgiving, if you play on normal or ranger difficulty).Lots of random loot you find will be of interest to various NPC's throughout the world (not the junk items, altho it says in tooltip that you never know who might be interested in a junk item. Still haven't found any use of em)World: Like many others said before me, its too much space with not enough content. And too many preset combat situations when walking on the map from zone to zone. Bugs: With the most recent patch i havent encountered many. Just one where monk suiciders go through stairs and walls.Overall: 6/10 Lots of fun but without enough depth to satisfy you'r RPG experience. Too much sloppy work on character development (like there are only a few of your party members on whom you can customize pants, jacket and hat) Many of them got just preset apperance.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												XCOM was a big favourite for me, so I was looking for similar turn-based tactical games. Wasteland 2 was a disappointment for me, mainly because the combat is very boring to several reasons: - map is not properly designed for the combat, not enough cover (or something which looks like a cover turns out not to be a cover once the game turns into turn-based) in many cases simple open area - enemies have terrible AI, they just keep running towards you, until they are in firing range, then they start shooting someone randomly - melee is useless, most efficient is assault/sniper - no way to properly prepare for a battle, you cannot position your soldiers, because you don't know what is cover, and how the grid layout looks like (that only becomes visible when the game switches to turn-based)So after a while I realized that the most efficient is to use only weapons with long range (sniper/assault/heavy), and being defensive, just wait until they come close enough, and shoot them. Many of the combats was just going into position with the group, crouch everyone, shoot something with the sniper to initiate the battle, then keep shooting the closest enemy with everyone, without moving at all. No tactics, boring like hell. I was really trying to be more offensive, but it doesn't work.Story is OK, but the character progress is boring, you pick a few skills for each character at the beginning, and then just put skill points on those as the character levels up. Lots of the skills are just to open boxes for loot. Graphic could also be better.I played most of the time in offline more, so I played way more than just 0.3 hours.
