content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												A fun post-apocolypse RPG.It's very similar to Fallout Tactics, but clearly different.  Maybe not quite as "polished" -- a poor mans fallout.The leveling was fun, skills cost more skill points to level as they increase, and plenty of level ups (my chars were level 45-ish at the end).  Attributes are almost "fixed" as you only get a few level ups of those.  There are a couple dozen skills to choose from.NPCs can join your party from time to time, in which case you take control of the character as if it were yours.  Although they can do their own thing in combat at times, the leadership skill can help keep them inline more.  I think you can have up to 7 characters in your party at once.The story was fairly long.  About half way through I was thinking things were going to quickly wrap up somehow, only to find out there was a lot more to go.There were a few camera bugs which were ocassionally annoying (but infrequent) and some other minor glitches.Overall, a fun game, and something to fill in the Fallout void if you've played through all of those.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a party based RPG set in a post nuclear war USA. The player controls a squad of Desert Rangers, whose mission is to protect civilians and maintain law and order, but now an army of robots want to wipe out Humanity, and its up to the Rangers to stop them. I never played the original Wasteland, but I'm a massive fan of RPGs, and I certainly found alot to enjoy in this game.Combat is turn based on a square grid, with each action such as moving, firing, reloading and healing costing ability points, similar to Xcom or Shadowrun. Its very tactical, and you also have to pay attention to factors like cover, line of sight, weapon range and friendly fire. The maximum party size is seven, four of which are created by the player, and the others have to be recruited as you progress through quests. There is a wide variety of abilities to put points into when levelling up. You can use several different types of guns and melee weapons, but also non-combat skills including lockpicking, safecracking, computer hacking, trap disarming, machinery repair and more. These skills are very useful because many quests can be completed in multiple ways, by finding alternate routes to enter a building or unlocking extra dialogue options.The story is really good and there are lots of interesting characters and groups. From drug gangs to slavers and religious fanatics, there's always somebody more crazy in the next town. Many quests involve a conflict between two or more factions and the player has freedom to choose who to support, but you'll rarely find an obvious "good guys" faction, more often its a case of "which is the lesser evil?". Dialogue is mostly text based, with only the major characters being voiced, but its all well written with lots of dark humour.I didn't encounter any game breaking bugs, but occasionally I thought certain quest progressions could have been better. Like the time I drank from a water well, got infected with a disease, and used a normal inventory item to cure myself. Later I found the town's doctor, who asked me to investigate why the people were getting sick. I didn't have any option to say "dude, its your well". The only way to progress the quest was to travel to another town to find a special microscope so the doctor could check out some samples, and discover what I already knew several hours of gameplay earlier.I also didn't like that inactive companions didn't seem to gain XP. One of my earliest recruits was kind of annoying, constantly complaining about literally everything, so I wanted to ditch him. But every new recruit I found after that was several levels lower, and I didn't want to be weaker in combat, so I was stuck with him.Except for those complaints, Wasteland 2 is a really great game, and I definitely recommend it to RPG fans, although genre newcomers would be better off starting with something less complex. It took me 68 hours to finish and I didn't complete every side quest, which is excellent value for money at full price.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I was hoping for a Fallout2. What we got was... something that tried to be Fallout2 and fell way, way, way short. Part of it is the skill system, part of it is loot distribution, part of it is the linear nature of the story, and map design is also pretty bad. The game can be super easy/trivial on the parts I want to be challenging, and needlessly frustrating on the parts that should be simple. There are no "multiple ways to solve a problem" there is one way, except they don't always tell you what that "right way" is. The game is a decent time-waster. It's not terrible, I certainly put more time into than other games. But I'm not going to remember it in 5 years.  But this really was billed as a 2nd coming of F01/F02 and it's not. It was a let-down, given the promises.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I like the setting, I like story, I like the gameplay, I like the gore, I like the character builder, I like almost everything. But like always there is one big thing what the developers have messed up really bad.There are many Recruitable NPCs who are too squishy concerning their attributes and skills. Some RNPCs (or even everyone?!) don't have the same amount of attributes like your selfmade characters. Why?! I don't know... Furthermore their attributes don't fit to theit skills.And another point... There are still too less RNPCs. Before starting a game, I figured out how I want to play the game. I've read on some community-sites, that you should match your selfmade NPCs with the RNPCs who are waiting for me in the wastelands. With the given RNPCs I am not able to play the game as I want, not so satisfying. There are always some skills missing I'd like to have in my party. For example I'd like to have all three speech kills (Smart♥♥♥♥♥ Kiss♥♥♥♥♥ Hard♥♥♥♥♥ but then I don't have enough skill points to spend on other important skills. I hope there will be a patch who changes it. The combat system could have been much more interesting. It only contains very basic stuff and in most cases the AI isn't very smart. Sometimes enemies are looking for cover but it happens very often that they stand in front of you with no cover. Melee fighters are always rushing to your party, even it is very obvious they won't survive it. Enemies with pistols are also quite stupid. They run to you and try to shoot you, even if you have more guys alive. Riflemen and snipers are smart and take cover and try to get higher positions than you.Anyway, it's a good RPG with many choices and possibilities. I'm playing it currently on Ranger-Difficulty (3rd difficulty of 4) and I must say, it's still pretty fair. Combat is challenging, but you always find enough equipment to patch your guys up.The atmosphere very good, most RNPCs have unique dialogues which are quite funny. All the descriptions you get during the game are also so good. There is very much too read, but it's worth the time to spend with it.So the points which deny a "very good" or "excellent" are:- too less RNPCs- RNPCs with bad attributes and skill which are not matching the given attributes- just basic combat system- "bad" AI (for melle and pistol fighters)Oh, and on ranger difficulty you don't want to miss your outdoorsman-skill. :)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												This is a good game in a lot of ways. It captures the turn based and RPG elements well. Its flaws are many and deep ,though. The characters and dialog tree are fine, but having 3 different skills to effect dialog is excessive and takes away from the game. Hard♥♥♥♥♥seems most valuable. The graphics are not anywhere near modern. If you want to see a good turn based game well implemented, check out any of the new XCom titles. They are turn and squad based but look good too. I guess at the end of the day, I think the developers got lazy and cut corners. Portrait Icons, for example, are recycled throughout the game. So the portrait of the guy you were helping in one town is now the portrait of a guy you are fighting, or even a whole gang. Worse, the portraits often have nothing to do at all with the character. Even seemingly main characters have generic or even mismatched portraits. In a game with a limited graphic demand and limited eye candy appeal, those portraits are important to telling the story. InExile just mailed it in on that and many other things after cashing a huge Kickstarter check, and that really lessens the game. Voice acting is limited and really bad compared to any other title I have played in a while. The voices of Matthias and General Vargas, in particular, are horrible. For its current list price of $40, it is not at all what I expected. Expect to be disappointed in a lot of ways, and frustrated a lot of the time in an otherwise fun game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Short version: this is not a great game. It will not be remembered for years to come as a high point of the genre. It will not spawn remakes and imitators. But it's still good enough, and frankly, if you like your combat turn-based and your texts long and well-enough written, you have no choice this Autiman, but to spend some time playing Wasteland 2.Now, let's dig in to see what went wrong.Character developmentAt first, character development looks good enough. For the first half of the game, you will value every Skill Point you get. Unfortunately, after that it becomes evident that character development is quite limited in Wasteland 2. You can spend Skill Points to get slightly better at hitting enemies. Or opening locks. Or disarming traps. Et cetera. But if you try to make two characters with the same specialization (say, Sniper Rifles), you will develop them in pretty much the same way. There are no ways to make a character unique: no Perks, no Feats, nothing of that sort. Why didn't the developers add such feature to the game, I can't imagine. It's not like it would require expensive voice-acting or even additional 3d models...At the very least, they could have borrowed a page from Shadowrun's rulebook, and give special abilities or bonuses at certain levels of skill. I don't really see a need to give my Sniper 10 in sniper rifles, when all it gets me is a few more percents of To Hit chance!CombatCombat here is turn-based and slightly more varied, that in Fallout 2. This is all good that could be said about it. Lacking abilities, this game offers little in a way of infulening the outcome of combat in dramatic way. This is especially dissapointing after GREAT combat in Divinity: Original Sin.In terms of combat, Wasteland 2 is far behind not only D:OS, but also both Shadowrun and X-Com. This is made worse by strange balance, which allows enemies to mostly negate all your careful placement of characters by running a very long distance in a single turn (this is not a bug: with bug, they had pretty much unlimited running range, now it's just too big).StoryShould you expect a great, thoughtfull story from a game that has Toaster Repair in its list of skills? I guess you shouldn't. But I still was disappointed by a pretty cliche main quest.Another bad mark here is tired trope where heroes take about 15 minutes to solve problems which locals could not solve for years. Negotiate a peace between two warring tribes? A bit of shooting and one dialog. Convince a community to stop ritual cannibalism? Two dialogs! Now, you shouldn't probably make the player feel like they are negotiating for peace in Middle East, but this is borderline insulting.DialoguesDialogues here are all right. Text are well-enough written and I had no wish to skip them.Still, there are to little Skill Checks, and lack of complex trees lead to shallow experience. Compare this to Arcanum's dialogues with Persuasion...WorldPost-apocalyptic games, books and movies are not known for a well-tought-out worlds. They are often seem more like a zoo. "See here, children, this farmers worship an unexploded nuke; and those town took their god from an old folk song!"Wasteland 2 did nothing to change it. Still, some are turned off by what they consider over-the-top sillines, especially in the very beginning of the game, in Ag Center. I, for one, found acceptable, but no engaging, and the rest of the game is the same. This world does not seem alive, I can't feel anything for it, it's just a backdrop for some fighting, questing, looting and trading.SummaryRiotPixels, gave the game 78% out of 100. I think this is exactly the right score for such a game. inXile failed to make a masterpiece, but, well, it's still a good, playable game. You can spend some fine time with it. Just don't place too much hopes in it, so as not to be disappointed. I, for example, do not regret backing it on Kickstarter, and will back other inXile projects in future. I mean, what's the alternative? How much turn-based RPGs are there every year? Two? Three? Another one is good, even if it's not a great one.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												After 50+ hours into the game, it started feeling like doing homework. 69 hours in, I had a blinding flash of the obvious: I was not required to continue playing. How liberating!It had its points. The combat mechanics were kind of fun. The post-nuclear America setting is always a good time. Some of the subplots were clever. The weapon-smithing was very satisfying.But the downsides were inescapable:* Some of your NPCs are fun, but your main characters are pretty much ciphers. Not very engaging.* The skill system is an annoyance. It is less about making interesting tradeoffs than making sure that you have someone maxed out in each of the 4 different "opening things" skills. It is less about looking forward the neat things that you get to do when you go up a level, than that you get to keep pace with the boxes that are inexplicably getting harder to open.* OMG, running back and forth across the map all the time. When I have to have a book sitting next to my computer to occupy myself during your game, there is a problem.* The characters and key items don't stand out well. You're constantly hitting the "highlight all" button, spinning around and trying to see if there is some bit of scenery that you're supposed to be interacting with.* It has an encumbrance mechanic. And if that wasn't enough: for many items it won't be clear when you'll find someone who needs it. So you have the choice of carrying it around all the time, or stowing it, finding the person who needs it, running across the g-- d--- map. Again.If you want an isometric tactical game, play the new xcom. If you want that + engaging plot, grab Shadowrun Dragonfall.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												The game play is fun, characters are well written and the quests are a nice change from the standard fetch, kill or escort.  I had fun playing until I got to Hollywood and the game turned out to be a load of bugs held together with spider's web.While the game engine itself is fine if a bit click-heavy, there are some serious, game-breaking bugs in the quests; you have to use a walkthrough if you hope to complete the game.  The problem stems from quest triggers not firing unless some very specific events take place in the right order: visiting one location before another, talking to NPCs in the wrong order, finding an item before being given the quest to fetch it, these will all break the quest line.  Most quests seem to work or you can reload a save from within the last half hour to remedy the hang up, so all goes well for a time.Unfortunately when you get to Hollywood it all goes down the poo chute.  This is part of the main quest line, you can't just give up and move on when it all goes wrong, which it will.  You either have to keep a huge archive or saves or use a walkthrough if you hope to get through the minefield of broken quest triggers.  I did neither, now I have to start over after 70 hours.  There is also no indication that you're doing it wrong, you have to go exploring to find the quests points and it's so easy to explore just a bit farther than you were meant to.Some parts of the game seem to serve no purpose - water for example.  In Arizona you use up water when you travel.  Ok, nice gimmick to make us choose where to go, how far to roam etc.  But oases are far too common, you will never be in any danger of running low on water.  It's not used at all in LA but you still have it weighing your party down.  There's also no way to drop unwanted/broken quest items, you can only store them in a box at the base.The main thing I didn't like is the constant save-reload of every action multiple times: the chance to pass a skill test shows little correlation with the pass/fail rate - I can fail regularly fail 60% and above chance to succeed, miltiple times in a row, but also regularly succeed in a 10% chance first time.  I get really fed up of repeating this stuff over and over.  It reminds me of the 30 minutes I spent playing Fallout 1 and being unable to kill the very first enemy.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Ah. Where to begin. Story: The basis is that you are a squad of rookie 'Desert Rangers', part of a type of law enforcement agency looking after settlements in post-apocalyptic Nevada. On your first assignment you're sent to find out the cause of death of another Ranger named Ace, which ends up laying the basis for the first half or so of the game. Early on, you're told to go save one of two critical settlements that are in distress. How silly is this? A tiny squad of newbie rangers being sent to secure a settlement on their own. On top of this, if you visit the settlement you didn't choose, you'll find it destroyed-as if the Rangers couldn't send another squad to help protect a MAJOR settlement, but the cherry on top is upon returning to the ranger base, you're greeted by a team of 'elite' rangers that seem to have been sitting with their thumbs up their *** instead of doing their job. Halfway through the game, the plot shifts from "protect the people" to "suddenly robots"Story Summary: 4/10Lackluster and mediocre. Gameplay:The game is very heavily RNG based. Funny then that the developer decided to pick an engine notorious for having issues with its RNG. It's kind of a 'no way, haha' moment when you miss a 90% chance shot the first 5 times, but you could imagine this soon gets tiresome. This is a really nasty thing, as the majority of actions rely on RNG. 60% chance to pick a lock? You're gonna fail and break it too.2% chance for your gun to jam? Better believe it'll jam every second turn. 90% chance to break down a little wooden fence? Broken leg. On top of this, enemies have ridiculous movement speed making any and all tactical positioning irrelevant because they'll close the distance in two turns. Oh, and to rub salt in the wound, all enemies but robots move dreadfully slowly, meaning if there's more than 6 enemies, you'll have to wait a good 2 minutes between turns. You'll be traveling across the map a lot, and there's not fast travel option for locations already discovered. This can get very monotonous very fast. Gameplay summary: 3/10RNG is awful, tactics are useless. Graphics:Not bad. Not the best, but decent, Graphics Summary: 7/10Okay.Audio: Not too many voiced lines, but the ones that are voiced are good quality. Not much music to speak of, mainly ambiance. It can get annoying to hear enemies make the same grunts turn after turn. Audio Summary: 6/10Meh.Overall:Though it can be enjoyable when you get exceptionally lucky, the majority of the time you'll be saving before each attempt at lockpicking, and praying to the RNG gods that they don't smite you when you dare to try to kill something. Overall Summary: 5/10Buyer's remorse.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Phenomenal, just what I had expected and more.After 50 hours I have finally beaten the game and that with skipping some side quests mainly in the second half of the game, Rarely does a game give you so many choices alot of which are tough moral choices that have very real effects on the game, every NPC except on is killable (The commander in Sante Fe), you can play the game in every way you can think of and killing everyone or betraying the rangers are legit options that you can make and they wont stop you from progressing in the game (they will make the game harder though and I am going to start a game where I am going to kill everyone right after I finish writing this) and dont think killing everyone doesnt have benefits, unlike in other games if you kill a marchant all of what he was selling is takeable.Some people claim that the combat is the weak part of the game but I have to disagree, the combat feels great, it can get annoying sometimes with some extremely hard fights and with some enemies being able to run completely insane distances.The story is well writen and there is not a single "bad guy" that fights you because you are evil no one is really bad or good, most of the people in the game are in the grey area, they are all driven by ideology,religion or another motivation and even stories of tiny side quests often have interesting plots and twists.Everything you see is described in a log of sorts in the lower right side of the screen which adds to the over all immersion of the gameNo game comes without flaws though, the game is often buggy mainly in the second half of the game, the game also lacks voice narration and has alot of text which resulted in me skipping alot of text, also alot of times when confronted with a moral question by a so called "bad guy" alot of times it felt to me like I can only say that I agree with him or something that sounds like "What you are doing is injust and we fight injustice" when I actually didn't really play the good guy, I was very much in the grey area, doing things the rangers don't approve of and even lieing to my command after killing civilians and often avoiding the peaceful solution and dealing with problems guns blazing and there was not really a good way to represent the fact that what the bad guy is doing has no benefit to me, at least in my opinion.Over all this is a one of the best games that I have ever played, everything from the atmosphere to the gameplay is awesome.10 Repaired Toasters/10.

												why didn't i buy this game sooner?i've been following this game for a long time but for some reason i didn't get it on day 1 or when it was still in early access and that was a huge mistake.you know when you hear so many good things about a game (like you read different reviews,you watch some gameplay videos,etc,etc.) but still you can't decide if you actually like the game and want to play it or not,you have this feeling that the game is going to disappoint you,i had this feeling about wasteland 2 because i hadn't played a good crpg for a long time,i mean Diablo III was ok and Dragon Age Origins was a mastepiece but i wanted something like classic Fallout series or even Baldur's gate series but i couln't find a game like them.....and today i started playing Wasteland 2,well to be honest it's not quite the same thing as a game like  Fallout 2 But it's great,it's really really great,i mean for the first few hours i was completely blown away by this game because i thought it's gonna be another mediocore game with basic rpg elements but it was completely different from what i thought it's gonna be.this is what a crpg should look like,this is a true classic and this is the true successor of Wasteland one and Fallout 2.i can just keep talking about how much i enjoyed the game,about the different in-game mechanics and about the dialogs but i don't want to do that,i just want everyone wh osi interested in RPGs try this game and see how polished and well-made it is.one of the best games i've played in the recent years........sorry inXile and Obsidian,i willl never doubt your again.another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review by me,thanks for reading and please support these guys,they're among the few Devs who still care about the users and the gaming community.+oh and i've heard so many good things abou Divinity:Original Sin,i don't have the money to buy it tight now but i'm definietly going to buy it in the future.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												This game is simply awesome! Fallout 1&2 are my best games ever and it seems it will be the same with Wasteland 2. It has fascinating story line, wonderfull turn based combat with tactical depth and great character system. It's a true cRPG unlike dozens of FPS with RPG elements out there. It's what true Fallout 3 should be. Story and gameplay are logical, it has intuitive interface (but needs some tweaking - it's beta, right?), nice graphics and wonderfull music made by Mark Morgan - remember City of Dead or Radiation Storm from Fallout? Yes, it's the same guy. Can't wait for the final version. EDIT:After playing the final product it seems this game is much worse than Fallout. There are too many bugs and illogical decisions that make this game very frustrating to play. Some of them weren't present in early access and some others I hoped to be fixed. <Sadly, they weren't.> edit: They're already fixed!EDIT2:After playing director's cut version I have to correct my previous edit. This game is AWESOME! Annoying things like too short sniper rifle range and too big walking distance of enemies were fixed. Furthermore, I discovered this game is non linear. And I mean really non linear. There's so many different things that can happen. It really has the Fallout spirit and I know what I'm talking about. I'm close to finish Fallout 2 for 20 time maybe, so it's not nostalgia that influences my opinion. Wasteland 2 is simply wonderful.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I'm a huge fallout fan, so this game was highly anticipated for me. I tried playing the classic fallout games a few times, but unfortunately their age made the games far too slow and painful to progress through despite their amazing visual style and overall presentation. I picked up Wasteland 2 to fill that experience I always wanted, but unfortunately it just couldn't do it. Overall, the game is very unpolished, and just doesn't have the fit and finish I would expect from a game that's been in development for nearly three years. Incoming gripe-fest: I can't say too much on the story or progression yet, as I'm not too far into it, but I feel like the game keeps you in areas far longer than you should be in. The Ag center quest took me nearly SIX hours in total, and I don't feel like much was accomplished in that time. The quest system is fairly ambiguous as there are no map markers or anything to even send you in the general direction of a task. I've had bugs make me reload a save from nearly hours earlier just for it to happen again(pathfinding is wonky). The lack of lore is another thing that pains me. The game doesn't go too far into what's going on in the world other than forcing DESERT RANGERS! down your throat for the first hour. Scavenging is weird: there are SO MANY obvious loot crates just sitting around for no apparent reason other than to give you ammo- there is so much ammo that it is never a problem in the slightest. And on the off chance you actually find a hidden safe, for the most part it is RNG, so it is likely you will just find .38 ammo over and over again.The game does have its merits though despite being quite janky. There is a LOT to do, and for content-per-dollar, I'd say you get a lot out of it. So if you're looking for a game where there is tons to do and you can play it for hours on end, this is a good choice. However, if you're like me and enjoy games with a higher quality standard, you should steer clear-at least until the game is well patched. The game is definitely a fallout fan's paradise in concept, but it just can't live up to it for so many reasons. I could rant all day, but in the end the only thing that matters is: How big of a Fallout fan are you?

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I was looking forward to this game and I waited until it was released.  I feel sorry for the people that paid 59.95 for something that was then released for 39.95.  I am wondering what on Earth they used all that money for?  It is not the graphics as they are mundane at best even at the highest settings.  The graphic design is amateurish.  Although there are many games that are graphically impressive and the play value is less than satisfying.  Unfortunately this game fails at that as well.  One aspect of the game is it’s supposed to adhere to some kind of reality.  Such as a rifleman being unable to shoot well, if a target is pressing them with a melee weapon or the weapons being old and prone to jams in the middle of combat.  Now one aspect of reality is a human being can see in a 180 degree arc barring any physical problems.  Yet in this game the player has to constantly twist and turn, pan, zoom in an out and mouse over everything in sight so as not to miss anything that is obviously needed to complete the mission goal.  Another sore point for me is the random encounters that occur when traveling on the world map.  Every encounter is on the same one of three possible areas.  Every encounter drops the player at one seemingly random entry point.  The player might reach the enemy in two turns, but the enemy can cross the entire screen and still be able to attack multiple times.   Assuming the player survives, they loot and then get to pan all over the screen looking for the exit point.  There is nothing else in a random encounter aside from the NPCs to be killed.  No random loot, no hidden chests, nothing at all.  So why the busy work to locate and then run to an exit?   And the exit is a Globe of some kind on pedestal.   Forget the boring senseless random encounters, look at the exit point.  Is that Immersion into a game world or what?A word to anyone buying this game if you have small children in the house when you play.  Play with the sound off or use headphones.  I am not prude by any sense of your imagination but this game spews profanity like a drunken sailor on leave at a bordello on the docks.As to difficulty, I can’t put my finger on the problem but boredom comes to mind as well as the old line seen in old adventure games "you can't do that now"  It doesn't actually say that, but that is the feeling the player gets when you examine a trap and it says 98% chance of success and 5% chance of critical fail and your explosives expert fails 3 times in a row and then it blows up in his face.   Now the % to fail or succeed is the game comparing the traps level to the team member’s skill level.Now, like all games all new teams start out at level 1 and as you gain experience you gain levels.  All standard fair, right?  So how come the first NPC team member you can add to your group is a level 15?

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												To the point: I would not reccomend this game, at least not in its current iteration. A patch was released a few days ago that fixes numerous bugs, which is always good, but worries of how many are still rampant. Beyond that, 'balance' is a foreign word in this game, with Assault Rifles reigning supreme, Handguns, Bladed and Blunt weapons being a complete joke, and doing more sustained damage by PUNCHING GIANT METAL ROBOTS than using live ammo. If you haven't done research prior to actually playing this game, you won't get very far, with many attributes and skills being virtually useless; this leads to either frustrating gameplay with your characters not possessing the correct skills, or starting from scratch (again and again) until you get it right. Hardcore players aside, most of us just want to jump in without having to worry about using a day calendar to make sure we can electronically unlock and unwire the explosives from a trash bag with...4 shotgun shells. Also, forget upgrading to cool armor like in Fallout and becoming a walking tank: more armor = bad in the Wasteland universe once enemies start using energy weapons. With that rant out of the way, let's focus on the good: Excellent atmosphere, funny characters, and a system, that if you ENJOY in-depth theoretical number-crunching, will last you hours, days, maybe even weeks and months. For most of us, however, that time investment just isn't worth it.Final Verdict: This game is...decent, for a Kickstarter title, but certainly not worth the $40USD pricetag. Find it on sale or get it from somewhere other than Steam to consider a refund if you find it lacking.

												Just finished a full playthrough of this game (med. difficulty). For the most part I really enjoyed this game and it does have a medium-high replay value as I really want to try different options in several quests. Now I'm done here are some high and low points.+ Fully customizeable characters (4) and followers (up to 3)+ Good assortment of weapons+ Variaty of weapon classes+ Lots of skills to master+ Rewarding challenges requreing some thought to strategy+ Freedom to explore region inbetween missions.- No apparent way to use weaponsmithing to make your own ammo- Extremely disapointing ending (buggy?)- Absurd pricing and scarcity of avaliable ammo- Some weapon specs dont make since (some higher tier weapon are actually weaker?)- In game characters (including yours!) seem very low resolution relitive to enviroment textures. (played native res of 2560x1440)- Not open ended completeing the storyline missions ends the game.I cant seem to figure out what is up with the ending. After winning the finnal battle General Vargus says to detonate the nuke. There is not nuke in the basment of the Citadel and the elevator does not work to return to the upper level. I tried reloading the game and it doesn't even reload to the area my characters are, it reloads outside the citadel. Really strange. I wonder if the latest patch (patch 5) just downloaded a couple days ago broke something?Obviously there are still some issues wtih this game and it does need some polishing/tunning/balencing done it. It really is a great game that I have had many fun hours playing. I do plan on playing through once more and I will be implimenting some mods I have downloaded from the nexus in an effort to do some tunning myself. I really hope InExile is able to fix the broken ending so you can actually set off the nuke and "save the world" through your self-destruction. Whatever... I guess its either a win/lose or lose/lose ending, your choice.Disappointing...

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												The game doesn't have any major glitches or problems. It just has forgettable characters, a storyline that fails to hook the player in (I never cared about who I was saving or why), and a rudimentary combat system (you tell your guys to point and shoot and that's about it [assuming they have ammo, which is sparse - something a person find appropriate in a post-apocalyptic wasteland, but it's only appropriate if the melee mechanics balance with the ranged mechanics]). But my biggest gripes are with the journal system and "the chance to fail."Journal system - if an NPC gives the location to something important, I want it saved in a journal, along with relevant information. This isn't the 90's and I don't want to have to carry a pen and paper just to understand what I am doing and why. It's also difficult to keep track of who is who and why they matter without a reference - at least for myself. Chances to fail - I don't mind failing in games. The problem is when I "critically fail" at opening a door (a door that MUST be bypassed to continue the game) and then wander around the complex, going through all the adjoining branches of the dungeon for two hours, only to discover that I'll have to reload a save from two hours before in an attempt to bypass the door I jammed shut. My time is very valuable to me and I don't have enough of it to waste my time by restarting from such an early save. I'm not a fan of roguelikes for this reason, and the fact the game put me through this has completely put me off of it. I might try it again months or even years from now. But I am totally disappointed at this point. The fact everything else about the game is simply "good" or "ok" but not "great" doesn't help (in otherwords, it's not worth the frustration).Bonus complaint: apparently EVERYONE in the wastes has explosives... and uses those explosives to booby trap EVERY FREAKING DOOR! My number 1 use of med packs isn't during or following combat - it's healing from traps - traps that remain invisible despite high perception skills and the ability to disarm them.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												This is definitely an old style game, meant mostly for people who loved the first Wasteland, the first two Fallout games, and  generally people that played computer videogames in the 90s. It does seem to try and trade off aesthetic quality for some kind of nostalgia feeling that in a way condones how the game looks and moves on the screen, and how some aspects not only seem rough and unpolished but even not finished.Those that think they're gonna buy an RPG with this game might be let down to find out that this game feels and plays more like a Desperados game than an actual RPG, except the tactical aspect is shallow waters, and moves like crouch and headshot are practically never used: you end up doing a little more than spamming attack on the enemies. There are stats(which, oddly enough, do not affect your skills, so how much charisma you have counts nothing on how good a barter you are or how well you can persuade, and so on), dialogues and choices but the game ends up boiling down to a turn-based shooter, where non combat skills and attributes don't count as much as how many points you have put in your shooting skills.Too many times i felt that a certain situation should have hadthe possibility of being dealt with with wits and a good dialogue, since dialogue based skills are there for the characters, and not just circumstantial fights. You can SOME times select a Hard♥♥♥♥♥Kiss♥♥♥♥♥Smart♥♥♥♥♥answer that will gain you some advantage, but it simply isn't worth spending skill points on three separate things you will be using so rarely along the game. It often feels like those alternative options were not YET implemented, because of time and resources, and not just not meant to be there at all, but that is just a feeling. Which makes some situations kinda awkward to play.. It also needs to be stated that the game needs 21GB of free space on the hard disk, and patches come at sizes of more than 1 GB, which is kinda hard to explain for a game of this nature, since there aren't many cinematics at all and a lot of the dialogues are text-only.In the end, though, the game is ok and even fun to play, especially for those that are feeling nostalgic. It just seems to rely on the nostalgia a bit too relentlessly.

I can lock pick it...or..spartan kick that ♥♥♥♥♥ in....or....use lots and lots of explosives....MacGruber would of wanted it that way.If they see screaming goats on the internet, it goes in the game.  It just goes to show the amount of passion and joy they put into this game.I highly recommend if you love this style of gameplay!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Brian Fargo really re-creates the late 90's magic here with the sequal to the original Wasteland. Most will know Brian ran Interplay studios which created and produced the Fallout 1, 2 and Tactics games. Such a shame it was sold...This feels so much like Fallout 1 and 2. The big differences being you are managing a party of up to 6 or 7 characters not just the one. Combat is far more frequent (a little repetitive) but the game has that same post apocolyptic feel with great writing, dark humour, sarcasm and just general wittyness that I remember from Fallout 1 and 2. I feel a little sad that I missed the original Wasteland, I should really get that going somehow and play it too.I have about 19hrs or so in Wasteland 2 and am only up to Dimonta (a place you must visit as a part of several different quests including the main). Now I know a little about what's to come as I've read teasers here and there (without spoiling the story for myself) and because of this I know that this game is huge. Just monstrous really. I think what makes it so big is the fact that there are loads of side quests that really draw the game out and the fact that there is a lot of back tracking sometimes in order to beef up, resupply and then carry on. But regardless of this I find it a treat finding all sorts of new weapons and modifying them to get that awesome assualt rifle bypassing armour by 10-15% with a few mods. I also love all the 80's and 90's pop culture references in there such as Cabbage Patch dolls, MAD magazines, D20 dice, trolls and many more. Those little items you stumble accross gives you a strong sense of nostalgia especially so if you grew up in those periods. I think there a real treat. I won't even go into the "toy snake" you find ha ha.The Director's Cut is definitely where it's at. Heaps more recorded dialog and just general performance increases and polish. I wouldn't bother playing the original Wasteland 2 and I don't think you can anymore? The game is also fairly stable with one wierd CTD (nothing in my event logs either) out of that 20 hours. It runs well and for the most part looks ok. I feel like some areas are a little bland and could have used a going over but aside from that the world looks good.Some areas feel a little empty. I know it's post apocolyptic but some more NPC's to engage with would be nice. The writing really shines when you do talk to those few NPC's that can talk. Overall the main quest story hasn't kicked in a whole lot just yet so I can't comment on it.Anyways it's not a perfect game and this is proven in the repetitive combat. There is some advantage to finding cover and ensuring your perks and skills line up to how you want your characters to operate but it's always the same. Battle starts and you find cover and then off you go until the enemy is dead. The AI enemies are good at taking cover and trying to flank but once you've seen it a few times I think you can say you've seen it all. I've heard that there are boss fights but I am yet to reach one so I can't comment on that either.Despite these flaws, the game isn't too bad. Give it a try if you love Brian Fargo, Interplay and the original Wasteland and Fallout series. I think you'd like it. I give it a 8 out of 10 overall.TLDR: Good writing, a little empty with repetitive combat but reeks of pop cultural references from the 80's and 90's that will have you thinking back to those times. Overall not a bad game but not perfect either.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Have tried to get into this game now 2-3 times and it's not working for me. Interface with the party members moving together and separate is awkward--especially when arcane puzzles require your characters to be all over like at the early AG center quest (but then they can move together through doors to other areas? How can you separate party members then have them teleport back together when one leaves an adventure map?Combat is awkward on a grid w/o hex. Mobs pretty much cover the entire map in one turn so good luck with a distribution of your melee and ranged characters. Many different skills are great, but it's awkward when you have things like safe requiring either computer skill or safecracking depending on type which must be perceived first followed by counter-intuitive things like using demolition skill to clear traps and such. Most of all really is the poison time limit they place on you in aformentioned Ag center quest. Solve all these arcane puzzles and fight all these awkward battles to avoid your party dying of a time limit disease. There is a reason I enjoy turn based games. I don't need time constraints. Game is just not clean and clear. If you want to add complexity to the game that is fine but you need to clear up your interface first. I LOVED Fallout and XCOM and this just isn't anything like them really. Really disappointed.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												So, I've 42 hours on the clock and am only half way through this game (starting off to california right now). What should I say about this game? Well, I'm 31 years old and this is (PC) gaming like I was used to back in the 90s.- No dumb "?" above questgivers- a party which you can create by your own imagination... with the chance to really f*ck up- really interesting world with (comic like) brutality, irony and funny references to especially gaming and apocalyptic movies at nearly every point of the maps- as of now, not the best story in the world, but it fits- sometimes really hard battles (playing on the third of four difficulties)- a few minor bugs, but no showstoppers so far- tons of sidequests and decission to make which actually matter- endless amount of flavor text which is really nice to read, but not necessary for completing the game- unfortunately very rare interaction between party members - some of the larger maps could be disorientating due to size and lack of a useful mapTo sum it up. If you like older RPGs like the Baldurs Gates, Fallout 1 and 2, Arcanum or even the oringinal Wasteland, GO GET IT, DONT WAIT FOR ANY SALE! The developers really delivered what they promised and they deserve their money! Hopefully we'll get a good Addon or even Wasteland 3! For me this is the first true sucessor to Fallout 2!Thumbs up!

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												You have already read the reviews of others and the positive ones are correct about the game. Although I would like to inform you of a few caveats.The game difficulty is well balanced at the normal suggested difficulty setting but starts to break while it is increased. Unlike Fallout Tactics, as the difficulty in Wasteland 2 increases the only change is quantitative. Your aim probability decreases, enemies do more damage etc. but the AI remains the same. Beating a battle set piece doesn't make you feel like you played well it mearly feels like you got lucky over and over again.One last pet peeve. The issue here is the half turn discrepancy between setting up your squad before combat and the first turn of combat. Since you can see battle coming you are able to plan ahead for it by setting squad order but the second battle starts all of your squad move just a little out of place and destroy all chance of strategic combat.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Played 31 hours in 3 days. 10 hours in to first play through decided I didnt like my setup Main menu'ed and New game.  The Game is amazing the Character creation can take an hour or more trying to fit all the skills your want in to 4 characters you quickly learn you cant have what you want, time to pick what you think you'll need.  While I see alot of comparing it to Fallout 1&2 no one mentions how close the game is to Fallout tactics the combat is almost a clone.  Fallout tactics was also a squad based game with the same Map system for travel.All in all I love the game, Best $40 I have spent this year the replay value is high and it makes me feel like I was a teen again, Playing Fallout on a computer that could barely run doom. ( Edit ) Having Completed the game I feel I should fill out the reveiw Some more.  First The Battle system does get a little bit boring shall I say? but its to be expected in a battle System of Turn Based and Guns in the end you know what is going to happen you'll hit that wall for every shot hits. The AI does tend to simply Rush at you rather than use cover but again to be expected from this type of game ( Fallouts where all the same )  But the story and the choices you make unlike normal RPG they carry a certain weight too them which after the first one or two you make and you realise this you start to question your actions, what to say to the NPC's what the out come might be and how to push it the way you want.  All in All I loved the game it felt Fleshed out and complete to me, I did not see any of the bugs the others have added to their reviews infact the only issue I did was that the Camera locked at one point and I had to Alt + Tab to fix it.  I will Play again, many times. I feel that if you want a game where choices do matter and who you Shoot changes the game this is the game for you.  I look forward to some DLC too. 10/10

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												This is a good game in a lot of ways. It captures the turn based and RPG elements well. Its flaws are many and deep ,though. The characters and dialog tree are fine, but having 3 different skills to effect dialog is excessive and takes away from the game. Hard♥♥♥♥♥seems most valuable. The graphics are not anywhere near modern. If you want to see a good turn based game well implemented, check out any of the new XCom titles. They are turn and squad based but look good too. I guess at the end of the day, I think the developers got lazy and cut corners. Portrait Icons, for example, are recycled throughout the game. So the portrait of the guy you were helping in one town is now the portrait of a guy you are fighting, or even a whole gang. Worse, the portraits often have nothing to do at all with the character. Even seemingly main characters have generic or even mismatched portraits. In a game with a limited graphic demand and limited eye candy appeal, those portraits are important to telling the story. InExile just mailed it in on that and many other things after cashing a huge Kickstarter check, and that really lessens the game. Voice acting is limited and really bad compared to any other title I have played in a while. The voices of Matthias and General Vargas, in particular, are horrible. For its current list price of $40, it is not at all what I expected. Expect to be disappointed in a lot of ways, and frustrated a lot of the time in an otherwise fun game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Short version: this is not a great game. It will not be remembered for years to come as a high point of the genre. It will not spawn remakes and imitators. But it's still good enough, and frankly, if you like your combat turn-based and your texts long and well-enough written, you have no choice this Autiman, but to spend some time playing Wasteland 2.Now, let's dig in to see what went wrong.Character developmentAt first, character development looks good enough. For the first half of the game, you will value every Skill Point you get. Unfortunately, after that it becomes evident that character development is quite limited in Wasteland 2. You can spend Skill Points to get slightly better at hitting enemies. Or opening locks. Or disarming traps. Et cetera. But if you try to make two characters with the same specialization (say, Sniper Rifles), you will develop them in pretty much the same way. There are no ways to make a character unique: no Perks, no Feats, nothing of that sort. Why didn't the developers add such feature to the game, I can't imagine. It's not like it would require expensive voice-acting or even additional 3d models...At the very least, they could have borrowed a page from Shadowrun's rulebook, and give special abilities or bonuses at certain levels of skill. I don't really see a need to give my Sniper 10 in sniper rifles, when all it gets me is a few more percents of To Hit chance!CombatCombat here is turn-based and slightly more varied, that in Fallout 2. This is all good that could be said about it. Lacking abilities, this game offers little in a way of infulening the outcome of combat in dramatic way. This is especially dissapointing after GREAT combat in Divinity: Original Sin.In terms of combat, Wasteland 2 is far behind not only D:OS, but also both Shadowrun and X-Com. This is made worse by strange balance, which allows enemies to mostly negate all your careful placement of characters by running a very long distance in a single turn (this is not a bug: with bug, they had pretty much unlimited running range, now it's just too big).StoryShould you expect a great, thoughtfull story from a game that has Toaster Repair in its list of skills? I guess you shouldn't. But I still was disappointed by a pretty cliche main quest.Another bad mark here is tired trope where heroes take about 15 minutes to solve problems which locals could not solve for years. Negotiate a peace between two warring tribes? A bit of shooting and one dialog. Convince a community to stop ritual cannibalism? Two dialogs! Now, you shouldn't probably make the player feel like they are negotiating for peace in Middle East, but this is borderline insulting.DialoguesDialogues here are all right. Text are well-enough written and I had no wish to skip them.Still, there are to little Skill Checks, and lack of complex trees lead to shallow experience. Compare this to Arcanum's dialogues with Persuasion...WorldPost-apocalyptic games, books and movies are not known for a well-tought-out worlds. They are often seem more like a zoo. "See here, children, this farmers worship an unexploded nuke; and those town took their god from an old folk song!"Wasteland 2 did nothing to change it. Still, some are turned off by what they consider over-the-top sillines, especially in the very beginning of the game, in Ag Center. I, for one, found acceptable, but no engaging, and the rest of the game is the same. This world does not seem alive, I can't feel anything for it, it's just a backdrop for some fighting, questing, looting and trading.SummaryRiotPixels, gave the game 78% out of 100. I think this is exactly the right score for such a game. inXile failed to make a masterpiece, but, well, it's still a good, playable game. You can spend some fine time with it. Just don't place too much hopes in it, so as not to be disappointed. I, for example, do not regret backing it on Kickstarter, and will back other inXile projects in future. I mean, what's the alternative? How much turn-based RPGs are there every year? Two? Three? Another one is good, even if it's not a great one.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												After 50+ hours into the game, it started feeling like doing homework. 69 hours in, I had a blinding flash of the obvious: I was not required to continue playing. How liberating!It had its points. The combat mechanics were kind of fun. The post-nuclear America setting is always a good time. Some of the subplots were clever. The weapon-smithing was very satisfying.But the downsides were inescapable:* Some of your NPCs are fun, but your main characters are pretty much ciphers. Not very engaging.* The skill system is an annoyance. It is less about making interesting tradeoffs than making sure that you have someone maxed out in each of the 4 different "opening things" skills. It is less about looking forward the neat things that you get to do when you go up a level, than that you get to keep pace with the boxes that are inexplicably getting harder to open.* OMG, running back and forth across the map all the time. When I have to have a book sitting next to my computer to occupy myself during your game, there is a problem.* The characters and key items don't stand out well. You're constantly hitting the "highlight all" button, spinning around and trying to see if there is some bit of scenery that you're supposed to be interacting with.* It has an encumbrance mechanic. And if that wasn't enough: for many items it won't be clear when you'll find someone who needs it. So you have the choice of carrying it around all the time, or stowing it, finding the person who needs it, running across the g-- d--- map. Again.If you want an isometric tactical game, play the new xcom. If you want that + engaging plot, grab Shadowrun Dragonfall.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												The game play is fun, characters are well written and the quests are a nice change from the standard fetch, kill or escort.  I had fun playing until I got to Hollywood and the game turned out to be a load of bugs held together with spider's web.While the game engine itself is fine if a bit click-heavy, there are some serious, game-breaking bugs in the quests; you have to use a walkthrough if you hope to complete the game.  The problem stems from quest triggers not firing unless some very specific events take place in the right order: visiting one location before another, talking to NPCs in the wrong order, finding an item before being given the quest to fetch it, these will all break the quest line.  Most quests seem to work or you can reload a save from within the last half hour to remedy the hang up, so all goes well for a time.Unfortunately when you get to Hollywood it all goes down the poo chute.  This is part of the main quest line, you can't just give up and move on when it all goes wrong, which it will.  You either have to keep a huge archive or saves or use a walkthrough if you hope to get through the minefield of broken quest triggers.  I did neither, now I have to start over after 70 hours.  There is also no indication that you're doing it wrong, you have to go exploring to find the quests points and it's so easy to explore just a bit farther than you were meant to.Some parts of the game seem to serve no purpose - water for example.  In Arizona you use up water when you travel.  Ok, nice gimmick to make us choose where to go, how far to roam etc.  But oases are far too common, you will never be in any danger of running low on water.  It's not used at all in LA but you still have it weighing your party down.  There's also no way to drop unwanted/broken quest items, you can only store them in a box at the base.The main thing I didn't like is the constant save-reload of every action multiple times: the chance to pass a skill test shows little correlation with the pass/fail rate - I can fail regularly fail 60% and above chance to succeed, miltiple times in a row, but also regularly succeed in a 10% chance first time.  I get really fed up of repeating this stuff over and over.  It reminds me of the 30 minutes I spent playing Fallout 1 and being unable to kill the very first enemy.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Great atmosphere, writing, voice acting and storytelling. Pretty much anything that isn't directly gameplay related is top notch.The gameplay itself is very unpolished and shallow. There's isn't a lot of options/ways for actual strategy in combat, all that you can do is to pretty much try and improve your odds by taking cover or higher ground and then let the diceparty roll its way. Building your characters isn't anything more then gaining numbers/stats.My biggest issue with the game is it's difficulty. I love playing games with "above normal"/hard difficulty so I sticked to the Ranger difficulty which has also been said that it's the recommended one to play, so playing on a lower difficulty was not an option for me and it would have felt rather demotivating.I grinded for a bit on the world map (random encounters, areas) between each (main) mission but I was still constantly struggling. Enemies were pumped with more health then your characters and most of the time they will also do more damage (example: throwing tons of rare/expensive explosives on you).. Oh and they will probably outnumber you as well.. The game turned into a tedious and unhealthy save reloading RNG party.If you are more into lore and storytelling then this is a game for you (preferably on a normal or lower difficulty).If you are looking for a strategic turn based RPG then this game will leave you dissapointed.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												How could a game with this much effort and thought and love put into it still kind of suck? I've been eagerly watching the development of this game for quite a while now. Upon finally playing it, I am sad to report that it is far inferior to any of the recent (or classic) Fallout games. Just like Wasteland 1. They can't quite seem to hit on a winning formula.You command a squad of desert rangers as they try to stop Very Bad Things from happening, mostly by killing all kinds of things in turn-based combat. Your rangers have absolutely no personality, and are combat units with a portrait. You can recruit other wastelanders to you cause, and they do have personalities, but for some reason the developers made the recruitable characters absolutely awful in terms of statistics. Managing your team of fighters is a chore instead of a joy. The interface is awkward and clunky, with strangely reversed controls. Typically, left click is "go there" and right click is "use/take/kill that", but this is reversed in Wasteland 2 with no option to change it.It all comes down to a statistical analysis of the utility of various statistics and skills, with a larger dose of probability-based gameplay. It reminds me of business school, and is just about as fun. I literally had to make an Excel spreadsheet to keep track of who was going to learn which skills. The developers of Wasteland may have been groundbreaking and inspired the Fallout series... but they've pretty clearly shown why Fallout was a cult classic and Wasteland was quickly forgotten.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Wasteland 2 provides a great RPG experience at a good price. For players of the first Wasteland game, it's a must-buy, and newcomers (particularly those who enjoyed games like Fallout 1&2) will find a lot to love.The character creation system is very nice, and while I fretted over skill and attribute points at first, I found that the game is so huge and there are so many different paths to take that you will find a rewarding, engaging, and different story with each party that you form (and you will likely want to play it through with a different setup at least once).The choices you make can have long lasting impact on gameplay, and for that reason it's one of the few (maybe the only?) that I played through again immediately after finishing.It's funny, entertaining, and well worth the price; to top it off it's a great example of crowdfunding done right.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a good game, but overall fell short of my expectations. The funny thing is that the mediocrity of Wasteland 2 reminded me how great Fallout New Vegas was and I finally finished my walkthrough of that game, rather than continuing with Wasteland 2. Both games attempt the same thing in so many ways, but Fallout just does it better. The writing, the quests, the immersiveness... Even though I actually prefer isometric RPGs to Fallout's ego perspective, Wasteland's implementation of it has a wide variety of shortcomings. The world feels much more static because environmental objects cannot be manipulated, the different areas are much smaller in size, and the overall level of interaction is much lower.Other downsides to be aware of:- AI is very dumb- Percentage based skill checks lead to a lot of reloading (it probably would have been better to have a binary 100% or 0% chance).- Balancing of different weapon types is off (melee based characters seem weak, assault rifle beats everything)- Battles are not tactical enough (more types of cover would have been nice, more firing modes, more environmental interaction, better system for explosive weapons)In spite of all this critique, I enjoyed the "classic" feel to the game and the very post-apocalyptical setting that inspired the original Fallout. Thoroughly enyoable, but definitely not a must-have.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Update: I changed my review to not recommend in order to purposefully lower the rating of this game on Steam. Quite simply when I kickstarted this game, Brian Fargo liked to go on and on about how they wanted to get away from big Publisher models, always being on the hook to publishers just seeking profit. But then they have been going out and trying to force developers with complete success so far, to change the names of their games if it contains the word Wasteland.You know its funny, because thats exactly something a publisher would do, they would throw money away pursuing these things instead of making games like Brian Fargo claimed thats what he wanted to do. Its understandable to engage in these legal matters when a game is intentionally trying to ape your stuff, but in every case the only similarity between titles, was the word Wasteland.Have the courage to stand for something InXile, no one is going to try and USURP the Wasteland IP by making ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little indie games. I won't be sending you anymore of my money(unless you get the Fallout IP back and make Fallout games). So yeah, Never again.Original, still true review below:I have about 110 combined hours between Wasteland 2 Classic and the Director's Cut.I backed this game on kickstarter and was pleased with Wasteland 2, to get the Director's Cut after for free was a huge bonus for me.The game itself plays like a squad-based Fallout 1 and 2, but in its own 1980s style post-nuclear setting. The RPG elements are solid but the game is combat focused which I am happy for. You get a number of useable skills to to do quests with, find hidden objects and loot. There is a ton of flavor text everywhere you go which help adds to the immersion and feeling of the game which I love. The music is a perfect ambient style soundtrack which hits all the right notes and there is an ambient soundtrack for areas aswell to help add to that immersion.There are tons of things to do in the wasteland and plenty to shoot aswell. Lots of weapons to choose from and different types of armors to wear. You can find clothing to dress your rangers up if you want, or will need to find clothing if you get it burnt off in combat!I think if you enjoy squad based turn based combat, you'll like this game. If you enjoy post-apocalypse settings, you'll enjoy this game. If you like to read and use your imagination, you'll like this game.If you liked Fallout 1 and 2, you will like this game.I found a Speak and Spell(remember those?) and pawned to the vendor for 8 scrap, it doesn't get much better than that.9/10

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												You want true Fallout 3? Here it is, no excuses.The buts :1) Combat is rather simplistic, a cover system, ducking, fire mode selection and an ambush option (spend some ap to shoot dudes who come into range next turn, useless imo) might please purists, might annoy if youre used to stuff like JA2 or Silent Storm.2) Simplified Armor system, no more tresholds and jazz. Weapons have a penetration rating (nyuk), resulting damage is normal when the armor rating is same or lower, if its higher damage is reduced.3) Resulting from that is a bizarro design decision where energy weapons do more damage versus a higher armor rating - e.g. a death laser kills you in power armor, but tickles if youre naked. Theres already pages of discussion elsewhere and the devs announced an enemy loadout change in some areas. Its still stupid imo.The bugs :1) Enemy movement AP glitches have dudes stroll ridiculous distances. All thats missing when some guy walks two screens and stops next to your sniper is the Benny Hill music. Announced to get fixed2) The last big hub of the game has an impressive array of intricate, multi-solution quests which are held together by spit and baling wire. Look at them wrong and marvel at duplicate characters, time travel dialogue and other sorts of broken flag funnies. Its almost a metagame in itself not to upset the straining scripting in that part too much. Announced to get fixed - 4/5 of the game are solid, id wager if you pick it up now it should be patched by the time you reach that part.   Heartily recommended despite parts of the endgame being a broken mess (wasnt this early access and♥♥♥♥♥♥)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Where to start... The game is awesome. I'm an early backer and I've played every beta that has been released, as far through as I can. Many of the bugs/issues noted by previous reviewers just simply aren't there anymore so a lot of the Cons of the reviewers just aren't correct.If you loved the original wasteland and you like turn based combat and actual movement strategy (think X-Com where if you move the wrong position you're toast) and a place where choices have real consequences then you will love this game. If you like all action and no brains then don't get this game. While it isn't a deep cerebral game, you do have to think about the solutions to problems (there are almost always two solutions or more to every problem). The isometric view isn't for some people but for those of us who came from the original world of RPG's it's an old friend that gives you a better view of the battlefield.Some in-depth points. This is a deep story and if you played the original you will appreciate a lot of the subtle humor. The NPC's almost all have a background - you don't though and you don't ever "grow" into a personalilty with a back story. I happen to like this approach where you get to explore your world without worrying about yourself too much. However, almost every path through the story will shape how other people view you and it will either help you accomplish missions or make it much more difficult.Pros: Everything. Basically if I was going to wait for a sequel then I would want it to be this. I don't really have any Cons for this game. Everything is beautiful and well done. It is a very replayable game (I've mapped out about 9 different paths that I want to (or have tried) try. In addition sometimes having certain NPC's with your party allows you to unlock areas or conversation paths that you could not otherwise discover.The team did a great job and I hope to write up a complete walkthrough in addition to the getting started guide which I'll update once the game goes live.

Early Access Review
								This is the game that will push all others into the dark corners of the damned.  If you enjoyed Wasteland and the Fallout series or you have a love for all things Post Apocalypse, this is the game for you!  You will not be disappointed.  You take a group of Desert Rangers out into the Post Nuclear afflicted Soutwest and investigate a possible threat.  It all starts with the Death of ACE.  Those of you who played Wasteland will know who ACE was.  Angela Deth is also part of this game.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								For those who loved games like Fallout, Fallout 2, and Fallout Tactics, You will love this game. So far it is fun, but I do have my gripes about it, one is the interface moving our team around is a little clunky, next would be the character models, these would be fine if it was the early 2002-2004, but with other games to compair it to, these could had been done a lot better they are very well super low poly to the point they look funky. Same with the textures, if we where all playing pc games on say on the first xbox's hardware it would be acceptable but its 2014. I really hope that the art end of this game is not done yet in terms of improvement. But I am guessing its about as good as its going to get visually. The other very limited weight/carry capacity, you do your first set of missions up to the first radio tower,  all of your inventory spots are about full, by the time you make it to the second tower your way overloaded, and a town/vendor to sell to  is far far away... and requires you to go though a radiation field, or go way out of your way around it, if you happen to get into a fight guess what you will pick up more stuff that you really have no room to carry. Hopefully the devs can find a solution to this. Overall great game, but it has many areas of improvement needed, from clunky controls, low polly assets that are almost waving like they are made of water when moving. To the tiny annoyances of inventory and not having a way to offload your loot at more locations besides out front of the ranger station at start of the game.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Wasteland 2 brings a unique style to RPG games. Giving off a fallout type of vide through out the whole game had amazing easter eggs to find and tons of interesting dialog. The combat was great and simple, Despite the minor bugs involving the camera glitching out durring combat but fixing itself after the next turn. Wasteland 2 state that there is 80+ hours.This may be true for some, yet for me it left me wanting more after finishing the game in under 60 hours. (All quests, side quests, locations, caches, characters, easter eggs, and pretty much everything was achived with a amazing immersive experience.-For me at least in under 60 hours) All and All wasteland 2 brings back the nostalga of the original wasteland and orginal fallouts. I would have to recommend this to everyone that loves the first wasteland and the fallout franchise. Although i would say i was abit annoyed by the fact it isn't open ended in terms of being able to continue to play and explore after the ending credits. I cannot however recommend this at its current pricing. the amount of content is great yet still is lacking in key areas. Best to wait for sales unless its a must have right now.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												So, I've 42 hours on the clock and am only half way through this game (starting off to california right now). What should I say about this game? Well, I'm 31 years old and this is (PC) gaming like I was used to back in the 90s.- No dumb "?" above questgivers- a party which you can create by your own imagination... with the chance to really f*ck up- really interesting world with (comic like) brutality, irony and funny references to especially gaming and apocalyptic movies at nearly every point of the maps- as of now, not the best story in the world, but it fits- sometimes really hard battles (playing on the third of four difficulties)- a few minor bugs, but no showstoppers so far- tons of sidequests and decission to make which actually matter- endless amount of flavor text which is really nice to read, but not necessary for completing the game- unfortunately very rare interaction between party members - some of the larger maps could be disorientating due to size and lack of a useful mapTo sum it up. If you like older RPGs like the Baldurs Gates, Fallout 1 and 2, Arcanum or even the oringinal Wasteland, GO GET IT, DONT WAIT FOR ANY SALE! The developers really delivered what they promised and they deserve their money! Hopefully we'll get a good Addon or even Wasteland 3! For me this is the first true sucessor to Fallout 2!Thumbs up!
