content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												You have already read the reviews of others and the positive ones are correct about the game. Although I would like to inform you of a few caveats.The game difficulty is well balanced at the normal suggested difficulty setting but starts to break while it is increased. Unlike Fallout Tactics, as the difficulty in Wasteland 2 increases the only change is quantitative. Your aim probability decreases, enemies do more damage etc. but the AI remains the same. Beating a battle set piece doesn't make you feel like you played well it mearly feels like you got lucky over and over again.One last pet peeve. The issue here is the half turn discrepancy between setting up your squad before combat and the first turn of combat. Since you can see battle coming you are able to plan ahead for it by setting squad order but the second battle starts all of your squad move just a little out of place and destroy all chance of strategic combat.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												Alright i'll get right to the point,  this game has numerous technical issues and often requires outside help as there is very little explanation for most missions. My only wish for this game was that the world was 'more open' and that the last 10-15% of the game felt rushed. Now that the criticism is out of the way heres what you will like.The meat of the gameplay is the RTS [duh] which is slick, and relatively smooth but often forces the player to watch all enemy moves [forces the camera to lock onto each hostile unit] but that is a small setback. The weapons and wearable cloths look great, with a fair amount of customization [not great but decent]. The combat is fun, and challenging and for loot hoarders such as myself there is ALWAYS something to loot, scavenge, and steal. The diologue system is great, but requires characters to upgrade non combat skills which can be frusterating for some, but offer rewarding new story archs for the player to follow which are otherwise impossible. I highly recommend creating you're own ranger or two [remember to specialize them in something] and create a backstory for them - makes you feel invested in the game and makes the player care who lives and who dies. However anyone with a heart can tell this game is a love letter to the fans who have been waiting for decades to indulge themselves within the wasteland universe. As with most love letters they at times try to hard, and on occassion written in haste. This is evident in some parts of the game [specifically late game]; despite this the effort and excruciating detail that went it to this game shows how much InXile wanted to make this game for others and for themselves. The story is great, the side quests have meaning and concequences with numerous outcomes all expressed in the epilogue which most will be more than satisfied with the thorough and satisfying ending; which leaves just enough loose ends to imply a wasteland 3 could see the light of day in the near future [ I hope anyway]. This is one of those games where I want to scream at the developers to take my money to support the game with new content [full expansions preferably] hoping containing a new area  map to explore. The epilogue this game provides will take a modest 5 minutes to read, and it manages to wrap this game up in a satisfying way. I'm a major gamer having thousands of hours on steam alone [doesnt even count for my console based games] and I can't say I havn't been as satisfied with an ending in years, I'd say the ending is similar to dragon age inquisition neatly wrapping up everything.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Played 31 hours in 3 days. 10 hours in to first play through decided I didnt like my setup Main menu'ed and New game.  The Game is amazing the Character creation can take an hour or more trying to fit all the skills your want in to 4 characters you quickly learn you cant have what you want, time to pick what you think you'll need.  While I see alot of comparing it to Fallout 1&2 no one mentions how close the game is to Fallout tactics the combat is almost a clone.  Fallout tactics was also a squad based game with the same Map system for travel.All in all I love the game, Best $40 I have spent this year the replay value is high and it makes me feel like I was a teen again, Playing Fallout on a computer that could barely run doom. ( Edit ) Having Completed the game I feel I should fill out the reveiw Some more.  First The Battle system does get a little bit boring shall I say? but its to be expected in a battle System of Turn Based and Guns in the end you know what is going to happen you'll hit that wall for every shot hits. The AI does tend to simply Rush at you rather than use cover but again to be expected from this type of game ( Fallouts where all the same )  But the story and the choices you make unlike normal RPG they carry a certain weight too them which after the first one or two you make and you realise this you start to question your actions, what to say to the NPC's what the out come might be and how to push it the way you want.  All in All I loved the game it felt Fleshed out and complete to me, I did not see any of the bugs the others have added to their reviews infact the only issue I did was that the Camera locked at one point and I had to Alt + Tab to fix it.  I will Play again, many times. I feel that if you want a game where choices do matter and who you Shoot changes the game this is the game for you.  I look forward to some DLC too. 10/10

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												This is a good game in a lot of ways. It captures the turn based and RPG elements well. Its flaws are many and deep ,though. The characters and dialog tree are fine, but having 3 different skills to effect dialog is excessive and takes away from the game. Hard♥♥♥♥♥seems most valuable. The graphics are not anywhere near modern. If you want to see a good turn based game well implemented, check out any of the new XCom titles. They are turn and squad based but look good too. I guess at the end of the day, I think the developers got lazy and cut corners. Portrait Icons, for example, are recycled throughout the game. So the portrait of the guy you were helping in one town is now the portrait of a guy you are fighting, or even a whole gang. Worse, the portraits often have nothing to do at all with the character. Even seemingly main characters have generic or even mismatched portraits. In a game with a limited graphic demand and limited eye candy appeal, those portraits are important to telling the story. InExile just mailed it in on that and many other things after cashing a huge Kickstarter check, and that really lessens the game. Voice acting is limited and really bad compared to any other title I have played in a while. The voices of Matthias and General Vargas, in particular, are horrible. For its current list price of $40, it is not at all what I expected. Expect to be disappointed in a lot of ways, and frustrated a lot of the time in an otherwise fun game.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Fallout 1 and 2 remain favorites of mine. While the FPS updates of Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas were great in their own way, inExile's Wasteland 2 is the true "successor" to Fallout's vibe and gameplay.This makes sense when you realize the Fallout universe was created as an IP-claim-avoiding homage to the original Wasteland.Many of the great people that worked on Fallout 1 & 2 have returned to make Wasteland 2, including great work from Chris Avellone on writing and design and the return of Mark Morgan's beautiful ambient music.It's worth noting this is game is thematically dark, with far less of the goofy humor that started to undermine the Fallout series. There's swearing, sex, drugs, lots of graphic violence, and many, many morally ambiguous choices.I haven't even finished the game yet, but I am already planning a second trip through the wastes. Highly recommended for fans of Fallout 1 and 2, Torment, Baldur's Gate, and post-apocalyptic fiction.

number of helpful: 14 of 28 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								OK...now this is the game. This is the successor to the grand father of cRPGs, the spiritual father of FALLOUT...This is Wasteland 2!The game is still in beta (or early access, what ever you want to call it). It is also still suffering from optimization issues, bugs, and clunky game design.HOWEVER, these things do not hinder the game. In its state, is is solid, and plays very well. It feels like a true port-apocalyptic game, and it can definitely stand up to FALLOUT of STALKER. The story telling is wonderful, combat works and feels great, the atmosphere is just perfect, there is a bit of humor and secrets, many new and unfamiliar enemies, andTONS of customization. You can tactically set up your team and develop them as they level up, or you can build your own character from the ground up. It is just overall a well done project.It is still being developed, and new updates will be coming out for it. The UI will be fixed, it will be optimized, much more will be added...and in the end, this wonderful, promising stone will be polished to be one of the greatest cRPGs done.I know, the price tag is a little steep. But, if you are willing to buy it, and if you are willing to put up with a (currently) incomplete game, and if you are going to commit yourself to giving back to the devs, then it will be a worthwhile purchase. Additionally, this is a great game if you loved FALLOUT (esp. the first 2 and tactics) and Wasteland. Should you buy it? It depends, you might not want to, and you are certainly not being forced to. But if you do, know you are contributing to a constantly developing and promising sequel to a beloved game.

												The rpg element of this game is reminiscent of how a tabletop rpg functions. I have played this game and became easily engrossed. The post-apocalyptic setting comes across pretty well too.There is certainly plenty of action and tactics to be had in this game, however, the puzzles it presents are sometimes tedious to figure out. Whether it is because you don't have your camera rotated the right way to see the interactive elements, or because you have to travel through three map sections just to get the piece to solve the puzzle (and then travel back) there does seem to be a bit of tedious work at times.The instruction-as-you-go tutorial works fine. It isn't too obtrusive if you don't want to look at the tips. However, it is a basic tutorial and some of the things you have to figure out yourself. Such as the green and red bar above weapons indicates optimal range values.I wish there was multiplayer for this game but unfortunately there isn't. I think it would be a lot of fun  for a group of friends to each control a character, but whatever.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												While a failure of overambition, and as a result clearly rushed, it is still one of the better isometric RPG's of the past decade.Its biggest failing, and it is one that is common in narrative RPG's which centers on an entire player created party instead of a single character, is that the story simply fails to draw you in.You are just not given a reason to care about your characters as anything other than stat sheets, and as a result the entire world becomes less engaging.The combat is, unfortunately, rather shallow and there is therefore entirely too much of it.Far too many areas are riddled with things to kill, and even the overland map has an abundance of random enemy encounters. There is a good variety of enemies, but when your tactical options are limited to shoot, move or overwatch, that does not matter as much as it should.Various classes do get a few special attacks at later levels, but it is not enough to add any actual depth to the combat. You never find yourself wondering what the best tactical option is beyond what enemy to focus on, or if you should use explosives (aoe).On the positive side, there is a great deal of reactivity in the various quests you uncover and the world is populated by plenty of well written characters. Overall the writing is pretty good, the world is interesting and the art work is excellent.While perhaps not the "real fallout 3" its kickstarter backers where hoping for, it is still a great game and definetly worth a playthrough.

												This game is simply awesome! Fallout 1&2 are my best games ever and it seems it will be the same with Wasteland 2. number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Brian Fargo really re-creates the late 90's magic here with the sequal to the original Wasteland. Most will know Brian ran Interplay studios which created and produced the Fallout 1, 2 and Tactics games. Such a shame it was sold...This feels so much like Fallout 1 and 2. The big differences being you are managing a party of up to 6 or 7 characters not just the one. Combat is far more frequent (a little repetitive) but the game has that same post apocolyptic feel with great writing, dark humour, sarcasm and just general wittyness that I remember from Fallout 1 and 2. I feel a little sad that I missed the original Wasteland, I should really get that going somehow and play it too.I have about 19hrs or so in Wasteland 2 and am only up to Dimonta (a place you must visit as a part of several different quests including the main). Now I know a little about what's to come as I've read teasers here and there (without spoiling the story for myself) and because of this I know that this game is huge. Just monstrous really. I think what makes it so big is the fact that there are loads of side quests that really draw the game out and the fact that there is a lot of back tracking sometimes in order to beef up, resupply and then carry on. But regardless of this I find it a treat finding all sorts of new weapons and modifying them to get that awesome assualt rifle bypassing armour by 10-15% with a few mods. I also love all the 80's and 90's pop culture references in there such as Cabbage Patch dolls, MAD magazines, D20 dice, trolls and many more. Those little items you stumble accross gives you a strong sense of nostalgia especially so if you grew up in those periods. I think there a real treat. I won't even go into the "toy snake" you find ha ha.The Director's Cut is definitely where it's at. Heaps more recorded dialog and just general performance increases and polish. I wouldn't bother playing the original Wasteland 2 and I don't think you can anymore? The game is also fairly stable with one wierd CTD (nothing in my event logs either) out of that 20 hours. It runs well and for the most part looks ok. I feel like some areas are a little bland and could have used a going over but aside from that the world looks good.Some areas feel a little empty. I know it's post apocolyptic but some more NPC's to engage with would be nice. The writing really shines when you do talk to those few NPC's that can talk. Overall the main quest story hasn't kicked in a whole lot just yet so I can't comment on it.Anyways it's not a perfect game and this is proven in the repetitive combat. There is some advantage to finding cover and ensuring your perks and skills line up to how you want your characters to operate but it's always the same. Battle starts and you find cover and then off you go until the enemy is dead. The AI enemies are good at taking cover and trying to flank but once you've seen it a few times I think you can say you've seen it all. I've heard that there are boss fights but I am yet to reach one so I can't comment on that either.Despite these flaws, the game isn't too bad. Give it a try if you love Brian Fargo, Interplay and the original Wasteland and Fallout series. I think you'd like it. I give it a 8 out of 10 overall.TLDR: Good writing, a little empty with repetitive combat but reeks of pop cultural references from the 80's and 90's that will have you thinking back to those times. Overall not a bad game but not perfect either.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												In my opinion, this is one of the top 10 crpgs ever made.  It has everything I look for in a crpg - party creation, good chargen and chardev, lots of ways that your skills interact with the environment, good combat, good story, great characters (like the kid that follows you around in the California base, Chisel, etc).9.5/10The only cons for me are -Would have liked 5 or 6 character creation instead of 4Too many and too much leveling that kind of makes the character development less meaningful.  A level cap of 20, 25 or 30 with slower leveling would have fit better IMO3d does nothing and adds nothing to the game but annoyance.  A fixed camera like PoE, Dark Sun, FO, etc, would have been my preferenceThat's it.  And I am well aware my cons are not really shared by the community at large.  Honestly, I did not believe inXile was capable of making a crpg, never mind a rpg I that is in my top 10 (and I've been playing crpgs since the mid-late-80s.  I am really looking forward to the new Bard's Tale from them now too.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a good game, but overall fell short of my expectations. The funny thing is that the mediocrity of Wasteland 2 reminded me how great Fallout New Vegas was and I finally finished my walkthrough of that game, rather than continuing with Wasteland 2. Both games attempt the same thing in so many ways, but Fallout just does it better. The writing, the quests, the immersiveness... Even though I actually prefer isometric RPGs to Fallout's ego perspective, Wasteland's implementation of it has a wide variety of shortcomings. The world feels much more static because environmental objects cannot be manipulated, the different areas are much smaller in size, and the overall level of interaction is much lower.Other downsides to be aware of:- AI is very dumb- Percentage based skill checks lead to a lot of reloading (it probably would have been better to have a binary 100% or 0% chance).- Balancing of different weapon types is off (melee based characters seem weak, assault rifle beats everything)- Battles are not tactical enough (more types of cover would have been nice, more firing modes, more environmental interaction, better system for explosive weapons)In spite of all this critique, I enjoyed the "classic" feel to the game and the very post-apocalyptical setting that inspired the original Fallout. Thoroughly enyoable, but definitely not a must-have.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												While a failure of overambition, and as a result clearly rushed, it is still one of the better isometric RPG's of the past decade.Its biggest failing, and it is one that is common in narrative RPG's which centers on an entire player created party instead of a single character, is that the story simply fails to draw you in.You are just not given a reason to care about your characters as anything other than stat sheets, and as a result the entire world becomes less engaging.The combat is, unfortunately, rather shallow and there is therefore entirely too much of it.Far too many areas are riddled with things to kill, and even the overland map has an abundance of random enemy encounters. There is a good variety of enemies, but when your tactical options are limited to shoot, move or overwatch, that does not matter as much as it should.Various classes do get a few special attacks at later levels, but it is not enough to add any actual depth to the combat. You never find yourself wondering what the best tactical option is beyond what enemy to focus on, or if you should use explosives (aoe).On the positive side, there is a great deal of reactivity in the various quests you uncover and the world is populated by plenty of well written characters. Overall the writing is pretty good, the world is interesting and the art work is excellent.While perhaps not the "real fallout 3" its kickstarter backers where hoping for, it is still a great game and definetly worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Wasteland 2 provides a great RPG experience at a good price. For players of the first Wasteland game, it's a must-buy, and newcomers (particularly those who enjoyed games like Fallout 1&2) will find a lot to love.The character creation system is very nice, and while I fretted over skill and attribute points at first, I found that the game is so huge and there are so many different paths to take that you will find a rewarding, engaging, and different story with each party that you form (and you will likely want to play it through with a different setup at least once).The choices you make can have long lasting impact on gameplay, and for that reason it's one of the few (maybe the only?) that I played through again immediately after finishing.It's funny, entertaining, and well worth the price; to top it off it's a great example of crowdfunding done right.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Great atmosphere, writing, voice acting and storytelling. Pretty much anything that isn't directly gameplay related is top notch.The gameplay itself is very unpolished and shallow. There's isn't a lot of options/ways for actual strategy in combat, all that you can do is to pretty much try and improve your odds by taking cover or higher ground and then let the diceparty roll its way. Building your characters isn't anything more then gaining numbers/stats.My biggest issue with the game is it's difficulty. I love playing games with "above normal"/hard difficulty so I sticked to the Ranger difficulty which has also been said that it's the recommended one to play, so playing on a lower difficulty was not an option for me and it would have felt rather demotivating.I grinded for a bit on the world map (random encounters, areas) between each (main) mission but I was still constantly struggling. Enemies were pumped with more health then your characters and most of the time they will also do more damage (example: throwing tons of rare/expensive explosives on you).. Oh and they will probably outnumber you as well.. The game turned into a tedious and unhealthy save reloading RNG party.If you are more into lore and storytelling then this is a game for you (preferably on a normal or lower difficulty).If you are looking for a strategic turn based RPG then this game will leave you dissapointed.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												I really wanted to like is so I forced myself to finish it.Worst part about the game is that you suffer for the decisions you made withen the first 5 minutes of play for the entire game.  You really need a character with a level 10 in every skill to do well in this game yet you are limited on party customization outside the new game screen.  Fallout Tatics and X-Com have a much better system for this where you simply recruit new characters.  Never really cared about any of the playable characters even though I was stuck with them the entire game. Second worst thing is that this is a split map, once you complete map 1 you cannot go back and pick up the pieces that you missed.  This sucks if you are a completionist.  Not only that you loose one of your best party members that you leaned on for roughly half the game.  I almost quit when this happened.If that isn't annoying enough there are some quests are just plain bugged and are not possible to complete.There is some interesting quests and choices that can be done in this game.  But progress in the storyline is very slow, and grinding at some points. Wasteland 2 is a long game, not because of the story but because of the pacing.Fallout 2 has great story pacing, never a dull moment; Fallout Tatics / X-Com has great squad based combat with ambushes staged around every corner; Wasteland 2 just failed to achieve greatness at either. It is just OK.

number of helpful: 28 of 57 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												I backed this one on Kickstarter, mainly because there was a goal set to fund aLinux version and there was only a few games for Linux then. The idea soundedgood – reviving an old classic, something like Fallout, multiple skills andways to solve quests, etc.After over two years of waiting it came. Playing it was tricky at first, due toa 'fog of war bug' on my integrated Intel GPU. It seems the problem was knownfrom early beta but all the developers could say was 'Intel GPUs are notsupported'. Oh… and I thought the game was supposed to be about story,playability and reviving classic. Nothing that should require a dedicatedgaming hardware. Current laptop should be enough. And is enough when theworkaround for the bug is known. But creators would not acknowledge that – buya gaming computer or don't bother us.OK, so with the workaround for the GPU bug the game was fun to play. There weresome game bugs, sometime ruining some quests, but nothing making the gameunplayable. I have played 60 hours… and got bored. 'Dozens of skills' reallymeans 'many different ways to open containers' all the same containers all thetime. It is a game of opening chests and safes. And digging holes.Yes, there is also the combat and combat skills. You need good hand gun orsniper skills not to kill your own people by mistake… But there are also highexplosives, which you need not skill to use at all. Always 100% hit chance,always 100% deterministic effects. How can it be? If not the price andavailability explosives would be the most effecting and safest method of fight.Then come the patches. Some bugs were fixed, often for parts I have alreadyplayed and do not wish to come back. Some features were implemented. And youknow what? Linux is not an equal platform now. Steam achievements wereintroduced two patches ago and they are 'Windows only'. Steam achievements!I could understand, that some advanced graphics or sound effects could betricky to do in Linux, or that handling some exotic controller could beimpossible. But the achievements?!It is not that Wasteland 2 is a bad game or that my contribution was waste ofmoney, but I am a bit disappointed and the game is not worth the 'user reviews'rating it has now.BTW I got bored by Fallout 2 too, so if you really love this type of games you could probably ignore my opinion.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												An old-style RPG, almost to a fault. I will say, it very much does feel like the logical extension of the original Wasteland/Fallout, had Fallout not gone the way of Elder Scrolls.There's some nice tactical turn-based combat here, but it's not especially deep. Similarly, the story is certianly inoffensive as far as quality, but it didn't really grab me, either. I got some nice nostalgia jolts from the presence of dialogue trees and inventories, but there's also plenty of clunky interfaces and awkward questlines.This is a game that feels out-of-time. It's not pushing anything forward, but it does play more or less like you'd expect a game from 1998 to play. As such, I think I appreciate it more in idea than in execution. And I'll say this much, if you're looking for an RPG that's long like old RPGs used to be, then buddy you will not be dissappointed.With Steam's binary scale, I think this one is more on the "recommend" side, but I'd throw in the caveat of "fourty dollars is perhaps a bit high." I liked it, but I didn't love it.

number of helpful: 19 of 39 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a fan of the original Wasteland, I had very high hopes for this game. Overall, I enjoyed the tone, the story, the interface -- and don't have the same criticisms that many others have had.Unfortunately, I found navigating around the world much more cumbersome that I would have expected. I spent a long time wandering around levels looking for the right building, a doorway within a map or the tiny green highlight that showed the way to the next location. So, basically I found myself spinning around and mousing around in order to find the locations I was looking for.In one of the early locations, I found myself having to make many time consuming trips across half of a beaten map to return to the city -- no way to fast-travel straight to it. While I appreciate the return to some of the old school magic, some of the hand holding that newer games do does allow the players to focus on the more important aspects of the gaming experience.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Ignore the people who are angry that inXile defended their trademark. They don't understand how the trademark system works. inXile could potentially lose their trademark if they don't defend it. The game is definitely enjoyable and provides a challenge even on the lowest difficulty. It's quite refreshing to find a game that doesn't hold your hand as though it's life depends on it. Even moreso with a game that actively rewards interacting with characters and exploring like Wasteland 2 does. The amount of lore behind every setting and character is fleshed out and gives a lore-nerd like me something to read, inbetween blowing people's brain's out.A love-it or hate-it thing about the game is that it doesn't do much in the way of quest markers. Typically the quest log will tell you where you should start looking and nothing more. While this does result in much more organic gameplay and storytelling, it can be frustrating when you've been searching for that one guy that you need to talk to for the past fifteen minutes.The game's addition of it's humor in it's post-apocalypic setting is implemented very well. The humor is enough of a sideshow to be entertaining, without ruining the theming of the game - it reminds me of Fallout 3 with the 'Wild Wasteland' perk in some ways, just the little things. Seriously, Toaster Repair is a surprisingly valuable skill in a world without toast.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												The graphics are incredibly bland, by which I mean that they were made by people that just don't have any sense of style whatsoever. There are games old like gameing itself like Fallout tactics or Baldurs gate that have more personality like Wasteland 2.The music and the sound design are as bland as the graphics are. Not really worth this line of virtual text.Another chapter are the dialogs or should I rather say monologs with intersections. You can't really select any answers. Well you can but only very very rarely. Mostly, the "dialogs" are all about utterly boring "Tell me about this one thing", "Tell me about 2nd thing"..."Tell me about that 20th thing. Really the dialogs even though nicely writen are total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.But of all else what I found the most boring is the combat system. Today when you got really interesting combat situations with elemental interactions like in Divinity: Original sin. But hell! Even old games like Baldurs gate got interesting AOF weapons and buffs and summons and what not. In W2 you got guns. Then you get slightly better guns. Snipers are guns with higher effective range but still guns. And then you got sticks. And thats about all of it. Oh yeah and you get to cover and everything happens in something I would call very bland arenas. Thats all I was able to see of the combat before I died of boredom.Remember me.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												1. Live action actor playing your commander in a cutscene has a beard.2. In-game portrait of your commander has a beard.3. Examining your commander reads: "A stiff, bearded older man... walks with a cane... wears a pearl-handed revolver..."Well... his actual in-game model is a 30 years old clean-shaven generic male dude with a generic DesertEagle-sized handgun and it seems that he misplaced his cane somewhere. Bummer.This pretty much sums up the whole game, because everything it offers to the player works exactly like that: roleplaying, combat, economy model, loot system, all of it. It's not an awful game per se, more so in it's Director's Cut version, but if it's the apotheosis of mr. Fargo's publisher-free talent, then it's a very good retirement milestone. It could pass as a solid 15$ mobile platform game, maybe even 30$ in it's DirCut state, but it is too weak and barebone, if not primitive, for a 60$ PC CRPG title.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												I funded this game at Kickstarter. I have mixed feelings about the result, as much as I try to like it:+ Size of game: Large world, much to explore, long play time. Lots of different, quite large (larger than in Fo1) cities/places. Often they have some politics with each other but usually most quests are done right at the location you are, and some quests are generic get-and-return or talk-to-and-return quests.-  Random encounters: Only fights and traders. Fights, if in the same area, take place on the same single map, same enemies. Traders can sometimes be found, nothing special. Better to skip everything if possible.o Only limited freedom. No real sandbox. No real open world. The game is mostly seen to be linear because you are always locked out of new places unless you progress in the story, a story which is very linear unless you take the "bad path" leading to an early-on bad ending. Along the storyline you just do whatever the Ranger HQ tells you to do, at least when it comes to the main quests. You got more freedom to do whatever you want when it comes to how you solve disputes and such, which is nice in turn.+ NPCs: A diverse selection of followers can be selected from to join your team throughout your journeys. Practically no interaction possible with them or between them. They do however often make comments, and rarely cause an event.-- Bugs: The game is definitely playable, but after Patch 4 there are still a lot of major bugs. Especially in the California half of the game. This game was released too early and clearly had obvious issues left at release, and the developers must have been aware of its state. Releasing a game as "finished" when it in reality is riddled with bugs, that's a BIG no-no for me!++ Bug-Fixing and Support: The feedback on bug report is fast and they still improve the game a LOT.o Story: While the story is in its essence very interesting, the dialogs are often not. The writing could be improved upon a lot. Aso Vargas is annoying.- Gameplay I: Quite weak attributes and skills system. It seems they did not think this design through well enough. Some skills were also dropped pretty late in development (sneaking). Negatives: Skills are not tied to attributes at all (brute force skill 10 works as well with strength 1  as it does with any other stringth. charisma and intelligence dont affect speech or dialogue options and dont affect the 3 speech skills (smartass,kissass,kickass) in any way, etc.)  Some skills should probably have been combined into one. Over all they tried to reinvent the wheel with their system and the wheel turned out to be cubic and clunky rather than more useful and efficient. Also: each player characters needs a lot of skill points to be spent on a weapon type to hit well wit hit but then a grenade or rocket launcher has 100% accuracy on any character by default. There are also two skills written as "???" without description in the character window, and that still after 4 patches.-- You want to open a box or safe or pick up some poo? Well, bad luck for you: Boxes, safes, doors,  poop; everything explodes in your face when touched. And the real bummer: disarming bombs, safecracking and lockpicking is extremely time-consuming even if skilled at maximum possible levels. Try a whole mine field... Medic and surgery also takes forever. It often feels like wasting my time waiting for bars to fill up when playing. It felt like this took a large part of my playtime. Even unlocking a door with a key (!!) takes about 5 seconds. Pure nuisance. At some point I started to just triggers bombs, mines and traps and eat the damage instead of defusing them because even if skilled to the max, it still takes too long to defuse everything in the game. What is also very time consuming is the movement inside locations. If entering rooms, all characters will be teleported, so you can't even split up your team leaving one character at an area's exit to shortcut running back all the way.o Gameplay II: The fights are not overly tactical. Formations are not supported. You often have to manually position each character 1 by 1 without being able to utilise the actual grid used in fights, meaning the characters will be moved unpredictably a short distance when a fight starts. Taking cover is practically useless, yjust shooting the enemy is often better than wasting action points running around taking cover. Fights are overall fun though. Just don't expect a Jagged Alliance here. ++ Gameplay III: Lots of weapons and weapon types available in this game and weaponsmithing is fun.o Dialogs: while you get different options in dialogs, most are just serving you some general info, repeating almost the same batches of text. When it comes down to actual choice, I often felt a bit limited despite having skilled all 3 speech skills to the necessary levels to have all options present. The skills are pretty useless because you only get to use each of them maybe 5 times in the entire game, and often they do not even lead to better results but to WORSE results which really sucks after having invested valuable points...++ Lots of quests and lots of things to do in this world. Often you have choices to solve quests differently, but ...-  ...the quests do however still converge to an unwanted ending in a lot of cases no matter how you approach it. Sometimes places and people cannot be saved against all logic.-- Graphics: The art direction feels uninspired / heartless and forgettable. Generally too many saturated vivid yellow/green/brown colours, subpar shading (where is the specular lighting?), terrible AA (some bad version of FXAA was chosen whyever), sometimes random blobs of colours. It overall looks very "meh" to me, they could have done a lot better. The low-poly modeling is generally fine for third person, but unfortunately they made mistake of letting the character portraits (optionally) be zoomed-in screenshots of the character. These captures look quite awful and you would normally not even see your character that close-up so why enforce making this flaw apparent?- Character portraits:  For your own characters, instead of the 3D snapshots, 2D portraits can be chosen. But the selection is small and some can be encountered in the game again on NPCs. However, you can add custom portraits to the game if you want. A lot of NPCs in the game unfortunately share the exact same portraits. Often the portraits are contrary to the 3D model. The character portraits repeat even on important characters creating great confusion in anyone who would try for recognise them by looking at the portrait. The descriptions given in the text can often conflict the 3D model's looks which also is contrary to the 2D portrait. Three impressions which do not go along with each other. This killed the immersion for me at times.- Many quests have to be solved in an unintuitive and sometimes unsatisfactory way (your actions may have an effect contrary to your goal), some relevant spots inside areas are weirdly hidden (Alexey in Highpool) which took me a lot of time to find in order to solve quests. Also I often encountered situations that weren't solvable (with the outcome I wanted) with logic and speech skills (Railroad Nomads conflict). Some quests were also bugged, but this was solved now. Personally I preferred the quest-solving in Planescape or Fallout. It seemed more straight-forward there, meaning that my actions lead to the results that I wanted to achieve.All in all I feel like this game didn't get as much love from the developers as it should have and also was released prematurely with unfinished design aspects all over the place. Some issues i mentioned might be resolved in future patches but most won't because they would require redesigning big parts of the entire game. Overall it was okay fun to play, but the buggy release make me give thumbs down.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												An excellent return to the formula of the original isometric CRPGs of the past, Wasteland 2 is a worthy successor to its fargone original. Mostly. There are a few moments of derp-dome come again with characters that simply don't fit in the game, but overall it has a good story and excellent gameplay. Bugs do occur, but the developers have released fixes promptly enough to satisfy my needs. Overall, I enjoyed the playthrough and the challenge of its "Supereme Jerk" difficulty.  While there are issues with the balance of the game (namely, assault rifle weapons are god-like, while pistols are mostly useless) and the game does use a simplistic toughening/weakening of the enemies and player respectively for its 'difficulty' scaling, it was certainly a well executed, if not perfect, recall to the early years of RPGs.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												This game is going to suck up more of my life than any game that has come before it. The amount of content is staggering, it is an OCD dream full of customization, grinding, a few novels worth of reading, and more extra storylines than you can shake a stick at. You can save a town, then destroy everyone in it. You can be the hero of a town and destroy another, and you will have a mission win for one or the other, either way. You will sell things that you don't know are valuable down the line, and regret it immediately afterward. This game is so immense, so huge, so non-linear, and so full of content that any AAA game developer would have split it into 5 games. I can't believe how "underground" this game has remained after last year. There was a moderate amount of hype surrounding it, and of all the games that received hype and delivered, this is it. Massive, addictive, and perfect. The soundtrack is even great, which is hard to to pull off with a game this long and, frankly, insane. Definitely my game of choice for 2014, and at the moment, my favorite game. 9.5/10. Buy it.

The game probably gets good later on, but even during the free weekend, I wasn't invested enough to keep going.Verdict: Wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game. I liked games like Fallout 1/2 and Fallout Tactics.  So the squad-based turn-based RPG is a category I like.  I also wanted to like this game to support indie designers, so against my better judgement I purchased the game shortly after release and at full price.  However, the flaws in this game are vary glaring and difficult to ignore.1) If you haven't played Wasteland 1, this game is hard to follow.  It is more like a continuation of the story than a sequel set in the same world. Many of the clues dropped require some knowledge of the events in Wasteland 1.2) The gameplay mechanics are just a mess.  The armor system is borked to the point of being pointless.  While the initiative system is interesting, there is no prevision for a character to delay his turn.  The effect of which is to create a log jam if a slower character is blocking a door.  Fortunately most of the combat is in wide open area -- probably for this very reason.3)  Looting is similarly botched where crappy useless loot is stored in containers that require a number of difficult checks to open.  The difficult of skill checks is uneven through out the game as well.I do like the three dimensional maps and the ability to rotate them (however they definitely do not rotate smoothly). The attitude and feel of the game seem to be done well.  The character models and animations however do not match the environment very well.  The in game character appearance does not change based upon the armor that is equipped. Clothing choices seem to be poorly matched to gender (I guess cross-dressing is a thing in the wasteland).Overall, I doubt many people will get past part one in the game much less get into part 2 (Las Angels) where the writing and encounters start to fall apart.This game will probably have to be saved by mods, which there does seem to be a few on the horizon to fix the mechanics.  However, I don't see the skill system being reworked with mods, which has a few issues as well -- mainly too many skills.  There are 29 skills in the game and at least 6 of them could simply be removed/combined with existing skills.Overall, Fallout Tactics was a better game.  If you are really liking this type of game, wait for a steam sale.

Its Wasteland. It's Fallout. Wasteland 2... is an A+ title by inExile - Who are currently also working on the sequel to PLANESCAPE TORMENT (how can we lose with these guys? -They promised on everything they said they would thus far - "One Size Does Not Fit All: Don't feel like finding the key for a door? Why not try a Rocket Launcher! Basically the same thing... right? Enhanced Classic RPG Game Play: Classic RPG game play ideas updated with modern design philosophies. Decision Making... with Consequences: With both short and long term reactivity to the players choices, every decision matters in the outcome of the story. Hugh & Customizable: Dozens of hours of game. Hundreds of characters. Thousands of variations on your Rangers' appearance. Over 150 weapons. Dozens of skills. Even the UI can be customized."- All true and very exciting for the old schooler to the new schooler.A+

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I'm playing on Normal difficulty and have about 6 hours in. The game starts out really promising, but then throws a bunch of missions at you at one time. When you get to the second big mission of the game, the enemies are extremely powerful and your band of mercenaries will not stand a chance. GOOD Things: The tactical combat is nice. There are a variety of weapons and it is critical to manage your squad's inventory.Resource Scarcity makes gameplay feel exciting and changes how you approach conflict. The world seems interesting and you won't feel bored reading through all the text. BAD Things: This game is difficult. This comes from someone who loves Dark Souls. Whereas another game could be difficult and fair, this one does not seem fair in the least. Oh, your squad member can shoot once per turn? Awesome. Here is a pack of enemies that can empty their magazines into you. Or, here are some people carrying machetes who can cross the whole of the wasteland and smack you in the face in the same turn you may get a chance to unjam your weapon.Seriously, this is infuriating. Let me shoot this pistol with a 3 percent chance to jam. 3 percent is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. You can set your watch to that thing jamming. No kidding, the game is incredibly unfair. I am a huge fan of the old school fallout games as well. I've played Ghosts and Goblins on the NES. I've seen unfair games, and this is such. WHO will enjoy this?Sadists. Masochists. People who love playing CIV on unfair difficulties. People who like pulling triggers and having their guns jam while criminals beat you in the face with spiked 2 by fours.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												I'm mainly writing this for my friends because I recommended this game to them before I spent enough time with it. I had really high expectations for this game but I really can't recommend it.  I wanted to love this game, I mean really LOVE it like I loved Fallout 2 or Jagged Alliance 2 or Morrowind. And I tried so hard to overlook the flaws I saw because damn it, I was waiting for this game over 20 years and I wasn't going to let some nittpicky BS stop me. But unfortunately all the problems I kept encountering just kept building up on each other until I pretty much gave up. Some of these problems are as follows: The combat is shallow and lacks any sort of tactical feel despite being turn based; You rarely have a need to move your characters and most battles can be won by standing still and spaming attack or maybe toss a grenade. You can crouch or use a headshot but there's no real advantage that I notice to even bother with these moves.  The missions all seem half finished; apparently it's "hand holding" to ask for any sort of clue as to what you need to do or even why you need to do it. And all of the quests have multiple ways to "complete" them but if you're looking for multiple ways to complete them in a manner that the devs wanted you to in order to "win" the game then you'll need to rely on online guides because those solutions require an extremely linear path to be followed. And by "win" the game I mean by having the optimal completion where everyone you encounter was happy with what you did. Those endings are there but as I said they're not very easy to figure out. "Conversations" with NPC's are nothing more than triggering the next bit of dialog by clicking on the keyword; there's no branching at all and you're really not interacting with NPC's in any meaningful way.  Character creation is also an oddity since it breaks the norm in most RPG's by having skills act completely independant of  attributes; ie charisma has no effect on your characters conversation skills or barter. And lastly there are some really bad bugs that have caused me to lose a lot of game play time; there's 3 quick save slots for a reason and you should be sure to use them.There's a lot to like here but I'm not going to sit here with a "pros and cons" list because I figure a lot of people are like me: if I'm thinking about buying a game I'm pretty much sold on it already and what I need to know is the bad stuff. Now none of the stuff I said above is so much that it's caused me to hate the game but it is enough to make me wish I had held off and waited for more reviews instead of buying it day one. $14.99-$19.99 is probably a good price point for this game but $40 is too much for what you get.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I backed this game because I am a huge fan of Fallout 1, but after a few hours I can't be bothered to play it. Everything seems unfinished and generally rough around the edges. The engine is garbage and the graphics are ugly even at maximum setting. And I'm not talking low-definition ugly - the whole look of the game is just a big mess. It's all pasted together and no details seem to stand out. The UI is abhorrent with a ton of wasted space, which is not acceptable in 2014.  Navigating around the place is a pain because there aren't any proper map markers like in Baldur's Gate, for example. In fact, various caves and other area transitions are so poorly marked that they are hard to click. The camera is beyond terrible and adds to the unfinished feel of the game. On one map there was a tall tower that got in the way of the camera while I was in combat and I spend an ungodly amount of time trying to see around it. This is simply not acceptable in modern games. And don't get me started about combat, such utter rubbish! The guns feel like little slingshots and at times it seems more tactically sound to just come at the enemy bare handed. The combat is so boring and broken I don't even have the space to get into it. This is just one of those games that you want so much to like but the more you play it the more everything bothers you until you just decide enough is enough, close it and then uninstall it. I really don't know what the developers were doing but no one is going to convince me that this pile of garbage is the result of over 3 million US dollars and countless unexplained delays by the developer. My department just finished coordinating a 1.5 million international research project and if we pulled things like inXile we would in all probability be sued into utter oblivion.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Bryan Fargo presents: Bryan Fargo's Wasteland 2 eschews almost every major game design improvement of the last thirty years for the cause of nostalgia. Combat is simplistic and enemy difficulty scales purely by turning them into bullet sponges, and any 'set piece' fights can be negated by having one party member trigger combat and then run back, drawing snipers from towers and cover to chase them down on foot. Attributes are completely disconnected from skills simply because that's how it was done 20 years ago; as a result, two of your *seven* attributes are dumpstats and may as well not exist (Luck and Charisma), and since Coordination is a meaningless concept when divorced from fine manipulation skills, it may as well have been folded into Speed. The modified ASSI system would be in fact, far less so than the current CLASSIC set-up.However, if you do want to choose Charisma on a character, do not level any social skills with them whatsoever! Charisma's only real benefit is a set boost to all XP gained that scales with how high the stat is, and all dialogue skills grant experience to the entire party when used. Active skills such as the two redundant Lockpicking skills, Demolitions, Mechanical Repair and Computer Science, et al, only grant experience to the user. As a result, your Charismatic character should be highly Intelligent in order to gather as many active skills to benefit from the experience stat. As a result, none of your other three characters really need high Int; 4 or 6 should suffice. Your ideal party should be a beautiful Adonic IT guy who can't tie his own shoes and can calculate pi to the first 200 decimals without paper, and three semi-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ punch monkeys who kill or sweet-talk everything between them and victory.The game is riddled with minor bugs, which would be expected of a newly released game, except every higher-tier Kickstarter backer got the questionable reward of becoming QA-tester for a day the majority of the development process. Unless you got a copy of the game for participating in the Kickstarters of other Interplay alumni, I guess. Currently, keeping any allied non-party NPC alive is terrifyingly difficult as they're often equipped with pistols, and since you can't control them, gleefully run into the firing arcs of any Ranger they can see to maximize their self-harm. But they will duel you to the death if you accidentally clip them, which results in the player having to utilize amazingly unorthodox tactics. Prepare to think outside the box!I've played through the original Wasteland multiple times, as well as Fountain of Dreams, Wasteland's toilet baby. It's not that I hate this game, or even dislike it; in fact, it's exactly what I expected when I put $60+ into the Kickstarter. I've privately bemoaned streamlining game mechanics in favor of overall experience, and it's almost cathartic to have the inevitable conclusion of that flawed ideal thrown in my face. I'm not a casual, but there have been a lot of general QOL improvements to RPG and strategy gameplay mechanics that an entire development team had to put horse blinders on to avoid.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Short review- the more you play this, the less you'll like it. It is long, very repetitive, and boring. I don't just want my money back, I want my time back.I'm a big fan of Fallout 1 & 2 and similar games. When I first started playing Wasteland 2, I enjoyed it. It had a similar feel. Unfortunately, as the game progressed, it just aggravated me. I found myself spending all my time performing useless actions rather than actually playing a game. There are crates/boxes strewn about everywhere, and nearly every single one is locked/trapped, so you spend a lot of time using skills to open them (which takes several seconds each attempt), having to reload multiple times because the difficulty of each lock/trap seems to be random. They pretty much never have anything useful, so you've just wasted your time. Also, you have to run across the same areas you've already cleared, just to exit the map. Then run BACK across just to turn in a minor quest.The areas are sprawling, but VERY repetitive. There's relatively little NPC interaction, and most of those are the same, too. I don't know how many times I've gone to a town where they complain about a disease, had to find the local doctor who magically can cure it, but he needs you to go get a specific item to save the day. It creates the illusion of a sandbox as you explore the open world, but most places won't appear on the map until you hit that point in the storyline, no matter how many times you walk over it.Even the fights got boring quickly. Weapon variety seemed decent at first, but ultimately felt pointless. And the "friendly fire" is ridiculous. I don't mind friendly fire, but it seems almost guaranteed to hit your friend if he's between you and the opponent, even if it doesn't make sense (like if the friend is in a crouched position right in front of the firer, who is standing, and you're firing at someone at a higher elevation).I got to a point where I thought the game was almost over, and I was excited. Then I discovered I was only about halfway through and got depressed. I considered quitting the game right then, but hoped it would get better in the second half. I should've stopped playing.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Now this game isnt bad, however, I recommend this game FOR HARDCORE TACTICAL RPGs FANS ONLY. If you are new to the genre, or if you don't really know, do NOT buy this now and wait for a reduction on the full price.Frankly this is a game I really would recommend you pirate before buying, especially if you're a casual gamer, you may not like this peculiar experience.Now lets be honest, I was not impressed when I first started playing this game. I was new to it, lots of stuff is unexplained (like the fact that you can blow up gates and such) and the game was a bit complex. After 40 hours of gameplay, I can say that this game is worth every penny of it's price. What this game lacks in graphics and in audio it catches up clearly with great combat mechanics and a very long story. Is the story good? No. At least, not the first part of it. However, all the plots that will unravel as you progress in the main story or the side plots are all quite exceptionnal. They all have different outcomes, which can completely reshape areas you were in previously. This game is fantastic in it's own distinct way. The universe is immersive (once again except for the poor character graphics and the bad audio) and sucks you into the game.With a bit more and really only a bit more effort in one or two updates, this game would get 9/10.All I'm asking for is a complete review of the OST of the game, the creating of a lot more character portraits, the remodelling of characters in general and the finishing of the spoken dialogue. With this relatively small amount of work, this game could really be outstanding.What follows is a break-up of the different things I experienced in game, in a bullet-point, non review-esque style.+ COMBAT: a solid combat system:10 different weapon types, including 3 melee weapon types (blunt, blade and brawl) and 7 close (shotguns, pistols, SMG) to medium (assault rifles, heavy weapons) to long (sniper rifles) range. With an extra emphasis on armor and some weapon types being very effective against heavy armor (energy weapons, a category in which there are weapons of all ranges) and some less.A cover system which sometimes bugs a bit.A crouch to aim better system.A headshot system that trades accuracy for extra damage.A "when you shoot someone lower (in terms of altitude) than you, you get a bonus in accuracy" systemSome hit ratios may seem a little low, the more you spend skill points in a weapon type, the more precise you become in your shots with it.+ EXPLORATION: Another well thought out systemYou will need to upgrade 11 different skills to survive in the wasteland, and by that I mean to efficiently explore every single area by destroying walls and lockpicking doors and gates and loot every single chest, safe... Don't forget to level up your perception skill to spot traps and mines and your demolition skill to disarm them.Your surgeon and field medic skills can help you a lot in the wastes, or rather, it can help the people around you a lot.The vision circle around your characters will be blocked by high objects, forcing you to move behind them making the game much more realistic.+ STORY: There are lots of different paths you can take throughout the main story and the side stories, which all affect each other in a way.To unlock different paths, don't forget to upgrade your 3 convincing skills, Hard-A-s-s, Kiss-A-s-s (which I think should've been called seduction but yeah whatever), and Smart-A-s-sAnd believe me, youll need them or you'll really be locked on one path instead of having the liberty to choose.* message to the creators of this game, an A-s-s is a donkey. The bottom is A-r-s-e not A-s-s!!! *+ I just sold pigeon droppings (and cow poo) for 1 dollar.- I just found out that instead of selling the pigeon droppings, I could've exchanged them against a rocket launcher. I feel cheated.+ Lots of readable stuff... if you want to take your time and read everything that happens... and a lot of things happen. When you see 15 lines of text appearing instantly when you walk in a completely normal place you can wonder what the point was, the fact that it is only written and not dialogued makes the reading a bit of a chore. Imagine having to stop every two seconds to read the paragraph of text that just appeared. Yeah. I support traditional text RPGs but I'm not so much a fan of what happens in between. Still, some pretty funny jokes, so yeah, it really depends on if you want to take your time and read everything. I would have preferred a complete spoken dialogue to paragraphs upon paragraphs upon paragraphs of text.+ The graphics are underrated. They frankly aren't that bad. In fact the environment looks pretty good.- When characters disobey orders, they act as if they have no brain and just run to the ennemy without even shooting their weapon.+ The narration that is in place is excellent...- ...Shame that it isn't complete ( AT ALL ), wouldve made for a better game experience.- Characters look ugly.- The same character portraits are used too often and do not correspond to what the character looks like.- The OST is poor. VERY poor. In fact in most places it seems non existent.- Not enough sniper ammo in crates, too much of the rest.- Sniper rifle seems op. Like in any other game.- Steam overlay is not accessible in-game.- No Steam achievements on a game that would be great with Steam achievements.- This game will force you to quicksave every half a second. Which can get annoyingbut is also good training for future life when you will have save your work every half a second by fear of losing it.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Armed with a more meaningful skill system, interesting characters and thrice as shorter in time, this could have been a great game. But as it is it's only decent.There are only two ways to play this game: distribute all the non-useless skills among your crew or prepare your♥♥♥♥♥to get continuously ♥♥♥♥ed in the second half. Forget roleplaying and meaningful characters: they are just upgradeable slots for your skills, 3 skills per head is about right. And, well, Scotchmo. And since skil budgeting is the key game element, you'll get constantly frustrated as you hire new crew members that deem your already distributed skills useless —unless you get a list of companions on the wiki beforehand and plan accordingly. And get a list of guns as well, as some of the fight skills fall into the “useless” category.The story itself is not that bad, and the game delivers in terms of humour. But despite that, it's too long on the verge of boring.It could have greatly benefited gameplay-wise by promoting importance to game choices: allowing only the main player skills to be used outside combat — but I guess that would be against the Wasteland tradition; allowing companion skills to be summed in some way that having several spesialists in, say, lockpicking, would be of benefit.Right now I see little interest in playing a game that takes this much time and urges the players to use the same only-one-correct style. Seen one gameplay, seen them all.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												The most pretentious project of 2014 does not deserve the hype it gets, not in the least.Yes, I am one of those who expected a new Fallout (Thank you, Brian ♥♥♥♥go) and got severely let down, but even without any more or less raised expectations, this game is a drag. Because this game is actually one of the worst games I've ever payed for, I will only rant about the features that annoyed me the most, I'm not going to mention every single bug (and theres millions of those).It's not an RPG, as it claims, as there is no interesting NPC-interaction at all, the only thing you get (or don't get, if you do not pass the appropriate skill check) are a bunch of dialogue options that may influence your task at hand, but have no influence on the game world whatsoever.It's a game of boring little scavenger-hunt style quests that losely tie to one another because they take place in the same game and are a prerequisite to be done if you want to finish the main story line.Also, if you dont follow the red line exactly the way the game wants you to, you will eventually end up "breaking quests" and that is merely frustrating.There is no real character development for your team, your guys are basically tools. The  best description I've read in a different review was the comparison of your party with a swiss army knife. Locked door? - flip our your lockpick guy. Difficult NPC? - flip out the loudmouth.Attributes dont really matter. Max your intelligence to gain the maximum amount of skill points per level, max your coordination for maximmum Action Points. There you go, easy game.(Anyway, how deep do you need to have your head stuck up your own butt to call your Attribute system "C.L.A.S.S.I.C"? That is not only a ripoff of the "S.P.E.C.I.A.L." joke, no, it's just like masturbating about how good your game used to be back then. But then again - why have I never heard of it before this sequel?)Well, then there's the tactical aspect of the game. Or is it? Nah, it's not.As stated in various reviews before this here one, there is nothing tactical about the combat system. There is one special skill, headshot which will deal double the damage, cost 2 more ap to use than a normal shot, and can not hit critically. In 99% of the situations you'll encounter it will simply be more useful to fire two standard shots instead, as you will most likely have the ap for those and they deal at least the same amount of damage as one headshot, probably though even more, because they can hit critically. You will not have enough AP to fire two headshots in one round. Never.Unarmed fighters can not attack diagonally. Only a selected variety of melee weapons can do that. What the...??!?! Thats just a cheap and lazy attempt at adding any difficulty to a game where the best thing the AI can do is run into range and shoot/ club at you. That's plain Blueshirt.Changing the difficulty basically makes your enemies bullet sponges. More Blueshirt.I have still not beaten the game, simply because it is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ boring and frustrating.It does have bright moments of genius, so I'm giving it more than 20%, but all in all this game is an utterly chaotic lazy piece of programming.Fargo claims, the game has "More written words than all LOTR-books combined!" Well, if you put a horde of Orang-Utans into a room full of typewriters, they'll eventually end up writing shakespeare. I believe this is exactly what happened during the development of this game.3/10, don't buy Wastemoney 2. Not even at a later and/or patched state.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Hello, here is my little Wasteland 2 review.The game is a turn based squad based tactical game with roleplaying elements. It plays in Arizona and LA after an nuclear&chemical apocalypse. So you will have to deal with Raiders, Bandits, giant animals, killer nuns, robots, cyborgs and other stuff.The production value and grafic quality is abysmal. The character models look atrocious, the level maps are bland and uninspired with next to unique landscapes to discover. The combat system has not many options to it. You have 2 skills to use in battle. Crouch and headshot. Your combat performance is calculated by your attributes, ranged weapons coordination, melee weapon strength. Your action points are calculated by speed, coordination and intelligence. Your weapon skill in blunt w, bladed w, smg, hand gun, energy weapon, assault rifle, heavy w increase your hitrate. When maxing your preffered weapon skill you can't improve your character anymore. The only thing to do are distributing attribute points. You get 1 for every ten level extra to spent. Now that is not really very exciting. You have no special skills beside animal whisperer and computer science to use in battle. those are used to hack robot or befriend animals to fight a short period of time on your side.Combat AI: All battles play the same, the AI enemies rush into maxrange or into melee range and start shooting hitting your characters. You do the same. I found no unique encounters beside one battle against tinker the cyborg in Damonta. The only thing you do there is hack some terminals before combat to safe a girl from dying. The AI melee fighter can run all the battle map to your characters in one turn. They can bypass your melee front fighters and attack your ranged characters. You can not block them, tackle them, stun them to help your ranged out. The only thing is to take them out really quick with all of your characters shooting them. The level design is really simplistic. The maps feel boring and bland. The only thing to explore are containers squattered over the map. For these containers you need your 5 "roleplaying" skills, lock pick, safe knacking, demolition, computer science and brute force to open them. The loot inside the containers is randomized. Most of the time you only get some ammunition or random vendor junk stuff to sell out of them. The social interaction with npc in the world is rather simplistic too. You have 3 social skills smart♥♥♥♥♥ kiss♥♥♥♥♥and hard♥♥♥♥♥to manipulate npcs with predefined keywords, but only the first time you see the keywords. When you close the social interaction screen the unused manipulation keywords just disappear.Crafting: Weapon smithing is the crafting in this game. When your weapon smithing skill is high enough you can disassemble weapons into different kind of things, a high chance for weapon parts and a lower chance for weapon improvements like a barrel, a new magazin or a scope. Weapon parts can be sold at ranger citadell. You can not use all enhancements items on all weapons.  That is as simple as a crafting system can get.The story is mediocre at best. Some unkown individuals make threats over radio. Your boss Vargas is scared. So your job in the first part of the game is to install 3 radio repeaters on radio antennas to triangulate the signals origin. You do so traveling to 5 locations on the Arizona map. Then you fly to LA and have to establish a base and do some good things so the people of LA recognize the Desert Rangers as the new power in the area. I call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about the upholding the Law, when all you do is shooting people who do not live according to your morale standarts. In LA you help or destroy some locations or factions and then go off to fight the big baddies in the game. Fun stuff are the radio messages from the different faction leaders. They comment on your behaviour directly after the event. They make propaganda against other factions and the desert rangers over the radio. Another thing are the different factions. They are not new or unique but have all a different flavor to them. The red scorpions in arizona are just bandits in red uniforms, with a dogloving commander. The Children of the mushroom cloud ♥♥♥♥♥ship an atomic bomb. The church of hammer wants to kill everyone in the world because they are all sinners. The Mannerites want to kill all people that are impolite or unclean. Mathias and his cyborgs want to transcend into artifical humans. The robot Durgan wants to eleminate all fleshbags.I have to force myself to play the game. 90% of the game is combat, and that is so mindnumbling simplistic and boring that i can only bear it for an hour. The game is only for people who really like postapoclyptic games and are resistant to the boring combat system. You will have to read one or two pages of text too. If you do not mind the simple gameplay mechanics, boring combat and simple level design you will have the game of your dreams. But don't come back to me, i did try to warn you.Have a nice day.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												This isn't a horrible game, it's just not really good. In a nutshell if you liked the first game this one is probably worth playing, otherwise steer clear.The good: The writing is engaging enough to keep you going. The handdrawn art is astounding.The Bad: The graphics could be a lot better for a modern game. To give it it's due, you don't spend all that much time zoomed in, so the lack of detail is only horrible right at the start of the game when you're trying to make characters. And honestly the "CLASSIC" system is a pretty bad system IMHO. The stats are bland, and most people tend to just max Int. The skills aren't even related to the stats. How good you are at doing things is determined only by skills. And some weapon skills suck compared to other ones in ways that you can only find out by getting halfway through the game playing the game. Yes, this is one of "those" games. Where you can reach a certain point and find out your characters builds are all wrong, and there's no way you could possibly win. Oh, and the game tells you that cover is very important, and the never gives you any cover that's in anyway useful. And melee is a good skill. So yeah, these guys wanted to make a dungeon crawler. Go figure with who's on the team who made it.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Good game, buried under questionable mechanics.I have mixed feelings about Wasteland 2: first of all, I've backed it on Kickstarted and I really happy about its success. Also, I used to like this game for about 1/3 of my walkthrough, and had some really good moments in it - good enough to not regret time I spent there. However, at one point I've realized this game has fundamental flaw, what will prevent me from completing it - and that exactly what just happened. I'm in the middle of LA region, and significant part of plot is ahead of me, but I just can't stand it no more. I know, for any quest left, for any encounter there will be 100 useless actions I'll be required to perform.Wasteland 2 is a good example why nobody should try to implement gameplay from 1990-x now. From 37 hours I've spent in this game I feel like about 30 were about opening boxes, crates and other various containers, disarming alarms and cracking safes. Not only that, this game is full of character skills for every occasion. Healer and surgeon. Heavy weapon and automatic weapon. Kiss a-s-s and smart a-s-s, and some other a-s-s - all related to one thing - dialogs. There is even special skill for toaster repair (not related to regular repair, of course). But having too many skills is just part of the problem. Another, biggest issue, most of this skills take real time to perform. It's 15 seconds or so to open a lock. 15 seconds of staring into the screen, it's not interactive. It's not much, but consider 5-10 safes per location - it's 2-3 minutes at best, more if you fail. Rinse and repeat it on the next encounter. You also might be really lucky to have 10 landmines begging to be disarmed - another 2-3 minutes of your priceless lifetime. Add alarms, healing, and whatnot - I'm surpised reloading weapons does not requires time! - and here you go. I clearly don't have The Skill to master all these skills. If you do - play it, it's rather good.

												Wasteland 2 is not a bad game, by any means. But the gameplay is pretty uninspired, the story is awful, and the writing is mediocre at best. If you want an okay time shooting the same three enemy types for a couple dozen hours, then this is the game you want. Seriously, I cannot over exaggerate how little effort they put into the story. You're the Good Guys, shoot the Bad Guys. That's pretty much the extent of it.If you want an interesting, post apocolyptic RPG with good writing, an interesting story, and fun gameplay, save yourself the time and money and buy Fallout 1, 2, or New Vegas instead.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Freakin' finally.  Let's just admit it, 2014 was a crap year for games, especially on Steam.  Finally here's a game that has me thinking about it when I'm not playing and always anxious to get back to my PC.  Hard to put your finger on that magic *something* that makes this game stand out from the rest but IMHO, and with all due respect, the dumbing-down of PC games to appeal to the console set appeared to be an irreversible trend - until this game came out. Yes kids, in this game you have to *think* before you act.  The writing is mature without being dry, nothing is dumbed-down, nothing is overly streamlined.  As everyone else has already said, if you enjoyed the early Fallout games and have been itching for something just that smart and immersive, look no further.  It is absolutely the Best Game of the Year 2014.  Bravo Devs, and THANK YOU for making a game for adults in a year of games designed to appeal to the lowest common denominator.
