content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												For being an RPG game, it really seems to favor FAQ readers and those that min-max every skill.  The game seems to punish you a bit too much for role playing by ramping up the difficulty to fast for casual play.  For example, I've gotten to places where I can handle the bad guys, but I cannot open a door or fix a broken lock.  They need to get the difficulty adjusted properly - I am not going to spin around for hours looking for random encounters just because I elected to try and have fun.I especially enjoyed having Deth randomly pulled from the party followed almost immediately by a couple of hard♥♥♥♥♥checks that only she could handle.  And dumping her inventory into the party's was such an elegant solution - given her high strength, it wasn't like she could overburden a couple of weaker party members or nothing.  That the nearby vendors had no money for purchasing the gear we might want to abandon continued the roll of peerless game design.Anyhow, it quickly becomes evident where the heavily tested portions of the game end and the raw, less refined squishy bits begin.  Yeah, this game feels like it was hurried a bit too much and could have used more time removing needless frustrations.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Tedious. That's my opinion of this game in one word. The plot and events often feel extremely bare-bones or predictable, and by the final fight I stopped caring. Bugs and all the choices I couldn't make kept me from ever slipping into role-play, and the whole perspective the game has on a post-apocalyptic wasteland was too generic to help. The gameplay is simple numbers-based RPG nonsense with emphasis on guns. When you're not fighting you'll be facing skill-tests, and it's annoying to find out after sinking several hours in that a particular skill is almost useless or that you failed to increase an arbitrary skill to a certain level. Everything is poorly explained, and I never got the feeling I was doing anything right. In the end I just gave up experimenting and did what seemed safe, even if it wasn't that much fun.I'm never going to beat the game. The conflict... there is simply no demand or impact. It's all as bad as vanilla Fallout 3 was.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												As of writing this review, I have about 90 hours spent onto the game, about 40 of these in the beta. The game has recently come out and received one patch. So that's the state I am talking about. I'll put my conclusion first for those that just skim reviews:Would I recommend to buy the game currently? Nope. Would I advise people returning from the beta to start playing now? Nope.But I am pretty sure if you give the devs three more months, you'll have a good game in the visual style of Fallout 2 and with the writing of the original Wasteland.Why would I not recommend this game now? Too many things are broken: Quests are a core issue in an a Fallout-inspired game, right? Sadly, a lot of alternative quest solutions are either broken or the feedback is not present -- so you keep wondering whether what you did had any effect. And it is even less reassuring when NPCs texts ("You doomed us all") do not match the quest summaries ("You saved everyone"). So you are currently not roleplaying, shaping the world by your interactions, you are tip-toeing around, trying to find a way to solve specific quests that does work. And hopefully the result matches your expectations.Would I recommend to buy this game later, say in the beginning of 2015? Yes, probably.  Quests, story development and game balance are all fixable. Still, I beleive it will only be a good, not a great game. Why? It does feel sloppily made. And I my doubts that a software that started with little care about quality will become perfectly polished by the same team. Now what do I consider sloppy but hard to fix? Some examples: The main method of story telling is text descriptions. Old school, yes, but the texts are really good. And you need to read them, otherwise you will miss clues. Why are they in that small lower right corner of the screen? Why do they not match what is on the screen? Character detail is low. And to keep the game usable, you need to have a long view distance. So NPC portaits are the most important means to identify characters. And the existing portraits are beautiful. But they are reused. More than once. In cases where they do not match the character at all. Those charming young men with character pics of old man popeye smoking his pipe ruin the game's atmosphere, as do the old women looking like young girls with, uhm, loose morals. The second part (which was not shown to the community) was as bad on release as the first part was halfway through the beta. So a lot of work still to be done there. Considering that the first part was released with many annoying problems that had been known for a while, this does not bode well.Recommendation: If you have not played the recent Shadowrun RPG yet, buy it instead (it's cheap). The story telling mechanism in SR is similar, but the game was designed around it. The actions are very limited, but the story flow is so much better. The combat uses a similar, probably also XCOM-inspired cover system. And the feedback about whether you are on the right track is much more direct. Enjoy it and come back to this game somewhere in 2015.Edit: Admittedly, this was not a nice read. That's what I get for deleting things I find too offensive and not putting anything els ein there. This version should read better ;-)

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								I backed Wasteland 2 the moment I saw it flash up on Kickstarter. Being a huge Fallout 1 + 2 fan, it was a no brainer to finally get another game in the same vein as the original Interplay titles. I pledged, watched gleefully as the target was first met and then exceed, I then sat here, twiddling my thumbs, awaiting the day that I would get my grubby mitts on Wasteland 2. When the Beta finally dropped, I have to be brutally honest - despite being warned that it really was a really early build, something felt completely off about the combat, and how the game ran overall. I was left with a slight tang of disappointment, nearing on buyers remorse. But, InXile kept patching the game on a near daily basis, and with the most recent patch, they've made Wasteland 2 run really well. I've spent a few more hours on it, and I've warmed to it alot. Infact, I can see what they're trying to go for, and I love it. I'm really looking forward to the final build.I would recommend this title for anyone who has a taste for turn based combat in their RPGs, while the combat isn't as complex as games such as X-Com, with the recent build it's actually pretty damn fun. The music by Mark Morgan is damn enar top tier, and it's shaping up to be a great experience. I eagerly await the final product. :D

												Hello everyone...Thats would be my  first review for a game.First off i backed this game on kickstarter from the very start, and was looking forward to see it finally.My review in short - this game is a mix of things that cant be mixed.To be honest i havnt had chance to play first wasteland, but i played all Fallout games from first till latest.Maybe a lot of time had passed but i cant say "wooohaa this game feels like previous parts but now it has so many new things!!!"What this game has are1) lifeless locations, poorly made2) in the middle of nowhere ( apocalypses ) there are crates and chests in perfect condition3) walls of text, at first i was reading it but ...gaah.. too much, its like every npc had really bad days and want to talk to somebody4) "easter eggs and jokes only true fans can understand .. ha.. ha"5) bloody crane "cinematic" you cant skip6) poor sprite icons at some places like menus and buttons and such, poor ui as whole, you have to really search for buttons you need7) and nothing else....Im comparing this game to fallout 2, which i think is the best one, and what i can say is - locations look as some first 3d engine test zones some student tried, I think use of 3d was really pointless , its just ruined the chance for the game to be really beautiful, and those bloody "camera blind spot secrets" are really annoying so you have to constantly rotate stupid camera if you want some loot. If you install Fallout 2 you can see as for the age this game has it still look interesting and battles look epic , bloody and interesting. Yes, combat requires to use tactics which is good part, but i think numbers are incorrect, or im unlucky , i had tons of ~80% hit chance misses and tons of 4% jams.IMHO this game could be better if they could did it whole in sprites, like...Fallout 1-2 Tactics! and fix camera and make it closer so you can really se your epic battle.Then while having tons of sprites they can place  one on top of another and make every location unique and interestingThen make only story telling guys have walls of text but not every damn npc!And use working methods and moves, this whole game feels like they said "HAHA we are so epic we will make game which is like our previous games but make it different! This worked bad? We will change it! This worked good? We will changed it! Yeah ! we are the best!"Something like this, uh oh, i dont know will I be able to play this game some more but i just dont want any more.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												Wasteland 2 is a throwback to the classic Fallout and Fallout 2 games set in a different but rather similar post-apocalyptic setting. Its the sequel to the ancient Wasteland game for the (I♥♥♥♥♥♥you not) Commdore 64, Amiga, and simliar systems. The original game is older than I am!As for the game itself... ugh... I want to like this one. I've gotten big into CRPGs lately. The character creation is neat, the cut scenes are live action and extremely well-acted, and the music is very fitting to the wild west/post-apocalypse feel... but dammit this game drove me out of  my ♥♥♥♥ing mind.Pros:- Excellent story and design. I loved how you have to choose right away between two different areas and it completely changes the story based on which one you pick.- Extensive character customization. This may well be the first game set on Earth that actually lets you choose both your nationality and religion. Dunno if that actually DOES anything, but its neat.- Crafting, modding, and so on is ready from the word go (provided one of your guys is a weaponsmith) and you can immediately use any mods you get.Cons:- The combat is horribly stacked against you even on the lowest difficutly. Here's a quick rundown of the issues I had with it:      - I want it to be a rule in games like this that if you have ranged combat, whether its guns or bows or whatever, that your BASIC ammo is unlimited. Especially, and I mean ESPECIALLY, when one of the first areas you go to has zombies that explode upon death and plants that burst the second you get near them. The only way to get past those without getting hurt was to shoot them, which eats up ammo very quickly.      - Some of the fights are so stacked against you it's painful. I get that people want a good fight, but when my four guys are up against four raiders with assault rifles, two throwing dynamite, two more with pistols, and one big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a machine gun in the same fight I might begin to think that this game's difficulty needs to be adjusted a bit. Yes it does come with difficulty settings but here's the thing: I WAS PLAYING ON ROOKIE WHEN THIS HAPPENED! I'm not asking for a free ride here, but for ♥♥♥♥'s sake I did that fight three times and each time my entire team got wiped out within a few rounds because our half of the battlefield is narrow and, again, TWO GUYS THROW BOMBS AT US!      - It seems like my guys miss a hell of a lot. My team had one guy who specialized in energy weapons, one who was good with pistols, another who used shotguns, and a melee specialist. No matter what though, even with crouching, I could sometimes only get about 50% hit chance even at point blank range and this was with them having most of their points in that weapon type.- Status effects for everyone! This involves combat too, but also those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t plants I mentioned and others. It is way too easy for the enemy to stack up damage over time effects on you. Poisons, bleeding, and other debuffs cause severe difficulty in and out of combat, especially when my healer girl would run out of medkits to keep my crew alive. Yes I get that if you got shot several times its very realistic for you to bleed... but in a game where I fight pod people, giant mutant rabbits, and maggots the size of dogs realism can kiss my big fat♥♥♥♥♥Overall: Fans of classic 'crush your balls' difficult CRPGs like the original Fallout will enjoy it, but in the end I found it too frustrating to keep going. By all means have some difficult fights, but when every fight is one that can kill the hell out of your team and I wind up resorting to save scumming just to get past them it doesn't exactly make me feel like the heroic lawman of the wastelands. Go the fantasy route and give Pillars of Eternity or Divinity: Original Sin a try instead.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												No mindexplosion hereWasteland 1 was a revolution. Games on the C64 were simple. Some of those guys and girls created The Bard's Tale and The Bard's Tale 3. They were my childhood heros and a big influence. Bard's Tale series were also quite simple but also quite addicting. Simple 21x21 dungeons with riddles and traps.Then Wasteland 1. Characters had skills. A major step forward. Instead of "You see enemies at 30" would you like to (F)ight (A)dvance or (R)un" you actually saw the enemies. People from your group could break out of formation and move towards the enemy while the rest remained stationary.But what really was special about Wasteland 1 was that there were areas you couldn't enter at the beginning and all you had were mechanical and brawling weapons. And you slowly progressed, solving riddles, making your way. There was one town that didn't allow you to enter and after many hours you finally got ahold of some energy weapons. Yeah baby! And you returned and blasted those arrogant ♥♥♥♥ guards' heads off, looting their armor and weapons and ammo. Then you progressed inside the town to try and solve the riddle, the mystery. Mind blown, truly.Now Wasteland 2.First of all. It's a generic, linear and tier based game with a main storyline and sidequests, all nicely placed in your journal. The first quest after the starting zone quest might seems like it gives you choice but that's just an illusion. It doesn't matter which one you pick. You'll have to go through certain main storyline areas regardless. A game on wheels.There is no skill tree. The tree is a list. And you have stuff like Toaster repair. One would imagine that after a nuclear war toaster repair would be the least needed "skill". Something like camp building, scavanging, weapon repair or armor repair or digging or climing sounds more like it would be something that would be needed after a nuclear holocaust. There's nothing like this. It reeks of simplification and consolitis. A game for the WoW generation.The graphics.... boxes. Everywhere. Characters look like they're straight from Everquest 1. Basic low-poly models. It's ugly. Buildings are boxes. There is no art. It's just boxes. Zones are designed like "hey let's place this box here and that box there" "and place a safe here and another container there". Everything looks the same. Bunch of boxes.The humor... well some might find it funny that some guys dressed in black and nuns carry ♥♥♥♥♥♥ around. Anything remotely philosophical doesn't exist in this game. It's like watching explosions on TV all day. Just that there are no explosions. The story is flat and uninteresting. The humor is like "look someone said♥♥♥♥♥♥♥teeheeheee" aimed at 12 year olds.Progression, as said, is linear and tier-based. Every weapon has an upgrade. This one does 5-12 damage, next one does 8-16 damage. The "weaponsmith" skill lets you disassemble weapons for mods or junk parts. Both can be sold, mods can be applied. Since your inventory is always more or less full you have to pick the weaponsmith skill so your're able to make some money to buy ammo. The majority of the game you'll be managing your inventory, trying to open containers and running around. Zones are made intentionally that you have to spend quite a while running around so you have the impression of huge zones. Worst example is the railway station map. If this game has 60 hours of play time 30 are spent on walking around.Wasteland 1 was an innovator. Wasteland 2 brings nothing new on the table. We've seen this before in other games and better. It promised that my mind would explode like a blood sausage. No it didn't. Nothing mind-blowing to see here apart from the bland, uninspired game. And only because the games of the last 10 years were mostly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console ports doesn't excuse the game to be released in this state.Voice-overs? Few. Most dialogues aren't voiced. Only "important" NPC ones and only the first 1 or 2 paragraphs. This game is unfinished. There are game-stopping bugs. For instance you're asked to leave a party member of yours as a hostage until you solve a quest. You solve the quest and when the part member is about to return to your party instead you get a message that your party is full. You can't hire new members since the size of your party magically shrunk to 7 instead of 8. But you still have to carry around all its gear and ridiculously heavy quest items you can't dispose of because they're quest items. So inventory management got even more annoying.Man this game sucks. And if you voice your opinion on their forums you get banned for it.They blew at least 3 mil USD on this and some say they earned over 6 million. The game is a Wasteland sequel only in name. It's a bad game. Maybe in 2 years if they're not too busy working on titles they're really interested in like this deaders game what's it called again.. Torment you might see a game that's worth the money spent, not invested because you don't invest in Kickstarter games you give them money up front so they can create a game they would like to make and you won't see any profits but a bare-bones game like this.A bare-bones game. No fluff. Don't waste your money on Wasteland 2. It's not worth it.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												I really wanted to love this game. I generally adore turn-based, squad level strategy games. This one has a lot going for it, but it has a handful of issues which are just crippling.First, the camera controls are abyssmal. In this day and age of camera freedom in most games, having such wonky controls is a step backwards. The camera never stays put and constantly resets itself any time you do anything. It's just frustrating to have to constantly readjust the camera because it decided to snap back to some awkward position.Second, the player character models are terrible, low quality and with pretty lousy customization options.Third, the character skill system is just really lacking, "Toaster Repair" being the prime example. Why on earth would they make something out of place? Of all the different capabilites, I have to spend points in a niche skill in order to repair a smattering of toasters laying around for rewards that really aren't worth the expense. Why? Just take that whole thing out. It just doesn't fit and makes no sense from both a gameplay or story perspective. It's ridiculous just for the sake of being ridiculous.The combat is fun, but can be frustrating when you're stuck in combat and can't find why. I really wanted to like this game. I've tried and tried, but I just can't get past the camera issues. It seems even worse with the "Director's Cut."

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I am an old school Fallout 1 and 2 fan who was disappointed with Bethesda's Fallout 3.  I didn't expect Wasteland 2 to be the Fallout 3 that should have been, but I believed it would be a game crafted with love and the principles that made Fallout special to me.  I cannot say that I didn't have fun, but I concluded that Wasteland 2 isn't a worthy purchase when there are so many other excellent alternatives.  Patches can fix glitches and how cheap the game feels-- you can't remember characters because they all have the same portrait-- but patches can't fix the fundamental gameplay flaws.  Most of the missions offer no alternative paths to success beyond mass murder, which wouldn't be a problem if the combat weren't shallow compared to games like XCOM and Banner Saga.  Many skills feel useless or poorly integrated. Traps is mostly used to disarm mines and it gets tedious.  Good RPGs give players more worthwhile choices.

												I participated in the kickstarter for this game, and mistakes were made.I really hope that in October when they release the "director's cut" it becomes a playable game.  As it stands right now, I can't even re-install it, otherwise i'll feel like im wasting space on my enormous hard drive that is nearly empty.Here's a quick review. Gameplay is flawed in several ways including: combat, customization, save scumming, AI is terrible, and the maps are boring and very bland.I also thought that when they announced they got way more money than expected from the kickstarter that the graphics wouldn't be so abysmal.  They describe the landscapes and situations in text, so why not add some of the described detail?  " A power cord runs from a radio tower to blah blah", yet I don't see a cable on my screen.  More than half of the time you will not even see what is described in great detail.  I have an imagination, but im not here to imagine a finished game.When a well known developer creates a game, and the fans and public are interested usually a game turns out pretty well.  This is not the case. It looks like it was made 10 years ago or more. A colossal disappointment for me.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												I really wanted to love this game. I generally adore turn-based, squad level strategy games. This one has a lot going for it, but it has a handful of issues which are just crippling.First, the camera controls are abyssmal. In this day and age of camera freedom in most games, having such wonky controls is a step backwards. The camera never stays put and constantly resets itself any time you do anything. It's just frustrating to have to constantly readjust the camera because it decided to snap back to some awkward position.Second, the player character models are terrible, low quality and with pretty lousy customization options.Third, the character skill system is just really lacking, "Toaster Repair" being the prime example. Why on earth would they make something out of place? Of all the different capabilites, I have to spend points in a niche skill in order to repair a smattering of toasters laying around for rewards that really aren't worth the expense. Why? Just take that whole thing out. It just doesn't fit and makes no sense from both a gameplay or story perspective. It's ridiculous just for the sake of being ridiculous.The combat is fun, but can be frustrating when you're stuck in combat and can't find why. I really wanted to like this game. I've tried and tried, but I just can't get past the camera issues. It seems even worse with the "Director's Cut."

												First off, I like this game.  If you liked the orginial Baluders Gate or Fallout you will like this game.  Feels very much the same except for my reason to NOT RECOMMEND the game.  BUGS BUGS BUGS.  Not the fun kind you can shoot, but the bad kind the made about half of my quest lines to not finish (I played Hollywood after Patch #2, and it was still hand many many broken quests).It was not just that the quest would not clear from my logbook, but also that quest in the actuall game would lock up and be unfinishable.  I'm sure if I did it in the right order, it may work, but in a game like this, it is very easy to not do things in the "correct" order (you kill the guy/steel the intel/destory the base/etc.  before getting the quest).  The game was clearly intended to be finished and explored in any order the player feels is correct, but the scripting does not support it.Other little problems:1)  NPC Pictures did not match the text descriptions or the model about 90% of the time.2)  Lots of unclear timers.  Timers are ok, if the player really understands what they should be doing, otherwise not fun.3)  Old school interfaceMaybe after a fan made "fixed" verson of the game's scripting is done, I would recommend it (or patch number 10 or so comes out).

												The combat isn't that great and some of the stats seem totally useless (there's basically no reason to ever put any points in things like luck or charisma instead of making everyone either 10 coordination / 10 speed / 10 intelligence or 10 coordination / 10 speed / 10 strength for melee characters), but the actual dialogues, missions, and story are great and there's plenty of content so if you liked the first two fallout games you'll probably like this. number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												3/5I've been playing Wasteland 2 and feeling a little disappointed. It's too retro.The pacing is on the slow side, and it's not the best-looking game.OK, it's set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland, but character designs and backgrounds can still look good. Like, the environments of Bethesda's Fallout 3 were dramatic and beautiful even if they were all drab gray ruins. My performance should not be this poor for a game that looks like this.And the skill use is just a touch too slow. If one needs to save-load-spam to get past a lock, or if there are a lot of mines to disarm, it's tedious.And the combat does not feel as dynamic and tactical as, say, the X-Com remake's. There's really only 2 options: headshot and burst, otherwise one crouches the team and shoots and that's it for tactics. X-Com's system encouraged much more movement and flanking, as well as having special abilities by class that affect tactics. And of course, Divinity: Original Sin introduces a lot of tricks with spell interactions that can control the battlefield, or that rapidly move characters around the battlefield. Compared to X-Com and D:OS, the combat in W2 feels primitive. Also, it REALLY needs formation options. It's damn tedious having to individually click on the characters to spread them out before triggering combat. Most of the time I just have them clustered up non-optimally because I can get away with it, but it would have been nice if there were Baldur's Gate style formations. If there is an option for this and I'm just too slack to find it in the interface, please, tell me.If I hadn't played Divinity: Original Sin or X-Com, I would probably really enjoy Wasteland 2. It's still a decent game, but it feels like D:OS just does it better. It's prettier, the combat is more fun, the pacing is better....Wasteland 2 feels like there was a little too much old-school thinking limiting their design decisions.And some of the mechanics just plain feel WEIRD. Like how disconnected attributes are from skill use. Or the way energy weapons work with armor. There should NEVER be a situation where it's better to have lower armor, that's just dumb.Plus there are too many skills that cover similar things like lockpick + safecracaking, 3 skills all covering dialogue, etc. Do shotguns, rifles, sniper rifles, smgs really all need separate skills? It ought to just be small arms, long arms, energy weapons and heavy. It seems COMPLETELY random that toaster repair requires its own skill. Normally, I'd still recommend this game as it's still above average, but there are SO many great games out or soon to be out; I would hold this purchase until it's on sale.I'm frankly astonished at how many people seem to love it. I mean, it's okay, and I'm still going to finish it, but they write like they love it. Did they not also play Divinity: Original Sin, an also crowdfunded game that is superior in nearly every way? I loved the old school rpgs too (the Fallout games, the Infinity Engine games, the gold box games), but a great deal of the good feelings around this game seem to be driven by nostalgia more than what it actually delivers.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												I love the character creation skills; I love the concept; I love rpgs. This game has (had?) so much potential. Much like a modern apocalyptic version of Arcanum (that great isometric steampunk game from Sierra).Unfortunately, the quests and storyline are absolutely, beyond description-justice, terrible. It's like one long errand.There's a part of the early game where you contract a life-threatening disease (and there's a timer) and you think "omg I don't care about anything right now except curing my characters... hurry up and cure my characters so I can go back to enjoying the game". Then you find out that it's like a 30-part quest just to get the cure. It's not fun. I flew past all the areas because of that damn plague timer. I would describe the experience like being stuck in a mosh pit and you have diarrhea... and you see the restroom way off in the distance... but there are 12 locked grates, poison gas, 15 diaglog-ridden side-quests between it and you, and once you reach it you realize it's just a sign and the bathrooms are out of order, so you have to go back the way you came, behind the building, and crap near the dumpsters.I digress.Seriously though, I had a blast with the first quest. It seems like it would be so much fun if it were a tactical combat rpg like it leads you to think... not like the errand-running puzzle fest where every corridor is blocked off and leads to a another 1hr side quest which has 2 locked doors which requires 2 more side quests. It's the kind of puzzle maze nonsense that would make Hansel and Gretel blush. Quests go like this:  you need X. To do X you need to go on the other side of the map. Oh, it's blocked. Ok, 3 fetch quests to unblock this. Great. Oh, you failed your computer check? Gotta go around. Oh but in order to go around you need to fix this broken generator. Ah, right, you'll need John from Across-The-Map again to give you the part you need to fix it. John needs you to find his missing heirloom though first before he can trust you. *long hours of clicking and walking*. Ok, here's the item, got the part, walk across the map, fix the generator, got one of the 3 fetch-quest items. Return the part. Go to 2nd fetch quest.♥♥♥♥♥♥ path is blocked. Need 2 more quests to unlock the door...Meanwhile, the timer is ticking down and your plague-ridden party is slowly dying. Ugh.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Hints of greatness marred by poor design.  If one's goal as a developer is to revive classical game mechanics, one has to be sure of actually improving upon them.  Wasteland 2 is ultimately a pale imitation.  The Unity engine powering WL2  performs poorly, looks bad, and is accompanied by fairly unimpressive audio throughout.  The crux of the game, combat, is unbalanced and uninteresting.  But for all its faults, is Wasteland 2 worth a play for true fans of the long-dormant genre?A big part of making a believable wasteland lies in making sure the details standout.  With few exceptions, WL2 fails to create the visual and audio cues necessary toward really immersing the player.  Instead of supplementing the audio/visual presentation of an area, WL2 instead opts to incessantly hurl descriptive text.  What would have been a charming callback to games of yesteryear is instead used, endlessly, in an attempt to cover up lackluster design.  Environments and the denizens therein are hopelessly underdeveloped, with the biggest culprit being the severe lack of character portraits.  I've met no fewer than three distinct characters all using the exact same portrait.  In a game prided for its community support, surely the developers could have reached out to fans for some more variation.  Character models themselves are messy, blurry, blocky affairs complemented by unnatural animation.  But enough about presentation; true fans of Wasteland, Fallout et al would never disparage a game for not looking like it was developed by Crytek.They would, however, disparage a game for playing poorly.  Right off the bat, player creation hammers the player with boundless stats whose longterm value is questionable at best.  How does .1 combat speed affect units?  How about +1 initiative?  What's the difference between selecting 4 intelligence and 5?  It is all too easy to hamstring oneself out the gate because the game does a remarkably poor job explaining all this.  The value of character skills runs the gamut, as well: after selecting a Mechanic skill for one of my units, I progressed through the game  almost never having been able to use it.  Why is lockpicking separate from safe cracking?  Why is alarm disarming separate from trap disarming?  Why can virtually any character, regardless of skill, use the supremely powerful (and rare) explosive weapons to perfect effect?  The skills screen tells me ammo for assault rifles and sniper rifles is more expensive than for handguns and submachine guns, and yet later on in the wastes the opposite holds true.  When the absolute basic mechanics at work in a game are flawed, the entire experience suffers for it.Speaking of flawed mechanics, how about that combat?  In a word, it's broken.  There's a slew of weapon types from which to choose, but some end up being significantly stronger than others.  Player characters never have quite enough skill points to be godlike killing machines, and if you've chosen poorly, there's no way to get those points back.  For a great stretch of the game my party featured two melee characters, but the few weapons available to them put said characters at an enormous disadvantage.  The heavy armor you'd expect to pair with such combatants instead hampers their movement to such a degree that they may spend half the battle simpliy shuttling between enemies.  And the enemies?  In a game featuring up to seven player-controlled characters (Take that, X-Com!), competent AI is a must.  Unfortunately, and this is the absolute biggest thorn in WL2's side, the AI is consistently absent.  The tactical combat WL2 aims to deliver flies straight out the window from the outset.  When combat begins, rather than units flanking, sniping, crippling, and controlling one another to sweat-inducing effect over the course of several nail-biting turns filled with careful planning and deliberate execution (ala the recent X-Com game), it devolves into one amorphous blob of units colliding with another amorphous blob of units until one blob lies dead.  Mainstays of tactical combat such as cover systems, range limitations, flanking, unit position, fields of fire, suppression, crippling wounds, stealth, targeted shots, etcetera etcetera are either completely absent or barely qualify as being in infancy.  Without fail, combat begins with enemy units covering several screens worth of distance on the first turn to stand directly in front of my characters.  How such tragically broken combat (in a game filled to the brim with it) made it to release is beyond me.So, the bottom line: is Wasteland 2 worth playing?  This is a tough.  On the one hand, as a gamer who grew up on Fallout, Jagged Alliance, Silent Storm and, yes, the original Wasteland, the prospect of an old-school video game renaissance thrills me.  The relative success in crowdfunding of Wasteland 2 and similar games proves I'm not alone in wanting more of its ilk.  Anything is better than nothing... right?  On the other hand, as somebody who puts Fallout 1 and 2 (and yes, even Tactics) up on a pedestal, looking past Wasteland 2's myriad faults becomes too difficult.  On its own, it may be an acceptable diversion.  But next to developer Brian Fargo's previous masterpieces, it simply doesn't hold a candle.  Significant patching and/or modding could remedy or obscure some of the more fundamental issues, but in its released state, I can't recommend Wasteland 2.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Don't get me wrong, Wasteland 2 is not a bad game. The problem is that it's not a good game either. At the beginning It definitely gives you that sweet feeling of an old style RPG, but as you go deeper into the game, you start to realise that it's just the surface and Wasteland 2 is pretty dull at the inside. It's not about some major issues, the problem is that there are huge number of small ones.1) Game mechanics is not transparent. Do you know that high combat initiative allows you have more than one move in a turn? Do you know how luck affects drop rates? How charisma works, is it party-based or character-based? Do you know that formula for action points is (STR+INT+SPD)/4+CRD/2. Sure, you can dig forums and find answers to most of your questions, but you can't find them in game.2) Boring levels. Maps are quite big and full of hidden crates and containers. There are no shortage of mobs as well. It makes progression tedious and dull.3) Most skills are poorly designed. Computer science, demolitions, lockpicking, safecracking, toaster repair - in 95% of the situations you use them to get access to some loot. And you really need that loot and those skills, because ammo is sparse. I found that Mechanical Repair and Animal Whisperer to be enjoyable, just because they are not used routinely.4) There are dosens of crates, safes, and blah-blah on the map. Almost all of them contains some junk, a little bit of ammo and tiny amount of money. It makes the gameplay grindy and tedious. Instead it would be much better to remove 90% of the crates and fill remaining 10% with cool items, and give the player feeling of the accomplishment.5) The storyline is not engaging and full of cliches. It really fits theme of original Wasteland, but what was good back in 80s is boring and repetitive now. It reminds me of Fallout Tactics, which is not cool. To be fair, there are good things about the story as well: i really like emphasis on hard decisions and "you can't save em all" attitude.  6) There are times when game really breaks the immersion.  First time you see a honey badger - it's really funny. Second time, it's ok. But when you see a whole valley full of them, you just facepalm. There are no day/night cycle (fallout 1/2, arcanum, hell - even Ultima 7 had that). And yeah - dosens of crates full of staff in what was supposed to be a wasteland.7) And list goes on and on.Note, that none of these issues are gamebreaking or something. They just take away some satisfaction of the game. So if your are a fun of post-apocalypse theme and turn based combat - by all means get it, but wait for the sale. Otherwise - avoid.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you go back to the isometric 3D-games of the late nineties and early 2000, you would encounter games such as Wasteland, Fallout, Fallout 2, Jagged Alliance 2, and similar. Those types of games set a prescedent and would influence dozens of other games including the sequels to Fallout (Fallout 3 and New Vegas). They were all open-world sandbox games where the first and foremost factor was player choice, and decisions and their consequences.What Wasteland 2 gets right is all of this AND a highly detailed RPG-experience that is almost unique today (check out Shadowrun Returns for another title with similar content). Expect a highly hard-core player experience though, this is not for the impatient.Updated 2014-09-14Wasteland 2 - beta impressions I have been playing Wasteland 2 off and on since just after Wasteland 2 became publicised and have seen it grow from a really buggy game to a somewhat buggy game. The core of Wasteland 2 is the same core as Fallout 2, you're in a post-nuclear world where radiation clouds common, and where people die like flies. In fact, this is the original post-apocalypse game series; believe it or not, but where Fallout 2 comes with a 50'ies style and tongue-in-cheek sense of humour, Wasteland 2 is pure unfiltered social realism. Not that there aren't things that are humorous, I unfortunately believe that they haven't been designed to be such. One of the earlier challenges you might face is encountering a situation where mutation has happened, mutated plants and insects, and getting attacked by gigantic fly larvae and flies that graphically appear... shall we say, funny... doesn't match at all with the general theme and art style which tries to be built on realism. This style-mismatch occurs on several levels, and where I don't have an issue with toasters (which is a Wasteland-classic) I do have an issue with some of the art which seems funny or silly in a bad way. This interferes with the authenticity of the game in my opinion and seems sloppy or not so well thought out to me. Gameplay Gameplay on the other hand is very well worked out, the combat is classic turn-based (á la Fallout 2) and tactics, using cover, and a large variety of different weapons. The combat and the effects of combat is very well worked through. You can even use skills against non-human opponents to distract or even scare animals away, which, when you fight "honey badgers" (yes, unfortunately they're in the game, and are almost as lethal as deathclaws in Fallout 2) are very welcome. Area of effect weapons are incredibly effective, and the encounters are challenging to say the least. Expect to have to do some fights over and over again until you figure out a way to win the fight with as little wounds or deaths as possible. Death is a big part of Wasteland 2 and there will be situations where you most likely will lose a character or two. Consequences are a factor in this game, fortunately there are plenty of new characters you can recruit along the way. From hobos to indians and doctors. Having a wide variety of skills in your party will be essential to making it in the wasteland, and (for example) only focusing on weapon skills in your party will immediately lead to your demise. Thus you will most definitely make use of every attribute and skill point spent, and get punished for every gap you have in your skill set. Wasteland 2 is big on consequences for your actions and many scenarios come with multiple possible outcomes. Expect to be faced with challenges where your decision to help one town over one other will come back to bite you in the butt. Water is essential to your survival in this game, and affects you directly. If you fail to help a city which provides you with water, you will suddenly find yourself in dehydration-station. Ammunition is also something which tends to run out, which means that having a secondary melee-weapon can be the difference between a complete loss and a victory. Also expect to pay through the ears for rare ammunition, so whilst having a sniper in most situations is a game-changer, paying to resupply that sniper with ammunition instead of buying medkits will be a tough nut to balance. Bugs and choices Unfortunately with a lot of complex mechanics, small side-quests and multiple-choice scenarios there are bugs galore, still in the late beta. Some which will be minor (like you being unable to end your turn in combat, thus having to load a save to start the encounter over [DON'T FORGET TO TURN AUTO-SAVE 15mins ON!) to major game-breaking ones where certain choices breaks things. In the beta I've run into at least three game-breaking things that made everyone in a town attack me on sight because a certain script triggered the wrong consequence. Similarly a situation where I was supposed to get certain gear from a quest that would make a dire situation better simply didn't, because the dialogue options stuck, and thus I had to play through a nightmare scenario where I couldn't complete a certain scenario without losing characters with a hitpoint amount lower than 70. Which meant for a lot of the game I didn't have a medic/surgeon and a survivalist... basically forcing me to fight every encounter, and be unable to heal. I really hope that the big patch that comes next week that takes us out of beta and into release will fix these bugs, because this IS a really good game. I have probably enjoyed it more than I enjoyed Divinity: Original Sin, which I was convinced was GOTY and the best RPG I played in a long time. But where Divinity was much more linear, and came with little changes in the story regardless if you played a "bad" guy or a "good" guy, Wasteland takes a completely different spin and makes you feel that your choices have impact, it feels more open world, and while there is a "main storyline", you can easily deviate from this if you choose to. Conclusion and my advice Given how the development has progressed during beta, I think that this game will be released in an unpolished state. In beta there has been at least 2 instances where fixes to game-breaking bugs have broken all save games. I think you SHOULD buy this game, but I think you should wait for some time AFTER release, particularly if you are impatient and are prone to temper-tantrums over the game messing things up for you. In beta I have simply "played past" some of the game-breaking bugs, ignoring the fact that the game didn't work as it was supposed to after making certain choices. This game will probably not receive top scores like Divinity, which was a polished game and graphically a lot more consistent and superior in stability. What Divinity lacked though this game has in larger amounts; is non-linearity, strong causality (choices matter), and a more open world. Where Divinity essentially limited where you could go at what level (which made progressing in divinity more linear) Wasteland 2 instead allows you to go everywhere, and whilst you might be more prone to miss with shots at lower levels, most fights are still possible to win even with a well-defined level 1 party. There is also random encounters, and changes in who you become friends if if you did what-effects making the world in Wasteland 2 much more dynamic. Unfortunately that's not enough to win the GOTY, I probably still think that Divinity: Original Sin is GOTY and probably the best RPG of the decade. But Wasteland 2 in a polished state would probably dethrone it. Unfortunately it is far from polished, and that's especially frustrating given how much potential the game has got.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												RPG side is adequate: character creation and skill usage are the same as in a lot of other rpgs. Except that success percentages mean nothing - skills fail much more often then their success numbers.  Story is very mediocre at best. Tactical side of the game is poor: very primitive cover system and only few combat maneuvers. And a lot of nonsensical stuff like enemies shooting your character but the same character cannot see the enemy or cannot shoot it back because of obstacle in the way, often hitting team mates when having 95% enemy hit chance (see above about success numbers). I would say that Fallout has much better tactical combat and so much better story. And if you wanna tactical turn based combat, Jagged Alliance and Xcom games are much better at it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												I fired this bad boy up hoping for some of the much-hyped kitschy source material with a well-rounded gameplay experience.If you release a game in 2014, it ought to be technically superior to games 10 years older. I felt like I was playing a Croatian version of Neverwinter Nights 1.Crap graphics and boring combat didn't do anything to make the expansive content palatable. I assume there was expansive content because the few missions I did went on and on and on.The first 3 random encounters I had all played on the exact same tileset. SO, basically punishment. Yawn. I don't play games to give my time away generously, I pay money for first-rate interactive entertainment.Anything less than that is a serious failure in this current generation of technology. Plenty of shoulders for game devs to stand on -- no excuse for lack of innovation. Sorry. Better luck next time.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												Bland. Uninspired and shallow combat that is really exposed by being turn based. Lots of runnng back and forth in a very unengaging way. I'll be hanging on for the Game Of The Year/Special Edition/Unity 5/Console upgrade in the hope that they somehow improve on it before I try it again. By no means is this a bad game but it is just very average. Meh. Maybe if it is deeply discounted and you are looking for an alternative to a swords and sorcery RPG.Edit : So I waited for the Director's Cut and I must say that it doesn't change my initial verdict. The game still feels clunky, the graphics are a bit more interesting and the new aimed shot combat mechanic makes combat a little bit more tactical. One thing they have introduced is major game breaking bugs (NPC's vanishing, plot mandatory doors not opening and a memory leak that causes major issues are amongst the more annoying ones.) To make matters worse, 2 weeks after release they still haven't been fixed which makes me question their commitment to support this mess.Still a negative verdict.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												First few sections of the game felt pretty solid, but the second half of the game in particular really seemed to drag on. Worse, bugs started cropping up more and more often. NPCs getting caught on objects mid-movement in combat causing the game to become stuck permanently, cutscenes playing off-screen, broken quests, typos in the dialog, redundant quest items wasting inventory space (mostly the rad suits - how many times is the same plot point going to be a major quest line?), fairly weak voice-acting (Matthias in particular), and just a slew of "little things."There was never really any point where the game grabbed me, which was probably its biggest failing for me. There wasn't any story or dialog that blew me away, and the combat never grew into anything special. It just felt like they took what they did in the first game and made the safest possible sequel they could. I constantly had a feeling the developers saw what they had and said, "Eh, close enough" and called it a day. I can't even remember a point where any of the voice actors really raised their voice beyond speaking volume.I'm sure patches will clear up a lot of the technical issues and typos, but the underlying problems are probably going to last.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												A brief warning up ahead - i have not yet finished the game nor am I entirely sure I am ever going to finish it.Secondly this brief review only portrays my own personal opinion and therefore is not universal for all kinds of people and especially fans of the original Wasteland.And on a final note I have not played Wasteland 1 so I can not speak to the connection between the two.So now that we have all that out of the way here we go:------------------------------------------------------------------Wasteland 2 is a decent to good game but boy oh boy does it make me feel sad almost every step of the way. The two words most fitting Wasteland 2 at the moment are "wasted potential". So many of the mechanics are servicable and many things make you smile for a while but still there is that lingering feeling of squandered potential and the feeling that this game could have been so much more if given more time or more care.Almost every aspect of the game is flawed in some major or (mostly) minor way, which accumilates to the above mentioned feel of dread at the unused potential of Wasteland 2.Character creation seems vast at first but quickly desolves to bare bones customization. The lack of customization on a visual level is almost an insult to most games (even old classics). Characters can be depicted as drawn portraits (from a very limited and often reused pool of portraits) or by a 3D rendered model of your customized avatar that honestly looks kind of dreadful.Which leads to the graphics, I mean don't get me wrong, I like Unity games and the Unity engine is a viable alternative to high priced alternative engines, but man does this game look ugly in places. It gets me kind of angry actually now that I write about it, because I see good art direction and interesting locations that are all sold short by the half baked graphics that look very unappealing and clunky from mid to close distances.The camera is also god damn TERRIBLE. It obscures important items or dangerous traps which can in terms lead to your party walking in mines, cutting your adventure short.This is especially sad since "IF" the game was designed isometrically it would have been completely unaffected by this problem but it had to be rendered in full 3D with a half baked camera pan that obscures something more or less important at almost any time.But all could be well if besides the technical shortcomings there was the hyped up, vast and immersive gaming experience that was advertised and propagated by the media and other reviewers but *SPOILER* it isn't.And this..this just hurts me the most. The game propagates that you have choices and a connection to the world around you but thats only kind of half true at best. The few choices you have ultimately lead to the same outcome and only shape your way to said outcome. And even worse all the locations remain stagnant and dull after you "complete" them.So for example i saved Highport and with that, I doomed the AG Center which felt awful and shows a GLIMPSE of how good the game could have been. But this is just a one and only occurence in the grand scheme of things, there are no consequences to either choice, it just dissolves into person X telling you how you dommed your food or your water support in regards to which location you saved. Thats it. Really.So Highport is save now but nothing happens there either. Vendors don't replenish. No new quests pop up. Dialogue is exhausted. Its practically as dead as it would have been if I did not save it. Basically I could delete the location and never return since there is nothing there for me to RETURN TO! It just serves as an replenish point for water while being sorrounded by two additional oasis' to replenish said water so...thanks..i guess.The bright side is that combat is actually pretty fun. Weapons feel good and useful, visual impact of hits taking off legs and popping heads like watermelons is satisfying. But ultimately the combat system is pretty shallow, with few combat options (Headshot,kneel/stand/Fire Mode/Overwatch/Reload) and even fewer options for cover. Also the system seems fundamentally flawed in its design by providing evasion and bonus to hit even if your cover is flanked by an enemy or right besides the enemy itself.The combat system is pretty much the only saving grace of Wasteland 2 and seperates it from being a bad game since you are going to fight A LOT and with that I mean literally almost EVERYTHING has to be resolved by shooting someone in the face with your revolver. The few places where you can negotiate or even talk to someone in the first place often lead to shooting someone else later anyway. The writing is decent, not great but by no means bad. But it suffers beneath the stagnant nature of the game. Once you talked with someone you exhausted his dialogue and there is in the rarest of occasions a reason to come back and talk to him ever again.One aspect that is not fun in the game in general is how it artifically ramps up the difficulty and punishes you for EXPLORING. Yes you read that correct, the game that boasts it lets you explore and make choices punishes you for doing so by stomping you into the ground by throwing almost impossible to defeat enemies in your way if you decide to go off the beaten and ultimately linear path of the game.For example i managed to fight off the Raiders in the prison area of the game, which was not that easy to begin with but doable. A Raider has somewhere around 80-120 HP and does variable, but ultimately manageable damage. Then i explored and stumbled across a giant robot with 500+ HP that could literally jump right next to me and laser my entire team to death, but hey it's just one right? I surely can overcome this "challenge"? Nope. Three of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s magically jump besides me and stomp me into fine dust.And that is just an example of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t the game can throw in your direction and that is not mentioning the randomnes of the combat itself with weapons with literally two percent chance of jamming, jamming 5 times in a row, or shots with 99% accuracy missing their mark in several occasions, which seems to corelate to bugs inside the system if the patch notes are to be examined.All in all it's by no means a bad game, but it's not nearly as good as it could have been nor is it as good as people make it out to be.It is great fun at places and even creates great moments of simple joy as you find a small amount of ammo for your favorite weapon or find a hidden cache and stock up on valuable grenades.But ultimately it is pretty shallow in many places where it boasts it would not be shallow. The game could have used a lot more time and effort for sure allthough I appreciate the initiative to bring back old CRPGs and their style of gameplay, but that does not justify the many shortcomings of this game.6/10 Buy it if you are a hardcore fan of CRPGs or Wasteland. Everyone else should wait untils it goes on sale for 50%-75%

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												I just want to start this off by saying that Wasteland 2 is not a game I'd usually associate with. I don't generally play a lot of top-down turn-based tactical RPGs. (That's a mouthful...) Even ones I enjoy don't get much of my time.That being said, I would highly recommend Wasteland 2. I've been playing through it on the normal difficulty before the Director's Cut upgrade, and I have to say it's difficult. But it's fair, too. Play your cards right, make the right moves, and every battle is perfectly winable. Every encounter is fair. There are some sections where you can usually see right away: "I'm gonna have trouble with this." But that's usually your hint to turn around and come back later.I've spent most of my time in Wasteland 2's classic version, due to the Director's Cut coming out after my 4-5 day binge on the game. I finally sat down to try out the Director's Cut, and I have to say... I'm impressed. The UI is improved, the graphics are sharper, the game is more responsive. Everything feels so much smoother. Class and character building at the beginning of the game has been improved ten-fold, with perks, and a new, MUCH cleaner system for allocating points (Which I have to say, I've fallen in love with. No more confusing menus with 30 unrelated options)In the end, all I have to say is this. If you like the more classic games like Fallout 1 and 2, or you enjoy the combat systems from games like XCOM. Or even if you're a fan of newer Fallout's and think a change back from first person to top down would be nice, I could not recommend this game to you enough. And even if that doesn't sound appealing, if you ever see this game go on sale, give it a shot. Hell, look around the internet, you can find this game cheaper in a few places.I'll leave it there. This game is well worth your time and money. There are problems with the game that I've found, and ones I haven't, but so far they're all so minor that I don't feel like they're worth mentioning. I'll update this at a later time if I fend anything worth mentioning.8.5/10

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												The combat isn't that great and some of the stats seem totally useless (there's basically no reason to ever put any points in things like luck or charisma instead of making everyone either 10 coordination / 10 speed / 10 intelligence or 10 coordination / 10 speed / 10 strength for melee characters), but the actual dialogues, missions, and story are great and there's plenty of content so if you liked the first two fallout games you'll probably like this. Though I do have to warn you that the second half of the game is extremely buggy due to a lack of testing, and occasionally quests in that half will bug out and be uncompletable, so you might want to wait for a few patches.

Early Access Review
								About: Reincarnating a classic and influential RPG franchise last seen in 1988, Wasteland 2 is the direct sequel to the first ever post-apocalyptic computer RPG. Much like its predecessor, this sequel is set in a dangerous, post-apocalyptic world, and aims to deliver a strong storyline requiring painful decisions by players and maximum re-playability for those who want to explore the depths of the game. Comment: Wasteland 2 is one of the best postapocalyptic role-playing games to emerge in a long time--and it's not even finished yet.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								I keep telling myself to wait for the release! I keep failing myself, I only play part way through AG Center or Highpool, and I've only given it short sessions since I bouight it. It has come a long way since it was released on steam as EA. The UI in all aspects has been really cleaned up. A  few bugs persist, but nothing game breaking (like having to zoom out further to leave a map in some instances). All in all I am very excited for the full release in August (hopefully)! So lets get down to it. Sounds are great. From weapons firing to people talking, its all well done! Music is on point. I love listening to it, although sometimes it cuts out, alot. This could be on my end, because it does happen in a few other games I own, but not all of them, although worth pointing out. The graphics are generally good, not great, but far from bad... In most instances, you can tell its not quite done basically. One random encounter on the roof tops really sticks out because you are zoomed in pretty close and you can't zoom out very far at all and thats when the graphical short comings will be most glaring. The control response is excellent, They go where I want them to, and shoot who I want. Grouping and Solo is achieved with a little button that takes some getting used to. I'll often forget I have the party selected to perform an action when trying to just select my sniper to take the opening shot, and they will all shoot wasting that precioous ammo! Not really a flaw, or oversight, it does leave you some great flexibilty and ease of command when just roaming. Just got to get used to it really. I highly recommend this game to any fan of Wasteland or Fallout. You'll find this a solid throw back even in this early state. Granted if you aren't on board with paying 60 dollars you could wait for the release where the price will drop significantly.

Wish I could give it a great review. The game is awesome in every way except for it's crazy instability.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												This game has a lot of potential. Every review online will tell you it's amazing and balls-deep in cRPG goodness. I agree with those sentiments, but the lack of refinement in the technical areas leave the game a buggy, almost-unplayable mess. I've had the game crash (literally) more than 20 times within the course of 3-4 hours of attempting to play it. What little I DID manage to play was actually pretty compelling (if a little cliche) and did fulfill a lot of the demands of people who wanted an old-school cRPG. But the real structure of the software itself is very shaky. I don't know if it's because of the Unity engine itself or because of some lack of proper de-bugging by the devs (I suspect both play a part) but every little bit of immersion is torn away because of constant game-breaking bugs. If in my search for solutions online I didn't come across MANY other players who are going through the same problems, I would have just assumed that my PC was not powerful enough, but people with MUCH better configs than me are having the SAME problems with the game, 32-bit or 64-bit, 4GB RAM or even more.It's because the engine cannot support the very large levels and system memory dumps are quite common. The the actualy game hiding behind these technical disasters is, like I said before, quite compelling. I am still waiting for some more major patch-work in the game to make it more optimized, but I'm not keeping my hopes up.If you really want a modern version of the first couple of Fallout games (and ofcourse the classic Wasteland), then give this game a try. Maybe lady luck will shine for you and you'll experience very little of the♥♥♥♥♥♥a lot of people have gone through, or maybe you'll find a solution that works for you. But if you find that nothing works for a long period of time and new bugs keep coming up, don't say you weren't warned.

												Wasteland 2 is the direct successor of the older eponymous title Wasteland 1988. The original Wasteland inspired and helped to give the game the legend of the Fallout series. In return Wasteland 2 again draws inspiration from the early parts of Fallout, Fallout and Fallout therefore 2. These games are intertwined not only post-apocalyptic atmosphere civilization destroyed by nuclear threat, but the big names in the gaming industry RPG as Brian Fargo, or Chris Avellone . So how can this ambitious project?Let good order, that the selection of a new game you can choose either of the pre-formed characters, or let go of the reins creativity and create the proper Ranger, according to your tastes. After creating the desired clubs and intro which is quite unnecessary and that includes images of low-budget B-movie, the game starts at the moment when the player finds himself at the funeral of his brother in arms, desert Ranger called Ace. Immediately after the player's train of four generals sent himself Vargas, commander of desert rangers to see the circumstances of death Ace. The player's group procedure already will grow to new members, where the maximum number of young men can be up to seven. When selecting characters to the suites is very important to the proper distribution of the various attributes of the control arms over medicine to control computers.In this field the game is really comprehensive and there are clear traces of the previously mentioned greats golden age of tensile RPG games. Because the system is so extensive, yet let's go back to the formation of character. Unlike Fallout series are not statistics SPECIAL (for the simple reason that it has the rights to Bethesda Fallout brand after the purchase), but here is very similar system CLASSIC This system played Statistics Coordination, Luck, Awareness, Strength, Speed, Intelligence and Charisma. The basis of each of these player starts at level 3 and can improve it to the maximum level of 10. Each of these statistics affect other attributes of character development, for example. Strength increases the number of AP (action points) points on the bike, which means the number of different moves that the player can perform during his rounds with the subject figure, the number of lives the Ranger, but also the capacity of the whole group. However, this particular statistics needed for players who like embarking on their enemies on the head and the body properly. Thus, it is primarily intended for close combat. On the contrary, such statistics Coordination, in turn, is essential for players who specialize in ranged combat, as well as increasing the number of AP points on the bike, but also the percentage increases the possibility of hitting the enemy with ranged weapons.In addition to these attributes is here yet different abilities, to which it is possible the selection of characters, but of course, an assignment to a new level of investment points. These skills are divided into basic, which include, for example, Barter, which will offer better prices from merchants or airline also Weaponsmithing, which in turn allows the improvement of weapons by various treatments. Another tree specializes in efficient use of various types of blunt weapons, through gun, to assault rifles and rocket launchers. Finally, there are third tree abilities, which include, for example, Lockpicking, which of course allows the player's retinue to get through various doors locked on. Or the Field medic, which in turn saves the player often bleeding partner and at least one member of her entourage would always be possessed. Finally, I mention one more special ability in this tree among others and Toaster repair by creators added before the recession, as for any true regardless of the game. This is because of the possibility of correcting toasting apparatus which can be found wandering in the world. On successful repairing such toaster can get interesting device, or sometimes complete waste. After completion of the selection capability can even create your character very well. You can customize the type of clothing, race, sex, portrait figures, or even religion. The so-called role-player is there is still appetizer, which you can put for a biography of his own character.Let us go further, however, and the gameplay itself. As you move through the different parts of the map it is important to follow any objects in the area, since it is often possible to find a box or boxes that can hide new weapons, or other valuable items. The bottom left is always located skills identified player character in the middle is the perfect weapon to attack and AP relevant document, the right is very important journal to real-time highlights the various important objects or phenomena around player, which otherwise you can not even noticed. Finally, top right is transmitter with which it is possible to establish a connection to the ground and learn the necessary information about the role player currently on, or can even be due to give an example to capture a cry for help, and thus get the some of those side jobs.Since the appearance of the same section of the map can go to the world map, which could be criticized its size, because it certainly could be greater. To move around the map consumed water supplies located in the lower right corner, but may be supplemented after finding so-called oasis on the World map or even after pumping water from wells, for example, at the base of the Rangers. At the bottom left of the dosimeter is then that player warns against excessive radiation-contaminated areas, which is in large doses, as otherwise, the player's retinue death. Also, there is also the possibility of radio link with the base.The last and perhaps most important mode is tactical combat mode, which starts when faced with enemies. As Wasteland 2 is a turn based RPG, the player has enough time to rethink your stretégiu even before they take it. In this mode, the earth appear square boxes where orange is the maximum number of fields that character can move with respect to the number of AP points. Then the blue fields that represent the maximum number of traveled fields including the possibility of attacking and finally the red circle, which represents the player's range weapons. In this mode, as already mentioned are strategizing and planning ahead, namely the distribution of young men in the field, cover behind objects, charging firearms and taking care of the health game Alpha and Omega.As the graphic page concerns the game can deny graphical beauty, because sometimes they look holdings, or even enemies expressly infantile. At other times, on the contrary holdings look and actually post-apocalyptic game and therefore the visual works a bit schizophrenic impression. After a page of music is still at high levels and audio superbly complements the atmosphere.This year has been for RPG fans tensile quite prolific and Wasteland 2 is one of the games that are worth play, the more so if you're a fan of old parts Fallout, or other tensile RPG from the "old school". For other players, the game offers interesting tactical combat and a great system attributes and improvement characters. It applaud makers, giving them miserable after years of development finally managed to produce quality work is inspiring and a link to the golden era of tensile RPG. Therefore, we do not hesitate to step into the wilderness!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												I've always greatly enjoyed post apocalyptic roleplaying games. Ever since I first tried the first Fallout game back in the days. This game is amazing. I sadly never played the original Wasteland game, but I've missed the hardships of surviving nuclear holocaust since I ran out of things to do in the latest Fallout game (New Vegas).'I followed this project on Kickstarter and let me tell you, by release I was NOT dissapointed. This game is everything I want in a game of this genre and more. To add to it all, it's absolutely massive and I realized earlier today that I have not yet completed 25% or so of it and I've been exploring the game for 30 or so hours so far.If you have any interest what so ever in the post apocalyptic classic RPG-genre, don't miss out on this game. It's worth every - I repeat; EVERY - penny.Since release there has been atleast one huge update to the game and the bugfixes and glitches are getting adressed and worked out as more and more people dive into the world of raiders, old trainyards and the panic of being almost completely out of ammunition.I love this. This is why I game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												There's a lot to say about wasteland 2. Where to start...       This game is what I've been craving since I finished Fallout 2 and Tactics, and it's great to know some of the old people who made Fallout 1 & 2 are still alive and making games, with the same great writing and dark humor I loved them for.      Although I think Van Buren would've been just as good, this still great even though it's on a different storyline, if not better since it's not stuck on that 1950's-ish theme fallout's cursed with. Instead this game feels like it's 1980 forever.      As for the gameplay, the way speech types work is a nice but refineable edition, and the lack of quest markers give it an unneccisary amount of extra exploring for things you can't find. LIke when I spent 3 and a half hours trying to find planks to fix the holes in the walls of the ranger compund. That's 3 hours I'm never getting back. As for the combat, it feels fun, but not complex enough. I remember the old fallouts having mines, settable traps, and other things, as well as the possibility of today's technology to add prone, advanced bullet physics, and a lot more character customization. The level layout is very good, and gives the game a nice fair level of competitiveness, while the skill reasons and effects leave me disarming and unlocking every single box, door, and crayon box in the game.      Something that also really bothered me that had no real bad effect is how a lot of guns were rechambered to use really small or world war 2 ammo, and there was no difference between a .308 and 7.62x39 round, so AK-47s and M60s were using the same ammo. I guess I'll just be waitng until someone makes a mod where guns make sense.       Last but not least, the experience of the game. I really enjoyed listening to the soundtrack of the game over and over again, (Why? I don't know) and also looking at the digital art book that came with it. I wish the concept art book came with more in it, but what bothers me most of all is the style of most of the concept art was really really cool lookiing with raggedy worn down looking people and creatures living in a mysterious dying world full of dust, mist, gloom, grey, red, and radiation green skies that were all screaming "THIS IS THE END OF THE WORLD". However when you actually play the game, you say "HEY MOM LOOK, I'M PLAYING CELL-PHONE NEW VEGAS!" If only the designers of the game world actually took more inspiration from the concept art and ACTUALLY made it the chilling, spine shaking, teeth gritting, bullet biting, soul crushing, post-apocalyptic fantasy some (now) old people had wet dreams over when they played wasteland 1.       Overall, with this game's good and bads, I'm giving this game a 9.2/10, just because it's harder to find a good post-apocalyptic RPG/Turn based tactical squad based combat extravaganza than it is to find a cat who'll ride on the top of your vacuum while you're vacuuming while running down the sidewalk.      That, and this calmed my fallout 2 "real" sequel withdrawl.       Now I just need to wait for Wasteland 3!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												With Wasteland 2, inXile renews with the tradition that is best illustrated with the now defunct Troika (creators of the great RPGs Arcanum and Vampire Bloodlines): creating an amazing RPG, and releasing it broken and full of bugs.Wasteland 2 is probably one of the best and most immersive RPGs I've played this year, and I would gladly recommend it to all RPG lovers, unfortunately it's also one of the most buggy games I've seen so far. From graphical glitches to an abysmal handling of the camera, the AI or various systems simply not working, most bugs aren't blocking the gameplay itself, and the game would remain great if it wasn't for the constant crashes. Despite two major patches already released on the title, it has been impossible for me to play more than an hour without a full game crash, and it's hard to love a game that doesn't let you play it.Let's not be mistaken: Wasteland 2 is a truly great RPG, and I'm looking forward to being able to play it in decent conditions, at which point I will change my review. Here's to hoping inXile will continue fixing it.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												While there can be no doubt that a lot of love and effort have gone into developing this game, the end result can underwhelm. Compare the graphics with the new kick starter project Divine Divinity Original Sin for example and I'm afraid that they are muddy and way below that which we have a reasonable right to expect in 2014. Travelling across the titular wasteland is disappointing, perhaps a better title would have been 'Only Bits of the Wasteland'. Make no bones about it, this game can also be brutally tough unless you have spent a good while creating your own party and their stats, as the random characters that the game can give you at the beginning are usually pants. Ubermicromanagement of your team is frustratingly essential too.Having said all that, there is a good game here (if you can put up with its fussyness) that can eat your free time as long as you have patience and can dig 'adult' humour... Recommended, but with reservations.
