content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Yep, it's technically awful, even after Director's Cut. Scripts are buggy, graphics is blurry, cut-scenes are idle.Don't expect it to be shiny and cool like Dragon Age/Mass Effect and other pop stuff.Well, why then this game is successful? Brilliant writing, that's why. Every major location feels like it has its own history - the atmosphere, complex relationship between community members, lots of quests with different ways to resolve. When I say 'different ways' it doesn't mean just a dialogue options to kill or to spare the bad guy, it really feels like most of your actions makes a difference, e.g. the order in which you initially speak with NPCs. Your party (4-7 fighters) is the key to go along - from weapon crafting or disarming an alarm to kissing right аss in dialogue, not to mention combat and medic skills, which are well balanced and pretty hardcore.Main storyline is generally linear and simple, but it feels just in tune with whole adventure of exploring the map and dealing with all the mess on visited locations.If you like oldschool RPGs like Fallout, Torment & Arcanum as much as I do, you have to give WL2 a chance.

												Simply awesome. If you ever played the original Fallout game, Wasteland, Fallout 2, etc you will love this game. If you don't you need your head examined honestly. content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												I bought this game thinking I would love it, but only ended up liking it. I think Wasteland paints a cool world and gets you thinking about how the world would be like under such a scenario. There are somewhat believable options that make the game play out in different ways. I found battle system adequate; there are much longer reviews that will dissect every part of it.The main thing that frustrated me was how they sort of tried to keep it "old school" by not including certain features. For one, you cannot warp out of zones and need to walk to the exit each and every time. It makes completing quests and doing side battles a chore, since you always have 30 seconds of running to the exit after you do anything. The game as a whole also depends on the random number generator too much. Stop with the pseudo dice rolling that can make any action fail. End of the day, Wasteland 2 is a good game, but not a great one. Still worth it if you are a fan of the genre.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Wow......people say this isn't like Fallout. Of course it's not, but it certainly, without a doubt feels just like it. I felt the nostalgia all over me playing this.If you take Fallout and put it in a bed with Divinity: Original Sin or Pillars of Eternity, well, this is the result.Now to the break down.The Good:Combat(8.7/10)- Combat is smooth, feels so much like XCOM, a favorite of mine, and is strategically rewarding. It has a good amount of gore and the animations are done fantastically. There are a lot of weapons to use and each weapon is made accordingly making strategic planning and placement crucial.Gameplay(9.6/10)- I couldn't exit the game. I didn't want to. I wanted to keep playing. It has that perfect feel of "Whats around this corner, whats in this box, whats in that cave" you dont want to leave your screen. The voice acting, holy hell the voice acting, it's a work of beauty. And the graphics, the graphics fit perfectly, backgrounds and non-enterable areas are drawn out and made so beautifully.Story(8.5/10)- The story so far, is quite interesting as there is interesting plot changes, eerie coms messages and decisions in each and every corner of the game to question, explore, and discover. The gears in your mind turn and you keep wanting to find out more and more.Character(8.9/10)- I was immediately attached to my characters after I spent about 10 minutes creating my 4 custom squad-mates. I had Bill my strong charismatic Desert Ranger look. Kit, my hard♥♥♥♥♥big-mouthed spy-sniper chick. Liam, my Australian drugged mechanic, and Rico, the young suck-up, Combat medic from the Marines. The level of detail is amazing, the designs and amount of combinations are extreme.The Decent:AI(6.8/10)- The AI is OK. It's not that hard, but it's not that easy either. It has strategies, and tries it's best to use cover and enemy types use their weapons accordingly. Pathfinding(7.3/10)- Pathfinding, I have had a few issues with. In combat and walking around. Some party members stray off at times, and in combat some of them take odd directions when I told them not to take that direction. It's a rare annoyance but is very very nagging when it comes around.The downright terrible♥♥♥♥♥♥Saving(1.6/10)- There is no autosave. Simple. Well, there is one, but it's non-existant. My last autosave from my most recent manual save is 45 minutes ago. 45 MINUTES. That is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Terrible. And in a game like this there needs to be a working autosave. Combat UI(4.6/10)- The Combat UI is near useless. It skips out on basic features that you have to use your Inventory to view like how much ammo one person has on them, and how much armor before that person begins taking real damage. Also, the only health-bar you see is when you hover over that person. It's annoying, when a person is low on health, I will RARELY know that until they die. That leaves you constantly wasting a minute or 2 checking health and seeing how many med-packs you have left.OVERALL VERDICT (8.7/10):Wasteland 2 is a welcoming game that if you're new, you will quickly get the hang of it, and at the same time can be a brutal experience. It is fun, heart racing, and definitely a "What's around the next corner" game that I can easily, easily, sink 80 hours into.If these few nagging bugs can be fixed, it will make the experience a whole lot smoother. And with these issues fixed the verdict is an easy 9.3/10

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												To make it short:Ive played all fallouts and not Wasteland 1. I will try to compare this game to Fallout 1+2 have played one playthrough. It took me about hundret hours to do almost everything as playing the good guy.I REALLY enjoyed the game. I think the game mechanic is very well balanced.If you played the first tow fallouts, this game is something for you. Different than the fallout saga you dont just control one character. You control four plus three (or were it five?) additional characters later in the game. You have to find out which character has which skills since you dont have too much points to spend. I was pretty lucky with doing so with mine since I didnt really knew what I really needed. The quest are very different to each others, also the characters. I wish they had done more pictures for the dialogues since I got sad sometimes about the great character of one NPC but still it has the picture of one of these hobos some meters next to him.The fights are round-based. Different to Fallout you dont literally throw away your AP with just switching the weapon. With the control over mutliple characters the fights are much better than in Fallout. Of course, temporary followers are computer-controlled and do some mistakes like friendly fire and stuff. But usually you dont have these guys with you for very long. You still can shoot them if they go on your nerves, their side quests arent that useful anyway.I like the customination of the characters. Armor isnt visible but you find some new clothes over the time. There arent really any Cons to say. The game is pretty bug free when it comes to the mechanics. The quest in the later half are just sometimes bugged. I almost didnt finished the game because I didnt knew what to do since the log didnt really told me anything at one point. In these cases you might want to look into the forums or steam discussions.Speaking of the visuals the scenery is very lovely arranged. It has too much plants for the setting but still its a beautiful game. But you should read other reviews about that too, I usually dont play highend games so I might have no idea how good graphics "have" to look like.I would give this game a very high rating, something around of 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												With Wasteland 2, inXile renews with the tradition that is best illustrated with the now defunct Troika (creators of the great RPGs Arcanum and Vampire Bloodlines): creating an amazing RPG, and releasing it broken and full of bugs.Wasteland 2 is probably one of the best and most immersive RPGs I've played this year, and I would gladly recommend it to all RPG lovers, unfortunately it's also one of the most buggy games I've seen so far. From graphical glitches to an abysmal handling of the camera, the AI or various systems simply not working, most bugs aren't blocking the gameplay itself, and the game would remain great if it wasn't for the constant crashes. Despite two major patches already released on the title, it has been impossible for me to play more than an hour without a full game crash, and it's hard to love a game that doesn't let you play it.Let's not be mistaken: Wasteland 2 is a truly great RPG, and I'm looking forward to being able to play it in decent conditions, at which point I will change my review. Here's to hoping inXile will continue fixing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												There's a lot to say about wasteland 2. Where to start...       This game is what I've been craving since I finished Fallout 2 and Tactics, and it's great to know some of the old people who made Fallout 1 & 2 are still alive and making games, with the same great writing and dark humor I loved them for.      Although I think Van Buren would've been just as good, this still great even though it's on a different storyline, if not better since it's not stuck on that 1950's-ish theme fallout's cursed with. Instead this game feels like it's 1980 forever.      As for the gameplay, the way speech types work is a nice but refineable edition, and the lack of quest markers give it an unneccisary amount of extra exploring for things you can't find. LIke when I spent 3 and a half hours trying to find planks to fix the holes in the walls of the ranger compund. That's 3 hours I'm never getting back. As for the combat, it feels fun, but not complex enough. I remember the old fallouts having mines, settable traps, and other things, as well as the possibility of today's technology to add prone, advanced bullet physics, and a lot more character customization. The level layout is very good, and gives the game a nice fair level of competitiveness, while the skill reasons and effects leave me disarming and unlocking every single box, door, and crayon box in the game.      Something that also really bothered me that had no real bad effect is how a lot of guns were rechambered to use really small or world war 2 ammo, and there was no difference between a .308 and 7.62x39 round, so AK-47s and M60s were using the same ammo. I guess I'll just be waitng until someone makes a mod where guns make sense.       Last but not least, the experience of the game. I really enjoyed listening to the soundtrack of the game over and over again, (Why? I don't know) and also looking at the digital art book that came with it. I wish the concept art book came with more in it, but what bothers me most of all is the style of most of the concept art was really really cool lookiing with raggedy worn down looking people and creatures living in a mysterious dying world full of dust, mist, gloom, grey, red, and radiation green skies that were all screaming "THIS IS THE END OF THE WORLD". However when you actually play the game, you say "HEY MOM LOOK, I'M PLAYING CELL-PHONE NEW VEGAS!" If only the designers of the game world actually took more inspiration from the concept art and ACTUALLY made it the chilling, spine shaking, teeth gritting, bullet biting, soul crushing, post-apocalyptic fantasy some (now) old people had wet dreams over when they played wasteland 1.       Overall, with this game's good and bads, I'm giving this game a 9.2/10, just because it's harder to find a good post-apocalyptic RPG/Turn based tactical squad based combat extravaganza than it is to find a cat who'll ride on the top of your vacuum while you're vacuuming while running down the sidewalk.      That, and this calmed my fallout 2 "real" sequel withdrawl.       Now I just need to wait for Wasteland 3!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												The Director's Cut has fine-tuned many aspects of gameplay that made the original a little rough around the edges, though at times the game can still feel unpolished.However, if you're willing to look past some initial shortcomings and allow yourself to be immersed in the story and setting of the game, you won't be disappointed.  The breadth and depth of player agency and freedom of expression is reminiscent of the mid-90s cRPGs that inXile are clearly trying to resurrect, and though they fall short of this goal at times, no other mainstream game gives you as many different tools to solve your problems as Wasteland 2.  Though I was skeptical at first, 20 hours into the game I found myself genuinely roleplaying for the first time since Fallout: New Vegas (other RPGs that managed to get me to eschew mechanical functionality for immersion: Baldur's Gate 1/2, Planescape: Torment, Fallout 1.  End of list.)Neither is there a dearth of problems to solve with your plethora of tools.  After 55 hours of gameplay (not counting 20 hours in the pre-Director's Cut version) I finally finished my first playthrough, and even after all that time I feel like there were plenty of quests left unfinished or only incompletely solved.  Which is why I'm starting another playthrough.  See you guys at 110 hours!

												If the current trailers for the Director's Cut isn't enough to convince you to buy this "modern classic" consider this. I have 141 hours on record for this game, and fully intend to spend an additional 70+ once the Director's Cut update posts on 13OCT15. This is a game that rewards and punishes you for the decisions you make in a way that feels logical and fair. Press the red button on a nuke? Yup, you just blowed yourself up. Chose to try and fight a whole map? Yup, everyone there may be dead at the end, and yes there are consequences.Dialogue is reminiscent of Planescape Torment in terms of its scope and quality. Graphics are very nice for a 3/4s perspective on a modern PC.If nothing else, deserves a buy for the fantastic customer-centric view by In-Xile. For backing the game, or for anyone who bought, the director's cut is being delivered for free. Wish more developers were like this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												Remember when your parents told you as a child, that 'Patience is a virtue'? (followed by a series of brutal beatings and repeated lashings with a lead-tipped whip?) With Wasteland 2, patience most certainly does pay off. I say this because the game does take a while to get going – from the outset, you’ll find yourself wandering the wastelands with your selected squadron, like a pack of ill-prepared hobos, with access to limited armaments and scarce supplies. But like all good RPG’s, once your characters begin to become more powerful and greater weaponry becomes available, you won’t be able to tear yourself away from it. The dialogue in Wasteland 2 is kept to a bare minimum and you won’t ever find yourself drowning in an overwhelming deluge of lore, banter or character back stories. Instead, the focus is firmly on combat. Those familiar with turn-based RPG’s will be right at home with Wasteland’s turn-based combat system, with two of the most critical player combat stats being Action Points (AP) and Combat Initiative. A higher number of AP allows your character to perform more actions per given turn, such as firing a weapon, reloading, moving, etc, while Combat Initiative determines how soon your character will have their turn once a battle has commenced and how often they will have their turn throughout the course of the fight.One of the things I found quite surprising, was how quickly characters tended to level up throughout the game. Even with high level characters, you’ll find that your squadron will still continue to level up in no time at all. This is markedly different to most RPG’s, where it typically takes exponentially more time.Although not absolutely necessary, previous experience with similar turn-based strategy games such as the original Fallout games (of which Wasteland 2 is undeniably similar to), the XCOM series and so on, is desirable. For those who haven’t played such a title before, I’d suggest accessing the no-doubt numerous online guides to provide you with a comprehensive understanding of Wasteland’s gameplay and help you avoid the frustrations that you’d otherwise encounter as a newbie to the genre. Along with Pillars of Eternity, Wasteland 2 represents one of the finest gaming experiences I’ve had in recent memory. Veterans of the genre will be immediately reminded of old-school classics such as Fallout 1 & 2, The Jagged Alliance series and the XCOM games, while users who are new to the genre entirely, will discover the true wonders of turn-based RPG’s.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												With Wasteland 2, inXile renews with the tradition that is best illustrated with the now defunct Troika (creators of the great RPGs Arcanum and Vampire Bloodlines): creating an amazing RPG, and releasing it broken and full of bugs.Wasteland 2 is probably one of the best and most immersive RPGs I've played this year, and I would gladly recommend it to all RPG lovers, unfortunately it's also one of the most buggy games I've seen so far. From graphical glitches to an abysmal handling of the camera, the AI or various systems simply not working, most bugs aren't blocking the gameplay itself, and the game would remain great if it wasn't for the constant crashes. Despite two major patches already released on the title, it has been impossible for me to play more than an hour without a full game crash, and it's hard to love a game that doesn't let you play it.Let's not be mistaken: Wasteland 2 is a truly great RPG, and I'm looking forward to being able to play it in decent conditions, at which point I will change my review. Here's to hoping inXile will continue fixing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												There's a lot to say about wasteland 2. Where to start...       This game is what I've been craving since I finished Fallout 2 and Tactics, and it's great to know some of the old people who made Fallout 1 & 2 are still alive and making games, with the same great writing and dark humor I loved them for.      Although I think Van Buren would've been just as good, this still great even though it's on a different storyline, if not better since it's not stuck on that 1950's-ish theme fallout's cursed with. Instead this game feels like it's 1980 forever.      As for the gameplay, the way speech types work is a nice but refineable edition, and the lack of quest markers give it an unneccisary amount of extra exploring for things you can't find. LIke when I spent 3 and a half hours trying to find planks to fix the holes in the walls of the ranger compund. That's 3 hours I'm never getting back. As for the combat, it feels fun, but not complex enough. I remember the old fallouts having mines, settable traps, and other things, as well as the possibility of today's technology to add prone, advanced bullet physics, and a lot more character customization. The level layout is very good, and gives the game a nice fair level of competitiveness, while the skill reasons and effects leave me disarming and unlocking every single box, door, and crayon box in the game.      Something that also really bothered me that had no real bad effect is how a lot of guns were rechambered to use really small or world war 2 ammo, and there was no difference between a .308 and 7.62x39 round, so AK-47s and M60s were using the same ammo. I guess I'll just be waitng until someone makes a mod where guns make sense.       Last but not least, the experience of the game. I really enjoyed listening to the soundtrack of the game over and over again, (Why? I don't know) and also looking at the digital art book that came with it. I wish the concept art book came with more in it, but what bothers me most of all is the style of most of the concept art was really really cool lookiing with raggedy worn down looking people and creatures living in a mysterious dying world full of dust, mist, gloom, grey, red, and radiation green skies that were all screaming "THIS IS THE END OF THE WORLD". However when you actually play the game, you say "HEY MOM LOOK, I'M PLAYING CELL-PHONE NEW VEGAS!" If only the designers of the game world actually took more inspiration from the concept art and ACTUALLY made it the chilling, spine shaking, teeth gritting, bullet biting, soul crushing, post-apocalyptic fantasy some (now) old people had wet dreams over when they played wasteland 1.       Overall, with this game's good and bads, I'm giving this game a 9.2/10, just because it's harder to find a good post-apocalyptic RPG/Turn based tactical squad based combat extravaganza than it is to find a cat who'll ride on the top of your vacuum while you're vacuuming while running down the sidewalk.      That, and this calmed my fallout 2 "real" sequel withdrawl.       Now I just need to wait for Wasteland 3!

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												The Director's Cut has fine-tuned many aspects of gameplay that made the original a little rough around the edges, though at times the game can still feel unpolished.However, if you're willing to look past some initial shortcomings and allow yourself to be immersed in the story and setting of the game, you won't be disappointed.  The breadth and depth of player agency and freedom of expression is reminiscent of the mid-90s cRPGs that inXile are clearly trying to resurrect, and though they fall short of this goal at times, no other mainstream game gives you as many different tools to solve your problems as Wasteland 2.  Though I was skeptical at first, 20 hours into the game I found myself genuinely roleplaying for the first time since Fallout: New Vegas (other RPGs that managed to get me to eschew mechanical functionality for immersion: Baldur's Gate 1/2, Planescape: Torment, Fallout 1.  End of list.)Neither is there a dearth of problems to solve with your plethora of tools.  After 55 hours of gameplay (not counting 20 hours in the pre-Director's Cut version) I finally finished my first playthrough, and even after all that time I feel like there were plenty of quests left unfinished or only incompletely solved.  Which is why I'm starting another playthrough.  See you guys at 110 hours!

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I've played about 10 hours of this game so far, and have been slogging through the story missions.On the first mission, I had to choose between a natural disaster, or a bloody conflict. I chose bloody conflict. I was just learning the game, so I took a few hits, but I never slipped too far down the slope of 'using your fists and only your fists to beat up guys wielding big scary guns', apart from this one character, my designated sniper. She ran out of .30-06 rounds quickly, and she was a sitting duck even though she was behind cover.Know by this point, I'd had someone else go down before this, and I had experienced the urgency of recovering a teammate before they died. The thing is, my sniper was the only one who could have saved the other teammate.In other words, my sniper was completely and utterly screwed, and I watched in horror until she stopped living. At this point, I knew the game wasn't going to be a cakewalk.Fortunately, the game threw some puzzles my way, and that took my mind off my sniper's untimely demise. More good news, I got a replacement sniper. She was a bit temperamental, but she was a better sniper than my other one. Her death was only a memory, and didn't affect me much.It turns out the natural disaster had ruined everything, so I had to go and find a place that wasn't ruined. That place turned out to be a great big place filled with snarly enemies that wanted to hang my crew to tell other people to ♥♥♥♥ off.I approached the camp tentatively, and that couldn't prepare me for what was to come. My crew got steamrolled, even though I was careful.And that was all on the easiest difficulty.I recommend it for masochists.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												Remember when your parents told you as a child, that 'Patience is a virtue'? (followed by a series of brutal beatings and repeated lashings with a lead-tipped whip?) With Wasteland 2, patience most certainly does pay off. I say this because the game does take a while to get going – from the outset, you’ll find yourself wandering the wastelands with your selected squadron, like a pack of ill-prepared hobos, with access to limited armaments and scarce supplies. But like all good RPG’s, once your characters begin to become more powerful and greater weaponry becomes available, you won’t be able to tear yourself away from it. The dialogue in Wasteland 2 is kept to a bare minimum and you won’t ever find yourself drowning in an overwhelming deluge of lore, banter or character back stories. Instead, the focus is firmly on combat. Those familiar with turn-based RPG’s will be right at home with Wasteland’s turn-based combat system, with two of the most critical player combat stats being Action Points (AP) and Combat Initiative. A higher number of AP allows your character to perform more actions per given turn, such as firing a weapon, reloading, moving, etc, while Combat Initiative determines how soon your character will have their turn once a battle has commenced and how often they will have their turn throughout the course of the fight.One of the things I found quite surprising, was how quickly characters tended to level up throughout the game. Even with high level characters, you’ll find that your squadron will still continue to level up in no time at all. This is markedly different to most RPG’s, where it typically takes exponentially more time.Although not absolutely necessary, previous experience with similar turn-based strategy games such as the original Fallout games (of which Wasteland 2 is undeniably similar to), the XCOM series and so on, is desirable. For those who haven’t played such a title before, I’d suggest accessing the no-doubt numerous online guides to provide you with a comprehensive understanding of Wasteland’s gameplay and help you avoid the frustrations that you’d otherwise encounter as a newbie to the genre. Along with Pillars of Eternity, Wasteland 2 represents one of the finest gaming experiences I’ve had in recent memory. Veterans of the genre will be immediately reminded of old-school classics such as Fallout 1 & 2, The Jagged Alliance series and the XCOM games, while users who are new to the genre entirely, will discover the true wonders of turn-based RPG’s.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Wow......people say this isn't like Fallout. Of course it's not, but it certainly, without a doubt feels just like it. I felt the nostalgia all over me playing this.If you take Fallout and put it in a bed with Divinity: Original Sin or Pillars of Eternity, well, this is the result.Now to the break down.The Good:Combat(8.7/10)- Combat is smooth, feels so much like XCOM, a favorite of mine, and is strategically rewarding. It has a good amount of gore and the animations are done fantastically. There are a lot of weapons to use and each weapon is made accordingly making strategic planning and placement crucial.Gameplay(9.6/10)- I couldn't exit the game. I didn't want to. I wanted to keep playing. It has that perfect feel of "Whats around this corner, whats in this box, whats in that cave" you dont want to leave your screen. The voice acting, holy hell the voice acting, it's a work of beauty. And the graphics, the graphics fit perfectly, backgrounds and non-enterable areas are drawn out and made so beautifully.Story(8.5/10)- The story so far, is quite interesting as there is interesting plot changes, eerie coms messages and decisions in each and every corner of the game to question, explore, and discover. The gears in your mind turn and you keep wanting to find out more and more.Character(8.9/10)- I was immediately attached to my characters after I spent about 10 minutes creating my 4 custom squad-mates. I had Bill my strong charismatic Desert Ranger look. Kit, my hard♥♥♥♥♥big-mouthed spy-sniper chick. Liam, my Australian drugged mechanic, and Rico, the young suck-up, Combat medic from the Marines. The level of detail is amazing, the designs and amount of combinations are extreme.The Decent:AI(6.8/10)- The AI is OK. It's not that hard, but it's not that easy either. It has strategies, and tries it's best to use cover and enemy types use their weapons accordingly. Pathfinding(7.3/10)- Pathfinding, I have had a few issues with. In combat and walking around. Some party members stray off at times, and in combat some of them take odd directions when I told them not to take that direction. It's a rare annoyance but is very very nagging when it comes around.The downright terrible♥♥♥♥♥♥Saving(1.6/10)- There is no autosave. Simple. Well, there is one, but it's non-existant. My last autosave from my most recent manual save is 45 minutes ago. 45 MINUTES. That is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Terrible. And in a game like this there needs to be a working autosave. Combat UI(4.6/10)- The Combat UI is near useless. It skips out on basic features that you have to use your Inventory to view like how much ammo one person has on them, and how much armor before that person begins taking real damage. Also, the only health-bar you see is when you hover over that person. It's annoying, when a person is low on health, I will RARELY know that until they die. That leaves you constantly wasting a minute or 2 checking health and seeing how many med-packs you have left.OVERALL VERDICT (8.7/10):Wasteland 2 is a welcoming game that if you're new, you will quickly get the hang of it, and at the same time can be a brutal experience. It is fun, heart racing, and definitely a "What's around the next corner" game that I can easily, easily, sink 80 hours into.If these few nagging bugs can be fixed, it will make the experience a whole lot smoother. And with these issues fixed the verdict is an easy 9.3/10

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Wasteland 2 is a Kickstarter effort to bring back a classic RPG from the 1980’s.  I would recommend Wasteland 2 to anyone who enjoys turn-based RPG’s or anyone really.What I liked:--Graphics and artwork   Wasteland 2 looks nice and has a ton of little graphical details to keep players    engulfed in the post-apocalyptic world.  The artwork maintains the same quirky    “Mad Max” style that was evident in the original game.  I enjoyed the multitude of    character portraits that complimented the in-game characters.  As a nice little extra    you get a digital artbook that shows many of the conceptual designs and finished    artwork from the game.--Nostalgia Factor   One of the main reasons I purchased Wasteland 2 is because of my experiences   with the original game.  I appreciated the humorous details put into the game.  Many   of the items you pick up as junk are reminders of the 80’s--Laserdiscs, Teddy   Ruxpins, 8-track tapes, etc.  I often found myself laughing at some ridiculous piece of   junk that I picked up.  Players of the original game will also appreciate that many of   the locations and characters from that game are present in the new game.  You   receive a copy of Wasteland with Wasteland 2 so you can revisit the original.--Challenging Gameplay  I enjoyed the combat and exploration in Wasteland 2.  I found the combat challenging  and it was refreshing to have “critical failures.”  The realism of having things go wrong,  while annoying at times, felt different from a lot of games.  Guns jammed in the middle  of a fight, lockpicks broke, your demolitions expert triggered a trap while trying to  disarm it.  Too many times players are presented with a cakewalk of perfection and  Wasteland 2 really strays from that path.--Choices  Players are given multiple choices in how to solve quests.  Maybe you’re a shoot first,  ask questions later type who opts to blow up all the Atchison’s rather than work out a  truce.  That’s a completely valid option.  Or you could attempt to negotiate a truce.--Character Design Options   Your characters can have a multitude of different and random talents.  Part of the   challenge in Wasteland 2 is distributing abilities around your group for the maximum   benefit.  Toaster repair is something I skimped on and regretted. Go toaster repair!What I didn’t like:I really enjoyed Wasteland 2 and don’t have many complaints.  For a Kickstarter gameit’s really well done.--Bugs  My first playthrough went really well for about 90% of the game.  It was when I got to  a later zone (won’t spoil it) that things got a little sketchy.  There is one area that will  not work if you do not complete the quests in a very specific order.  It also seems  somewhat unfinished--there are references to places in town that do not exist.  There  have been several major patches that have attempted to fix many problems, but this  one still persists.  It’s not unplayable, just mildly annoying.I would recommend Wasteland 2.  If you have any frame of reference to the original game you will enjoy this immensely.  There are a lot of extras thrown in--artbook, the original game, and the soundtrack--which are fun.

												Fantastic game. 2D Fallout literally. Large party of characters. All customisable at the beginning. Deep and interesting dialogue. An immersive world. Its like going back in time to when games actually had a story... Few negatives:Map travelling is a bit of a letdown. Mainly because the rest of the world looks so nice and going to a flat featureless map with a moving dot gives me no sense of immersion. Bullet shortage/conservation affecting choices in combat is a bit more of a pain than it needs to be imo. At least early in the campaign.Now if I could just find dogmeat to round out my party.....

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												The game can be short and it takes a long time until the story really starts, but man this game really is good once it gets going. I have to express my admiration for this game and the daring they put in to the plotlines and quests. They don't necessarily alway seem that amazing, but once you realize that almost every quest blocks other quests or content, you should being to understand just how daring this is. Most game companies try make you experience as much of the content they laborously crafted in each playthrough.Wasteland 2? It really doesn't even try. You can casually miss by accident or by design a lot of very interesting quests, places and characters. This is extremely daring as anyone who doesn't play it seriously can easily get unsatisfying experience if they don't pay attention.I am also a big fan of the very long support they have given the game that has really fixed most of not all of the problems the game had on lauch.

Posted: September 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I backed this very early on pre its steam debut and I have not regretted it. Infact the initial playable alpha was so polished for what it was that I chose not play any more of the game until its completion. I have dipped back in never progressing further than my first foray to check on the progress and this is truly a shining example on how a kickstarter / early access game should be run.Can i verify that the story and the complexity is as good as the taste I have had? No. Is everything I've seen a solid indication that it may well be? Yes!This will save me until the next Fallout proper installment.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Now only a few days from release, I can easily say that this game is well worth the high price. Brian Fargo's latest work is a crater-deep, atmospheric tabletop-style game, bringing back the best aspects of Fallout and the original Wasteland while leaving behind the clunky interface. This is what a turn-based RPG should be, what Fallout 3 should have been. This nonlinear game somehow manages to have better storytelling and immersion than games that actually try to pull the player along any kind of linear path. You know how a lot of people advertize their experience as being full of choice and freedom? Here is the game that actually means it. No tutorial, no big opening scene, you get about a minute of instructional dialogue for your first mission and then you can go wherever the hell you like, and the game spontaneously punish you for trying to explore so early, like others might.Genius turn-based combat system, inventive characters, perfect DnD Campaign fuel, oddly colorful post-apocalyptic world, and a haunting soundtrack to back it all up. I'm definitely gushing, yes, but this is the one experience in an RPG I've had that has been the closest to absolutely flawless.
